This study investigates production and characterizations of monoclonal antibodies generated against rpo41 clade C epiV3 peptides by employing peripheral blood mononuclear cells from three HIV infected Indian donors that were successfully cultured with interleukin 2 (IL2) cytokine stimulation. The induced antibodies were tested for their specific reactivity against rainbow trout erythrocyte antigen intracellular transport assay (RETIA), ELISA assay and western blot analysis was conducted on whole lysates derived from HUT78 targets cell lines challenged with purified recombinant gp120 Pro542 V3 envelope protein. The outcome identified five IgG isoforms capable of recognizing an exposed epitope pattern across the entire V domain suggesting inverted structures along both extremities that indirectly trigger β sheet conformations are potential hallmarks relevant to immunogenicity response within more heterogenous- susceptible populations similar to what is seen in India’s diversified demographic profile.

title: Informational Landscapes in Art, Science, and Evolution
abstract: This paper examines the Informational Landscapes in Art, Science, and Evolution to explore how humans seek meaning through representation. Through an analysis of paintings, scientific writings, and biological archaeological discoveries throughout history, this study investigates how information is embedded into our interpretations of nature. Our exploration seeks to understand cultural perception as it relates to our perceptions of knowledge by uncovering patterns in the methodologies that we employ while studying the natural world around us. This investigation evaluates the prevalence of informational landscapes within various disciplines with applications for shedding light on both constructivist and evolutionary theories related to human cognitive development.

title: The Evolutionary Pattern of Glycosylation Sites in Influenza Virus (H5N1) Hemagglutinin and Neuraminidase
abstract: This article examines the evolutionary patterns of glycosylation sites in hemagglutinin and neuraminidase, two integral proteins found in influenza virus (H5N1). While H5N1-infected individuals have a higher case fatality than other subtypes, its transmission dynamics are still poorly understood. Through comparative analysis of H5N1 sample sets from various epidemics across different geographical regions, this study offers insight into the possible underlying biological mechanisms for the spread of influenza viruses on an international level. Furthermore, detailed assessment is provided to identify specific sequence motifs that can serve as signatures for evolutionary adaptation. Taken together, these findings may help improve current disease control models by uncovering hidden molecular characteristics associated with this potentially fatal flu strain.

title: Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS): review of common infectious manifestations and treatment options
abstract: The immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) in HIV-infected patients initiating antiretroviral therapy (ART) results from restored immunity to specific infectious or non-infectious antigens. A paradoxical clinical worsening of a known condition or the appearance of a new condition after initiating therapy characterizes the syndrome. Potential mechanisms for the syndrome include a partial recovery of the immune system or exuberant host immunological responses to antigenic stimuli. The overall incidence of IRIS is unknown, but is dependent on the population studied and its underlying opportunistic infectious burden. The infectious pathogens most frequently implicated in the syndrome are mycobacteria, varicella zoster, herpesviruses, and cytomegalovirus (CMV). No single treatment option exists and depends on the underlying infectious agent and its clinical presentation. Prospective cohort studies addressing the optimal screening and treatment of opportunistic infections in patients eligible for ART are currently being conducted. These studies will provide evidence for the development of treatment guidelines in order to reduce the burden of IRIS. We review the available literature on the pathogenesis and epidemiology of IRIS, and present treatment options for the more common infectious manifestations of this diverse syndrome and for manifestations associated with a high morbidity.

title: Willingness to accept H1N1 pandemic influenza vaccine: A cross-sectional study of Hong Kong community nurses
abstract: BACKGROUND: The 2009 pandemic of influenza A (H1N1) infection has alerted many governments to make preparedness plan to control the spread of influenza A (H1N1) infection. Vaccination for influenza is one of the most important primary preventative measures to reduce the disease burden. Our study aims to assess the willingness of nurses who work for the community nursing service (CNS) in Hong Kong on their acceptance of influenza A (H1N1) influenza vaccination. METHODS: 401 questionnaires were posted from June 24, 2009 to June 30, 2009 to community nurses with 67% response rate. Results of the 267 respondents on their willingness to accept influenza A (H1N1) vaccine were analyzed. RESULTS: Twenty-seven percent of respondents were willing to accept influenza vaccination if vaccines were available. Having been vaccinated for seasonable influenza in the previous 12 months were significantly independently associated with their willingness to accept influenza A (H1N1) vaccination (OR = 4.03; 95% CI: 2.03-7.98). CONCLUSIONS: Similar to previous findings conducted in hospital healthcare workers and nurses, we confirmed that the willingness of community nurses to accept influenza A (H1N1) vaccination is low. Future studies that evaluate interventions to address nurses' specific concerns or interventions that aim to raise the awareness among nurses on the importance of influenza A (H1N1) vaccination to protect vulnerable patient populations is needed.

title: Factors influencing psychological distress during a disease epidemic: Data from Australia's first outbreak of equine influenza
abstract: BACKGROUND: In 2007 Australia experienced its first outbreak of highly infectious equine influenza. Government disease control measures were put in place to control, contain, and eradicate the disease; these measures included movement restrictions and quarantining of properties. This study was conducted to assess the psycho-social impacts of this disease, and this paper reports the prevalence of, and factors influencing, psychological distress during this outbreak. METHODS: Data were collected using an online survey, with a link directed to the affected population via a number of industry groups. Psychological distress, as determined by the Kessler 10 Psychological Distress Scale, was the main outcome measure. RESULTS: In total, 2760 people participated in this study. Extremely high levels of non-specific psychological distress were reported by respondents in this study, with 34% reporting high psychological distress (K10 > 22), compared to levels of around 12% in the Australian general population. Analysis, using backward stepwise binary logistic regression analysis, revealed that those living in high risk infection (red) zones (OR = 2.00; 95% CI: 1.57–2.55; p < 0.001) and disease buffer (amber) zones (OR = 1.83; 95% CI: 1.36–2.46; p < 0.001) were at much greater risk of high psychological distress than those living in uninfected (white zones). Although prevalence of high psychological distress was greater in infected EI zones and States, elevated levels of psychological distress were experienced in horse-owners nationally. Statistical analysis indicated that certain groups were more vulnerable to high psychological distress; specifically younger people, and those with lower levels of formal educational qualifications. Respondents whose principal source of income was from horse-related industry were more than twice as likely to have high psychological distress than those whose primary source of income was not linked to horse-related industry (OR = 2.23; 95% CI: 1.82–2.73; p < 0.001). CONCLUSION: Although, methodologically, this study had good internal validity, it has limited generalisability because it was not possible to identify, bound, or sample the target population accurately. However, this study is the first to collect psychological distress data from an affected population during such a disease outbreak and has potential to inform those involved in assessing the potential psychological impacts of human infectious diseases, such as pandemic influenza.

title: A Delay Differential Model for Pandemic Influenza with Antiviral Treatment
abstract: This paper introduces a Delay Differential Model (DDM) for pandemic influenza with antiviral treatment. Influenza is a highly contagious respiratory illness caused by the Influenza virus, which is responsible for more than thousands of deaths every year. Considering its potential severity, it has become important to study preventive measures such as antiviral treatment through mathematical modelling techniques. The DDM proposed in this article incorporates delay terms and age structure that capture these aspects in an efficient way, making possible the identification of optimal strategies for preventative infection control measures against influenza epidemics including flu strain reassortment risks. In addition, we propose an application example of our model to assess connections between parameters related to different stages on infected cases and quantify effectiveness among alternative combination therapies with one or two drugs from different classes of anti-influenza treatments at multiple dosing levels are also considered.

title: Clinical Review: Gene-based therapies for ALI/ARDS: where are we now?
abstract: This clinical review aims to bring forth the current knowledge on gene-based therapeutic approaches for acute lung injury/acute respiratory distress syndrome (ALI/ARDS). Through novel genetic editing tools, gene editing has become an efficient tool for treating ALI/ARDS diseases and other inherited disorders with promising results. As a result of decades of research into this field, various innovative strategies have been developed that involve gene therapy or regulation through small molecules. This paper will discuss some examples of successful gene-editing agents which may lead to breakthroughs in curing these life-threatening conditions. Recent scientific studies suggest that genomic engineering is an incredibly powerful means of managing ARDS by directly targeting mutant genes associated with pathogenic pathways leading to disease. Therefore, this paper will assess recent developments in medicine and provide a comprehensive overview of options currently available as well as highlight potential future directions in the treatment space. Together, this review provides evidence linking genomics technology towards creating effective therapies for ARDS patients and that could potentially improve their outcomes without significant side effects or toxicity risk factors associated with certain courses of drugs taken orally or intravenously today.

title: Antiviral Activity of Some Plants Used in Nepalese Traditional Medicine
abstract: Methanolic extracts of 41 plant species belonging to 27 families used in the traditional medicine in Nepal have been investigated for in vitro antiviral activity against Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) and influenza virus A by dye uptake assay in the systems HSV-1/Vero cells and influenza virus A/MDCK cells. The extracts of Astilbe rivularis, Bergenia ciliata, Cassiope fastigiata and Thymus linearis showed potent anti-herpes viral activity. The extracts of Allium oreoprasum, Androsace strigilosa, Asparagus filicinus, Astilbe rivularis, Bergenia ciliata and Verbascum thapsus exhibited strong anti-influenza viral activity. Only the extracts of A. rivularis and B. ciliata demonstrated remarkable activity against both viruses.

title: Virulent Avian Infectious Bronchitis Virus, People’s Republic of China
abstract: This article describes the epidemiology, diagnosis and control of the recently identified virulent avian infectious bronchitis virus (AIBV) in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). In recent years, AIBV outbreaks have been reported in many provinces throughout the PRC. AIBV spreads rapidly among poultry and can quickly cause high mortality. Specific clinical signs include swollen-head syndrome, severe respiratory distress, trampling reaction and edema formation in infected birds. Avian infectious bronchitis is one of the most widespread viral diseases affecting chickens worldwide. Furthermore, this virus is highly contagious through close contact with infective agents expelled by an infected bird or via contaminated objects such as feeders or water containers. The ability to acquire resistance against AIBV infection has important implications for animal health management programs across Asia and should be addressed urgently to limit economic losses associated with this disease.

title: A comparison of methods for purification and concentration of norovirus GII-4 capsid virus-like particles
abstract: Noroviruses (NoVs) are one of the leading causes of acute gastroenteritis worldwide. NoV GII-4 VP1 protein was expressed in a recombinant baculovirus system using Sf9 insect cells. Several methods for purification and concentration of virus-like particles (VLPs) were evaluated. Electron microscopy (EM) and histo-blood group antigen (HBGA) binding assays showed that repeated sucrose gradient purification followed by ultrafiltration resulted in intact VLPs with excellent binding to H type 3 antigens. VLPs were stable for at least 12 months at 4°C, and up to 7 days at ambient temperature. These findings indicate that this method yielded stable and high-quality VLPs.

title: 2,500-year Evolution of the Term Epidemic
abstract: This article examines the evolution of the word epidemic over a span of 2,500 years from its Greek origin in Homer’s Iliad. Drawing on etymology, linguistics, and history this research intends to map out how the term has been used to describe epidemics across different regions throughout time. By describing changes in nomenclature within both medical and general vocabulary over this period, we will reveal why it is necessary for language use to adjust with changing circumstances. Furthermore, implications that arise regarding our current understanding of pandemics are strengthened by an overview of modern linguistic applications of 'epidemic'. Finally, conclusions drawn from this study attempt to inform doctors and policy-makers alike by contextualizing their language choices appropriately when conversing about public health threats.

title: Empirical Relationship between Intra-Purine and Intra-Pyrimidine Differences in Conserved Gene Sequences
abstract: DNA sequences seen in the normal character-based representation appear to have a formidable mixing of the four nucleotides without any apparent order. Nucleotide frequencies and distributions in the sequences have been studied extensively, since the simple rule given by Chargaff almost a century ago that equates the total number of purines to the pyrimidines in a duplex DNA sequence. While it is difficult to trace any relationship between the bases from studies in the character representation of a DNA sequence, graphical representations may provide a clue. These novel representations of DNA sequences have been useful in providing an overview of base distribution and composition of the sequences and providing insights into many hidden structures. We report here our observation based on a graphical representation that the intra-purine and intra-pyrimidine differences in sequences of conserved genes generally follow a quadratic distribution relationship and show that this may have arisen from mutations in the sequences over evolutionary time scales. From this hitherto undescribed relationship for the gene sequences considered in this report we hypothesize that such relationships may be characteristic of these sequences and therefore could become a barrier to large scale sequence alterations that override such characteristics, perhaps through some monitoring process inbuilt in the DNA sequences. Such relationship also raises the possibility of intron sequences playing an important role in maintaining the characteristics and could be indicative of possible intron-late phenomena.

title: Role of nitric oxide in management of acute respiratory distress syndrome
abstract: The current mortality rate of patients suffering from acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is between 45% and 92%, with most dying within the first two weeks of the illness. In an effort to combat such an alarmingly high mortality rate, various treatment therapies such as low tidal volume ventilation strategies, corticosteroid therapy, and use of nitric oxide (NO) have been attempted in the management of patients with ARDS. Three cases which were admitted to the ICU and confirmed to have ARDS were unable to be weaned from ventilatory support, and nitric oxide therapy was initiated. It improved patients' oxygenation for short periods of time but did not affect the mortality. The patients could not be weaned from the ventilator and expired.

title: Cochrane Systematic Reviews of Chinese Herbal Medicines: An Overview
abstract: This paper provides an overview of systematic reviews from Cochrane Reviews which examine the use of Chinese Herbal Medicine. The authors describe the current state of knowledge regarding the efficacy and safety profiles for Chinese herbal medicines, focusing on their usage in clinical practice. The findings indicate that there is limited evidence to support the use of select plant-based medicines in treating specific health condition, but future controlled trials may provide more objective evidence to validate such traditional treatments. Range studies are needed to evaluate traditional using data gathered over a longer period, as well as a detailed assessment on quality control measures related to its manufacturing process. In conclusion, this article advocates increased investment in healthcare research focusing on medicinal plants and highlights case studies with positive outcomes arising from such interventions. It prompts practitioners while prescribing these herbs due diligence be exercised concerning potential side effects or contraindications with concomitant prescribed drugs or entire other pre-existing medical conditions.

title: HMGB1, an alarmin promoting HIV dissemination and latency in dendritic cells
abstract: This article explores the impact of high-mobility group box 1 protein (HMGB1) on human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) dissemination and latency in dendritic cells. HMGB1, a ubiquitous multifunctional nuclear protein is upregulated in many inflammatory conditions and has been shown to play an important role during HIV infection by interacting with viral proteins or host cell receptors. Overwhelming evidence suggests that both direct and indirect mechanisms are involved in modulating HIV virulence pathways upon interaction with HMGB1, influencing its dissemination within the central nervous system as well as provoking reactivation from latency. However, further research is required to understand the exact conduit through which HMGB1 acts on the disease progression. The current study analyzes how this alarmin molecule affects not just viral copies being released from reservoirs but also perpetuates systemic inflammation contributing to lifelong management associated complications for those living with HIV/AIDS

title: Stimulation of ribosomal frameshifting by antisense LNA
abstract: Programmed ribosomal frameshifting is a translational recoding mechanism commonly used by RNA viruses to express two or more proteins from a single mRNA at a fixed ratio. An essential element in this process is the presence of an RNA secondary structure, such as a pseudoknot or a hairpin, located downstream of the slippery sequence. Here, we have tested the efficiency of RNA oligonucleotides annealing downstream of the slippery sequence to induce frameshifting in vitro. Maximal frameshifting was observed with oligonucleotides of 12–18 nt. Antisense oligonucleotides bearing locked nucleid acid (LNA) modifications also proved to be efficient frameshift-stimulators in contrast to DNA oligonucleotides. The number, sequence and location of LNA bases in an otherwise DNA oligonucleotide have to be carefully manipulated to obtain optimal levels of frameshifting. Our data favor a model in which RNA stability at the entrance of the ribosomal tunnel is the major determinant of stimulating slippage rather than a specific three-dimensional structure of the stimulating RNA element.

title: Complement in Action: An Analysis of Patent Trends from 1976 Through 2011
abstract: This paper explores a timely issue of recent activity in patenting: the exploration of how technologies are complemented through strategic collaboration and competition. The examination period stretches from 1976 through 2011, providing an overview into how growth dynamics have changed across various industries through the increased use of patent systems for securing technological innovation. Using a database restricted to patents with respect to countries we analyze trends regarding collaborating, competing and complementing patterns within their respective markets in order to provide much needed insight into this research area. Given that patents may influence market performance and industry structure, understanding such networked evolution is imperative for those engaged in policy-making decisions related to patenting in the future.

title: DENV Inhibits Type I IFN Production in Infected Cells by Cleaving Human STING
abstract:
Title: DENV Inhibits Type I IFN Production in Infected Cells by Cleaving Human STING
Changes to the innate immune response are largely responsible for increasing dengue virus (DENV) severity and pathogenesis. A recent study suggests that DENV has developed an ability to disable antiviral interferon production in infected cells through targeting a central signaling molecule known as human stimulator of interferon genes (STING). This article will examine the mechanisms behind this phenomena and discuss the implications that it may have on treatment strategies concerning acute DENV-induced illnesses.  Through gain-of-function experiments, biochemical assays and expression analyses, researchers were able to demonstrate how cleavage of human STING directly intervened with cytosolic DNA sensing pathways necessary for activation of type I IFNs, resulting ultimately in inhibition of these host defenses meant for control over viral infections. In addition, utilization of small molecules demonstrated that cyclization of STING was essential for its full activity against DENV infection; therefore providing understanding into why certain mutations can detract from cellular recognition but still enable replication within a cell environment. Lastly, results clarified details regarding prerequisites pertaining to efficient triggering yet particular accuracy needed within and between aspects of both vRNA sensing systems acts synergistically against the virus. Overall, these findings depict novel insight into inhibitions carried out by DENV onto human cellular defense networks during an infectious cycle by attacking specific target sites like STING required for proper regulatory control over type I interferons production which could serve great significance towards further vaccine or drug developments towards eradication dengue infection worldwide

title: Effect modification of environmental factors on influenza-associated mortality: a time-series study in two Chinese cities
abstract: This paper explores the effect modification of environmental factors on influenza-associated mortality in two Chinese cities, using time-series analysis. Seasonal variations of mortality were evaluated according to both total numbers and proportionates due to influenza related death with different ambient temperature, relative humidity and air pollution. To gain insight on seasonal trends, autoregressive integrated moving average (ARIMA) models combined with generalized linear model (GLM) were developed from 2016-2018 data retrieved from National Health Statistics in China. Results showed that the effects of environmental variables seem more prominent during winter season comparing to summer among two study areas when compared their Adjusted R2 values for ARIMA+GLM models. This research result will enhance our understanding on how a complex interplay between environment exposure such as meteorology and air quality affect health outcomes like underling medical conditions and may provide additional consideration framing public health policy pressing issues like future pandemic preparedness or climate change mitigation measures as part of compliance strategy in either city level or provincial domain.

title: Host-protective effect of circulating pentraxin 3 (PTX3) and complex formation with neutrophil extracellular traps
abstract: "Host-protective effect of circulating pentraxin 3 (PTX3) and complex formation with neutrophil extracellular traps" investigates how an evolutionally conserved molecule, PTX3, shapes the host's holistic anti-bacterial defense. In a novel approach, this study aims to define the relevance of DNA-neutrophil extracellular trap (NET) crosslinking by PTX3 for bacterial growth inhibition in vitro, and then validate its clinical significance in human bacteremia. Through cytometeric analysis of NETs formed under varied concentrations of PTX3 incubated with Klebsiella pneumoniae as well as measurements for immune cell uptake efficiency and neurotoxin release by confocal microscopy imaging under identical conditions; we demonstrate that higher concentrations correlate with significantly enhanced protection from bacteria invasion through direct binding leading to phagocytosis or disrupting bacterial membrane via pore formation. Our findings reveal previously unknown ability of this intrinsic factor to foster pro-inflammatory responses against invading microorganisms and those targeting pathogenic transformation by encapsulating them into stiff polymeric networks thereby curbing their spread inside body tissues.  Furthermore, experimentation on patient data collected over period 2014 - 2016 reveals adequate correlations between plasma PTX3 levels elevations in septic shock patients successfully combatted K.pneumonia infection against severely ill counterparts who were overcome notwithstanding temporary swings in circulating quantitative profiles indicating insight into a novel link between microbial elimination defensive mechanisms triggered within bloodstream downscaled upon severe disease progression prior further more intensive outcome centric studies planned ahead

title: A host type I interferon response is induced by cytosolic sensing of the bacterial second messenger cyclic-di-GMP
abstract: The innate immune system responds to unique molecular signatures that are widely conserved among microbes but that are not normally present in host cells. Compounds that stimulate innate immune pathways may be valuable in the design of novel adjuvants, vaccines, and other immunotherapeutics. The cyclic dinucleotide cyclic-di–guanosine monophosphate (c-di-GMP) is a recently appreciated second messenger that plays critical regulatory roles in many species of bacteria but is not produced by eukaryotic cells. In vivo and in vitro studies have previously suggested that c-di-GMP is a potent immunostimulatory compound recognized by mouse and human cells. We provide evidence that c-di-GMP is sensed in the cytosol of mammalian cells via a novel immunosurveillance pathway. The potency of cytosolic signaling induced by c-di-GMP is comparable to that induced by cytosolic delivery of DNA, and both nucleic acids induce a similar transcriptional profile, including triggering of type I interferons and coregulated genes via induction of TBK1, IRF3, nuclear factor κB, and MAP kinases. However, the cytosolic pathway that senses c-di-GMP appears to be distinct from all known nucleic acid–sensing pathways. Our results suggest a novel mechanism by which host cells can induce an inflammatory response to a widely produced bacterial ligand.

title: A simplified procedure for the subtractive cDNA cloning of photoassimilate-responding genes: isolation of cDNAs encoding a new class of pathogenesis-related proteins
abstract: This paper presents the development of a new and improved subtractive cDNA cloning procedure for the isolation of cDNAs encoding Photoassimilate-Responding (PAR) proteins, enabling genetic analysis and manipulation of plant cells. Traditional hereditary research methods involving PAR genes using existing promoters have been severely limited by lack of high throughput approaches in both cost and complexity. Through our simplified protocol involving selective hybridizations with targeted subtraction probes, we were able to successfully isolate two novel PR1 families containing four clones which encode an unlimited number of photoassimilates that could potentially be used as target genes in future generation biotechnology applications. In further studies, these proteins were isolated from a wide variety of species ranging from vegetables to algae, indicating their broad range of possible uses in many different contexts. Through this combined approach utilizing optimized genetic engineering techniques for selection and amplification, we established several promising lines for investigating various aspects related to photosynthesis regarding control mechanisms associated with positive phototrophic growth promotion or negative stress response formation. Ultimately, this method will provide researchers and plant breeders the ability to precisely identify the roles performed by each gene within a given family, allowing greater accuracy when targeting specific individual components over traditional indirect Single Gene Transformations (SGTs). This highly efficient method provides significant advantages compared to former strategies employing vector cloning hybrids or semi-pure feeder cell extractions

title: Evaluation of Approaches to Identify the Targets of Cellular Immunity on a Proteome-Wide Scale
abstract: The immune system is one of the most complex biological systems and plays an important role in defending us from pathogens. Despite its complexity, it remains a challenge to identify its cellular targets on a proteome-wide scale. In this study, we investigated multiple approaches to address this problem. We evaluated each approach's strengths and weaknesses according to several criteria such as accuracy, coverage of immunogenic regions, computational resources needed, functional information attainable and cost effectiveness. By combining these parameters with existing knowledge about immune components, we systematically identified potential target proteins at both subcellular and organismal levels for more accurate therapeutic interventions against disease pathology. The overall results suggest that some current methods may be suitable for targeted detection on various types of cells whereas others should require further optimization before reaching their full utility in cell immunity identification tasks. We thus hypothesize that combining different approaches could lead to novel insights into identifying possible regulatory mechanisms underneath recognised clinical states or the development of inflammation aggravation symptoms due to abnormal T-cell activity associated with autoimmune disorders. This research provides evidence supporting the use of our proposed strategies as efficient alternatives for effective generation of data required when aiming at deeper understanding cellular immunity dynamics within biomedical settings

title: Sentinel surveillance for human enterovirus 71 in Sarawak, Malaysia: lessons from the first 7 years
abstract: BACKGROUND: A major outbreak of human enterovirus 71-associated hand, foot and mouth disease in Sarawak in 1997 marked the beginning of a series of outbreaks in the Asia Pacific region. Some of these outbreaks had unusually high numbers of fatalities and this generated much fear and anxiety in the region. METHODS: We established a sentinel surveillance programme for hand, foot and mouth disease in Sarawak, Malaysia, in March 1998, and the observations of the first 7 years are described here. Virus isolation, serotyping and genotyping were performed on throat, rectal, vesicle and other swabs. RESULTS: During this period Sarawak had two outbreaks of human enterovirus 71, in 2000 and 2003. The predominant strains circulating in the outbreaks of 1997, 2000 and 2003 were all from genogroup B, but the strains isolated during each outbreak were genetically distinct from each other. Human enterovirus 71 outbreaks occurred in a cyclical pattern every three years and Coxsackievirus A16 co-circulated with human enterovirus 71. Although vesicles were most likely to yield an isolate, this sample was not generally available from most cases and obtaining throat swabs was thus found to be the most efficient way to obtain virological information. CONCLUSION: Knowledge of the epidemiology of human enterovirus 71 transmission will allow public health personnel to predict when outbreaks might occur and to plan interventions in an effective manner in order to reduce the burden of disease.

title: Clinical review: Mass casualty triage – pandemic influenza and critical care
abstract: Worst case scenarios for pandemic influenza planning in the US involve over 700,000 patients requiring mechanical ventilation. UK planning predicts a 231% occupancy of current level 3 (intensive care unit) bed capacity. Critical care planners need to recognise that mortality is likely to be high and the risk to healthcare workers significant. Contingency planning should, therefore, be multi-faceted, involving a robust health command structure, the facility to expand critical care provision in terms of space, equipment and staff and cohorting of affected patients in the early stages. It should also be recognised that despite this expansion of critical care, demand will exceed supply and a process for triage needs to be developed that is valid, reproducible, transparent and consistent with distributive justice. We advocate the development and validation of physiological scores for use as a triage tool, coupled with candid public discussion of the process.

title: Virus-Specific Read-Through Codon Preference Affects Infectivity of Chimeric Cucumber Green Mottle Mosaic Viruses Displaying a Dengue Virus Epitope
abstract: A Cucumber green mottle mosaic virus (CGMMV) was used to present a truncated dengue virus type 2 envelope (E) protein binding region from amino acids 379 to 423 (EB4). The EB4 gene was inserted at the terminal end of the CGMMV coat protein (CP) open reading frame (ORF). Read-through sequences of TMV or CGMMV, CAA-UAG-CAA-UUA, or AAA-UAG-CAA-UUA were, respectively, inserted in between the CP and the EB4 genes. The chimeric clones, pRT, pRG, and pCG+FSRTRE, were transcribed into full-length capped recombinant CGMMV transcripts. Only constructs with the wild-type CGMMV read-through sequence yielded infectious viruses following infection of host plant, muskmelon (Cucumis melo) leaves. The ratio of modified to unmodified CP for the read-through expression clone developed was also found to be approximately 1:1, higher than what has been previously reported. It was also observed that infectivity was not affected by differences in pI between the chimera and its wild counterpart. Analysis of recombinant viruses after 21-days-postinculation (dpi) revealed that deletions occurred resulting in partial reversions of the viral population to near wild type and suggesting that this would be the limiting harvest period for obtaining true to type recombinants with this construct.

title: Recombination Every Day: Abundant Recombination in a Virus during a Single Multi-Cellular Host Infection
abstract: Viral recombination can dramatically impact evolution and epidemiology. In viruses, the recombination rate depends on the frequency of genetic exchange between different viral genomes within an infected host cell and on the frequency at which such co-infections occur. While the recombination rate has been recently evaluated in experimentally co-infected cell cultures for several viruses, direct quantification at the most biologically significant level, that of a host infection, is still lacking. This study fills this gap using the cauliflower mosaic virus as a model. We distributed four neutral markers along the viral genome, and co-inoculated host plants with marker-containing and wild-type viruses. The frequency of recombinant genomes was evaluated 21 d post-inoculation. On average, over 50% of viral genomes recovered after a single host infection were recombinants, clearly indicating that recombination is very frequent in this virus. Estimates of the recombination rate show that all regions of the genome are equally affected by this process. Assuming that ten viral replication cycles occurred during our experiment—based on data on the timing of coat protein detection—the per base and replication cycle recombination rate was on the order of 2 × 10(−5) to 4 × 10(−5). This first determination of a virus recombination rate during a single multi-cellular host infection indicates that recombination is very frequent in the everyday life of this virus.

title: Association and Host Selectivity in Multi-Host Pathogens
abstract: The distribution of multi-host pathogens over their host range conditions their population dynamics and structure. Also, host co-infection by different pathogens may have important consequences for the evolution of hosts and pathogens, and host-pathogen co-evolution. Hence it is of interest to know if the distribution of pathogens over their host range is random, or if there are associations between hosts and pathogens, or between pathogens sharing a host. To analyse these issues we propose indices for the observed patterns of host infection by pathogens, and for the observed patterns of co-infection, and tests to analyse if these patterns conform to randomness or reflect associations. Applying these tests to the prevalence of five plant viruses on 21 wild plant species evidenced host-virus associations: most hosts and viruses were selective for viruses and hosts, respectively. Interestingly, the more host-selective viruses were the more prevalent ones, suggesting that host specialisation is a successful strategy for multi-host pathogens. Analyses also showed that viruses tended to associate positively in co-infected hosts. The developed indices and tests provide the tools to analyse how strong and common are these associations among different groups of pathogens, which will help to understand and model the population biology of multi-host pathogens.

title: Injection drug use and HIV/AIDS in China: Review of current situation, prevention and policy implications
abstract: Illicit drug abuse and HIV/AIDS have increased rapidly in the past 10 to 20 years in China. This paper reviews drug abuse in China, the HIV/AIDS epidemic and its association with injection drug use (IDU), and Chinese policies on illicit drug abuse and prevention of HIV/AIDS based on published literature and unpublished official data. As a major drug trans-shipment country with source drugs from the "Golden Triangle" and "Gold Crescent" areas in Asia, China has also become an increasingly important drug consuming market. About half of China's 1.14 million documented drug users inject, and many share needles. IDU has contributed to 42% of cumulatively reported HIV/AIDS cases thus far. Drug trafficking is illegal in China and can lead to the death penalty. The public security departments adopt "zero tolerance" approach to drug use, which conflict with harm reduction policies of the public health departments. Past experience in China suggests that cracking down on drug smuggling and prohibiting drug use alone can not prevent or solve all illicit drug related problems in the era of globalization. In recent years, the central government has outlined a series of pragmatic policies to encourage harm reduction programs; meanwhile, some local governments have not fully mobilized to deal with drug abuse and HIV/AIDS problems seriously. Strengthening government leadership at both central and local levels; scaling up methadone substitution and needle exchange programs; making HIV voluntary counseling and testing available and affordable to both urban and rural drug users; and increasing utilization of outreach and nongovernmental organizations are offered as additional strategies to help cope with China's HIV and drug abuse problem.

title: Heliox reduces respiratory system resistance in respiratory syncytial virus induced respiratory failure
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) lower respiratory tract disease is characterised by narrowing of the airways resulting in increased airway resistance, air-trapping and respiratory acidosis. These problems might be overcome using helium-oxygen gas mixture. However, the effect of mechanical ventilation with heliox in these patients is unclear. The objective of this prospective cross-over study was to determine the effects of mechanical ventilation with heliox 60/40 versus conventional gas on respiratory system resistance, air-trapping and CO2 removal. METHODS: Mechanically ventilated, sedated and paralyzed infants with proven RSV were enrolled within 24 hours after paediatric intensive care unit (PICU)admission. At T = 0, respiratory system mechanics including respiratory system compliance and resistance, and peak expiratory flow rate were measured with the AVEA ventilator. The measurements were repeated at each interval (after 30 minutes of ventilation with heliox, after 30 minutes of ventilation with nitrox and again after 30 minutes of ventilation with heliox). Indices of gas exchange (ventilation and oxygenation index) were calculated at each interval. Air-trapping (defined by relative change in end-expiratory lung volume) was determined by electrical impedance tomography (EIT) at each interval. RESULTS: Thirteen infants were enrolled. In nine, EIT measurements were performed. Mechanical ventilation with heliox significantly decreased respiratory system resistance. This was not accompanied by an improved CO2 elimination, decreased peak expiratory flow rate or decreased end-expiratory lung volume. Importantly, oxygenation remained unaltered throughout the experimental protocol. CONCLUSIONS: Respiratory system resistance is significantly decreased by mechanical ventilation with heliox (ISCRTN98152468).

title: Lipid Rafts and Alzheimer’s Disease: Protein-Lipid Interactions and Perturbation of Signaling
abstract: This paper investigates the role of physical protein-lipid interactions in the perturbation of cellular antagonism caused by Alzheimer’s Disease (AD). We focus on lipid rafts as potential platforms for modulating neuronal pathology, such as tau aggregation and amyloid-beta misfolding. To understand these complex processes to allow improvement of current therapeutics, we review experimental evidence describing regulation through cholesterol metabolism, explore what is known on the atomic-level forces driving protein binding to model membrane lipids, and consider available data on clinical drug trials targeting lipid rafts in human AD patients. Our comprehensive overview reveals an intricate relationship between AD pathology, cell signaling and composition of microdomains that necessitate further exploration virtually at all levels - from molecules to individual organisms.

title: On managing complex adaptive systems motivated by biosystems application to infections
abstract: Many attempts to control Complex adaptive systems (CAS) have failed. Here we try to learn from biosystems to derive some principles for CAS management. An application to managing infections is given.

title: Mekong Basin Disease Surveillance (MBDS): A Trust-Based Network
abstract: This paper provides an overview of the Mekong Basin Disease Surveillance (MBDS): A Trust-Based Network, and examines how trust is cultivated among members. The MBDS was established in 2000 to improve surveillance, detection and response capacities for high impact infectious diseases across six countries: Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, Thailand Vietnam and parts of China. This network has become essential in the fight against epidemics such as Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS), Avian Influenza H5N1, Human Immunodeficiency Virus/Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (HIV/AIDS) as well as various other communicable illnesses endemic to the region with a focus on training front line professionals at all levels. Reflecting on factors which encourage collaboration between members; trust is considered to be a primary factor allowing institutions from varying backgrounds come together. By recognizing risk thresholds expected by each member within the network and respecting deontological principles based on moral responsibility built upon mutual understanding and cooperation rather then force or coercion trustees are better able to share useful information that promotes sustainability through collective action for optimal health outcomes throughout southeast Asia.

title: Dynamic features of cells expressing macrophage properties in tissue cultures of dissociated cerebral cortex from the rat
abstract: This study investigates the dynamic features of cells expressing macrophage properties in tissue cultures derived from dissociated cerebral cortex tissues of rats. After isolating and characterizing neurons, glia, and other non-cell material components in this preparation, various cellular assays were conducted to investigate the phenotypic characteristics of identified macrophages under varying conditions. Additionally, imaging studies allowed for the quantitative analysis of these processes over time using multiple markers. Our results demonstrate a high degree of heterogeneity among expressed macrophages that was found to vary depending on age and treatment regimen. These findings provide insight into the role these osteoclastic or proinflammatory immune cells may play during development as well as how they could be affected by external factors such as chemotherapeutic agents or diseases like Alzheimer's. Ultimately, our research offers new understanding about how changes in environment can influence expression patterns of different cell types when exposed to an ever changing environmental context within host organisms.

title: A Three-Dimensional Comparison of Tick-Borne Flavivirus Infection in Mammalian and Tick Cell Lines
abstract: This paper investigates the comparative efficacy of tick-borne flavivirus infection in mammalian and tick cell lines. The three-dimensional comparison seeks to analyze the effects of viral entry, replication, assembly and exit on host defense mechanisms between these two types of cells. Through this investigation, insights are revealed into how different cell lineages influence virus invasion strategies and thus helps elucidate potential therapeutic interventions capable of mitigating or preventing such infections altogether. Additionally, this study offers valuable insight into evolutionary relationships that may ultimately lead to a deeper understanding of tick ecology with respect to viruses as pathogens. To explore these themes further we carried out an evaluation using multiplex fluorescent imaging across suitable animal models suffering from Flaviviridae infection. We report a unique correlation linking cell type susceptibility level with host response at various stages throughout the disease’s trajectory by identifying host protein markers associated with intracellular viral protection which provided more definitive data in terms of gene expression patterns affected by particular variants within each group showing limited cross-over effect between them

title: Evidence of Recombination and Genetic Diversity in Human Rhinoviruses in Children with Acute Respiratory Infection
abstract: BACKGROUND: Human rhinoviruses (HRVs) are a highly prevalent cause of acute respiratory infection in children. They are classified into at least three species, HRV-A, HRV-B and HRV-C, which are characterized by sequencing the 5′ untranslated region (UTR) or the VP4/VP2 region of the genome. Given the increased interest for novel HRV strain identification and their worldwide distribution, we have carried out clinical and molecular diagnosis of HRV strains in a 2-year study of children with acute respiratory infection visiting one district hospital in Shanghai. METHODOLOGY/FINDINGS: We cloned and sequenced a 924-nt fragment that covered part of the 5′UTR and the VP4/VP2 capsid genes. Sixty-four HRV-infected outpatients were diagnosed amongst 827 children with acute low respiratory tract infection. Two samples were co-infected with HRV-A and HRV-B or HRV-C. By comparative analysis of the VP4/VP2 sequences of the 66 HRVs, we showed a high diversity of strains in HRV-A and HRV-B species, and a prevalence of 51.5% of strains that belonged to the recently identified HRV-C species. When analyzing a fragment of the 5′ UTR, we characterized at least two subspecies of HRV-C: HRV-Cc, which clustered differently from HRV-A and HRV-B, and HRV-Ca, which resulted from previous recombination in this region with sequences related to HRV-A. The full-length sequence of one strain of each HRV-Ca and HRV-Cc subspecies was obtained for comparative analysis. We confirmed the close relationship of their structural proteins but showed apparent additional recombination events in the 2A gene and 3′UTR of the HRV-Ca strain. Double or triple infections with HRV-C and respiratory syncytial virus and/or bocavirus were diagnosed in 33.3% of the HRV-infected patients, but no correlation with severity of clinical outcome was observed. CONCLUSION: Our study showed a high diversity of HRV strains that cause bronchitis and pneumonia in children. A predominance of HRV-C over HRV-A and HRV-B was observed, and two subspecies of HRV-C were identified, the diversity of which seemed to be related to recombination with former HRV-A strains. None of the HRV-C strains appeared to have a higher clinical impact than HRV-A or HRV-B on respiratory compromise.

title: Identification of serum proteomic biomarkers for early porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome (PRRS) infection
abstract: The purpose of this study was to determine whether serum proteomic biomarkers can be used for early detection of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome (PRRS) infection. The identification of such biomarkers could aid in the control and elimination of PRRS across pig herds, by enabling faster recognition and targeting of outbreaks in pigs. This would ultimately reduce the impact on animal performance, improve productivity, and decrease costs associated with production losses due to disease mortality. Serum samples from 64 clinically healthy, virus-exposed but seronegative six month old swine were collected before clinical signs appeared and after these animals were challenged with the Lihe strain. These serum profiles were compared against a database established using four PRRS-positive regionally adapted strains representative of distinct genetic classifications (PC195A/VR2332, NML8907/Harleyville117a2bMv1 subtype II EU, RPRSV‑IL‑12‑3 C449660, D127–00KH145XLA 4va) derived from three countries to identify potential novel biomarkers specific for early stage infection . Proteomics technology coupled with an optimized statistical analysis pipeline identified 62 common proteins between infected groups over noninfected controls characteristics. Among these are thyroid peroxidase isoform P8632_PIG 1 which displayed upregulation after challenge suggesting it as a possible signature marker affecting host immunity during acute phases followed by other related lipid binding transporters like fatty acid binding protein 11B family member A1 which may play a role supporting the immune system’s adaptive response upon resurgence or continuous pro-inflammatory phase signaling chronic exposures to antigens induced by prolonged infectious conditions like existent in cases related to enzootic persistence onset models widely reported leading fatal outcomes in classical PRRS endemic scenarios as expected outcome according epidemiological trends already registered around key areas where viral presence is historically well documented . Identifying serum proteomic biomarkers for Early Porcine Reproductive & Respiratory Syndrome Infection will provide novel opportunities for reducing loss incurred due to this devastating disease

title: Severe malaria - a case of fatal Plasmodium knowlesi infection with post-mortem findings: a case report
abstract: BACKGROUND: Zoonotic malaria caused by Plasmodium knowlesi is an important, but newly recognized, human pathogen. For the first time, post-mortem findings from a fatal case of knowlesi malaria are reported here. CASE PRESENTATION: A formerly healthy 40 year-old male became symptomatic 10 days after spending time in the jungle of North Borneo. Four days later, he presented to hospital in a state of collapse and died within two hours. He was hyponatraemic and had elevated blood urea, potassium, lactate dehydrogenase and amino transferase values; he was also thrombocytopenic and eosinophilic. Dengue haemorrhagic shock was suspected and a post-mortem examination performed. Investigations for dengue virus were negative. Blood for malaria parasites indicated hyperparasitaemia and single species P. knowlesi infection was confirmed by nested-PCR. Macroscopic pathology of the brain and endocardium showed multiple petechial haemorrhages, the liver and spleen were enlarged and lungs had features consistent with ARDS. Microscopic pathology showed sequestration of pigmented parasitized red blood cells in the vessels of the cerebrum, cerebellum, heart and kidney without evidence of chronic inflammatory reaction in the brain or any other organ examined. Brain sections were negative for intracellular adhesion molecule-1. The spleen and liver had abundant pigment containing macrophages and parasitized red blood cells. The kidney had evidence of acute tubular necrosis and endothelial cells in heart sections were prominent. CONCLUSIONS: The overall picture in this case was one of systemic malaria infection that fit the WHO classification for severe malaria. Post-mortem findings in this case were unexpectedly similar to those that define fatal falciparum malaria, including cerebral pathology. There were important differences including the absence of coma despite petechial haemorrhages and parasite sequestration in the brain. These results suggest that further study of knowlesi malaria will aid the interpretation of, often conflicting, information on malaria pathophysiology in humans.

title: High Fidelity Processing and Activation of the Human α-Defensin HNP1 Precursor by Neutrophil Elastase and Proteinase 3
abstract: This paper investigates the high fidelity activation of a particular human precursor protein, Human neutrophil peptide 1 (HNP1), which is carried out by Neutrophil Elastase (NE) and Proteinase 3 (PR3). Our findings reveal that HNP1 has a substantially higher cleavage efficiency when activated by NE or PR3 compared to other elastases. Moreover, we have developed an innovative method based on fluorescence spectroscopy to monitor in real-time the processing of HNP1 with NE or PR3 in vitro. Through our studies, we discover significant insights into the enzymatic activities and substrates preferences for both enzymes as well as their substrate commercial availability respectively. Finally, our analysis illustrates how knowledge about these activities can be used for clinical purposes such as proteolytic therapy for diseases caused by microbial infections.

title: Discovery and Development of Toll-Like Receptor 4 (TLR4) Antagonists: A New Paradigm for Treating Sepsis and Other Diseases
abstract: Sepsis remains the most common cause of death in intensive care units in the USA, with a current estimate of at least 750,000 cases per year, and 215,000 deaths annually. Despite extensive research still we do not quite understand the cellular and molecular mechanisms that are involved in triggering and propagation of septic injury. Endotoxin (lipopolysaccharide from Gram-negative bacteria, or LPS) has been implicated as a major cause of this syndrome. Inflammatory shock as a consequence of LPS release remains a serious clinical concern. In humans, inflammatory responses to LPS result in the release of cytokines and other cell mediators from monocytes and macrophages, which can cause fever, shock, organ failure and death. A number of different approaches have been investigated to try to treat and/or prevent the septic shock associated with infections caused by Gram-negative bacteria, including blockage of one or more of the cytokines induced by LPS. Recently several novel amphipathic compounds have been developed as direct LPS antagonists at the LPS receptor, TLR4. This review article will outline the current knowledge on the TLR4-LPS synthesis and discuss the signaling, in vitro pre-clinical and in vivo clinical evaluation of TLR4 antagonists and their potential use in sepsis and a variety of diseases such as atherosclerosis as well as hepatic and renal malfunction.

title: Growth of exocrine acinar cells on a reconstituted basement membrane gel
abstract: The article, 'Growth of exocrine acinar cells on a reconstituted basement membrane gel' investigates the potential of 3D systems to improve adhesion and growth in pancreatic-derived exocrine acinar cells. By replicating basal composition, structure and components of extracellular matrix that are found in vivo using recombinant proteins, a reconstructed basement membrane (rBM) is developed for this purpose. The objective of this study is to analyze the influence of rBM gel on 18 differentially expressed gene products related to cell adhesion and apoptosis over an eight-day period while quantifying changes in cell morphology also upon treatment with various growth factors. It is expected that activity within these pathways will be compared between 2D monolayer cultures vs cultured under 3D conditions when supplemented with various growth factors thus allowing us to comprehend functional effects caused by environment transition from 2D to 3D systems better.

title: The calculation of information and organismal complexity
abstract: BACKGROUND: It is difficult to measure precisely the phenotypic complexity of living organisms. Here we propose a method to calculate the minimal amount of genomic information needed to construct organism (effective information) as a measure of organismal complexity, by using permutation and combination formulas and Shannon's information concept. RESULTS: The results demonstrate that the calculated information correlates quite well with the intuitive organismal phenotypic complexity defined by traditional taxonomy and evolutionary theory. From viruses to human beings, the effective information gradually increases, from thousands of bits to hundreds of millions of bits. The simpler the organism is, the less the information; the more complex the organism, the more the information. About 13% of human genome is estimated as effective information or functional sequence. CONCLUSIONS: The effective information can be used as a quantitative measure of phenotypic complexity of living organisms and also as an estimate of functional fraction of genome. REVIEWERS: This article was reviewed by Dr. Lavanya Kannan (nominated by Dr. Arcady Mushegian), Dr. Chao Chen, and Dr. ED Rietman (nominated by Dr. Marc Vidal).

title: Supreme Emergencies Without the Bad Guys
abstract: This paper investigates the overlooked concept of supreme emergencies - disasters and catastrophic events that don't require any villains, perpetrators, or evident bad guys. Supreme emergencies add yet another emergency type to supplement existing definitions and afford a novel approach for better risk management through preventative responses. Using concepts from crisis communication research, this paper uncovers emergent trends in emergency management by discussing case studies of three different areas subjected to supreme emergency scenarios: a landslide in India; poor weather conditions leading to crop failure; and an invasion of aquatic plants disrupting water systems in Asia. Finally we develop conclusions about preparing for unpredictable nature-related events as well as create policy implications based on identified strategies suitable for such unique circumstances.

title: Assessment of Virally Vectored Autoimmunity as a Biocontrol Strategy for Cane Toads
abstract: BACKGROUND: The cane toad, Bufo (Chaunus) marinus, is one of the most notorious vertebrate pests introduced into Australia over the last 200 years and, so far, efforts to identify a naturally occurring B. marinus-specific pathogen for use as a biological control agent have been unsuccessful. We explored an alternative approach that entailed genetically modifying a pathogen with broad host specificity so that it no longer caused disease, but carried a gene to disrupt the cane toad life cycle in a species specific manner. METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS: The adult beta globin gene was selected as the model gene for proof of concept of autoimmunity as a biocontrol method for cane toads. A previous report showed injection of bullfrog tadpoles with adult beta globin resulted in an alteration in the form of beta globin expressed in metamorphs as well as reduced survival. In B. marinus we established for the first time that the switch from tadpole to adult globin exists. The effect of injecting B. marinus tadpoles with purified recombinant adult globin protein was then assessed using behavioural (swim speed in tadpoles and jump length in metamorphs), developmental (time to metamorphosis, weight and length at various developmental stages, protein profile of adult globin) and genetic (adult globin mRNA levels) measures. However, we were unable to detect any differences between treated and control animals. Further, globin delivery using Bohle iridovirus, an Australian ranavirus isolate belonging to the Iridovirus family, did not reduce the survival of metamorphs or alter the form of beta globin expressed in metamorphs. CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE: While we were able to show for the first time that the switch from tadpole to adult globin does occur in B. marinus, we were not able to induce autoimmunity and disrupt metamorphosis. The short development time of B. marinus tadpoles may preclude this approach.

title: Relapsing macrophage activating syndrome in a 15-year-old girl with Still's disease: a case report
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Macrophage activating syndrome is a severe, potentially life-threatening condition that may accompany Still's disease. It is characterized by fever, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, severe cytopenia, serious liver dysfunction, coagulopathy and neurologic involvement. The principal treatment for patients with this syndrome includes etoposide 150 mg/2 M twice a week for two weeks, dexamethasone 10 mg/2 M for two weeks and cyclosporine 3 mg/kg to 5 mg/kg for a longer period. Cases of relapse of macrophage activating syndrome are relatively rare. CASE PRESENTATION: We describe the case of a 15-year-old Iraqi girl with Still's disease who developed macrophage activating syndrome with acute respiratory distress syndrome that required resuscitation and mechanical ventilation. Following intensive treatment, including high dose steroids and cyclosporine, the patient improved significantly. Two weeks after cyclosporine was discontinued, however, she was readmitted with an acute relapse of macrophage activating syndrome manifested by spiking fever, arthralgias, maculopapular rash and leukocytosis. This time the patient recovered following the reintroduction of treatment with cyclosporine and the addition of mycophenolate mofetil (Cellcept). CONCLUSION: We believe that cyclosporine is a cornerstone for the treatment of Still's disease. We recommend continuing this medication for several weeks following the patient's clinical recovery in order to prevent macrophage activating syndrome relapses.

title: Immunologic Changes during Pandemic (H1N1) 2009, China
abstract: This paper sets to provide a review of the immunologic changes during pandemic (H1N1) 2009 in China. We analyzed data from patients' clinical records and regional surveillance data over two years, spanning 2008-2009. Our resultse suggest that significant while substantial increases were observed in some cytokine levels specific to influenza viruses occurred concomitant with this outbreak. This provides additional evidence for an increased susceptibility to infection leading to greater morbidity associated with H1N1 virus infections compared due to failure in removing antigenic stimulation and allowing multiple rounds of viral replication. The present study thus highlights critical level information regarding immunology characteristics during an influenza Outbreak which could be harnessed for improved treatment regimens and vaccines design development strategies in future outbreaks.

title: An object simulation model for modeling hypothetical disease epidemics – EpiFlex
abstract: BACKGROUND: EpiFlex is a flexible, easy to use computer model for a single computer, intended to be operated by one user who need not be an expert. Its purpose is to study in-silico the epidemic behavior of a wide variety of diseases, both known and theoretical, by simulating their spread at the level of individuals contracting and infecting others. To understand the system fully, this paper must be read together in conjunction with study of the software and its results. EpiFlex is evaluated using results from modeling influenza A epidemics and comparing them with a variety of field data sources and other types of modeling. EpiFlex is an object-oriented Monte Carlo system, allocating entities to correspond to individuals, disease vectors, diseases, and the locations that hosts may inhabit. EpiFlex defines eight different contact types available for a disease. Contacts occur inside locations within the model. Populations are composed of demographic groups, each of which has a cycle of movement between locations. Within locations, superspreading is defined by skewing of contact distributions. RESULTS: EpiFlex indicates three phenomena of interest for public health: (1) R(0 )is variable, and the smaller the population, the larger the infected fraction within that population will be; (2) significant compression/synchronization between cities by a factor of roughly 2 occurs between the early incubation phase of a multi-city epidemic and the major manifestation phase; (3) if better true morbidity data were available, more asymptomatic hosts would be seen to spread disease than we currently believe is the case for influenza. These results suggest that field research to study such phenomena, while expensive, should be worthwhile. CONCLUSION: Since EpiFlex shows all stages of disease progression, detailed insight into the progress of epidemics is possible. EpiFlex shows the characteristic multimodality and apparently random variation characteristic of real world data, but does so as an emergent property of a carefully constructed model of disease dynamics and is not simply a stochastic system. EpiFlex can provide a better understanding of infectious diseases and strategies for response.

title: Identification of a novel Getah virus by Virus-Discovery-cDNA random amplified polymorphic DNA (RAPD)
abstract: This paper presents the identification of a novel Getah virus by combining PCR and Virus-Discovery-cDNA random amplified polymorphic DNA (RAPD). Recent years have seen an alarming increase in the prevalence of vector-borne diseases caused by arboviruses. Of these, Getah and its associated vector, mites, is a major health hazard of global significance. To address this challenge, we utilized Virus-Discovery-cDNA RAPD to generate cDNAs from two pools of mite species collected from various locations worldwide. These were then subjected to PCR for virus detection and subsequent cloning into plasmid vectors for further analysis. Our results revealed that one pool had significantly higher viral titers than another pool. Sequencing analyses further confirmed the presence of seven different types of Getah viruses along with full length sequences on each sample type showing considerable variation in gene organization and size suggesting distinct evolutionary pathways as well as diversity among members within each group. Altogether our findings demonstrate utilization of modern molecular techniques such as cDNA RAPD can be harnessed to detect diverse strains/variants in vitro which may aid future design strategies for rapid diagnosis and relief treatment options against emerging pestiferous arbovirus threats like Getah that threaten global public health safety standards uniformly across all nations globally.

title: RNA-Seq Based Transcriptional Map of Bovine Respiratory Disease Pathogen “Histophilus somni 2336”
abstract: This article presents the first comprehensive description of the transcriptomic landscape of Histophilus somni 2336, a crucial pathogen in bovine respiratory diseases. The method to be employed is high-throughput RNA sequencing (RNA-Seq) which enables a large-scale study of gene expression associated with this disease, allowing for a better understanding of its molecular mechanisms. Results from this study are expected to provide valuable insight into the virulence factors and differentially expressed genes responsible for H. somni 2336 pathology, ultimately opening up new prospects  for improving our knowledge on development and treatment options relevant to bovine respiratory illnesses.

title: Human Anti-CCR4 Minibody Gene Transfer for the Treatment of Cutaneous T-Cell Lymphoma
abstract: Cutaneous T-Cell Lymphoma (CTCL) is a rare and highly aggressive hematological malignancy that affects the skin, causing itching, scaling, redness or bumps. Limited therapeutic options for this disease have led to the development of various strategies aimed at targeting specific molecules involved in its pathogenesis. The present study investigates the potential role of human anti-CCR4 minibody gene transfer as a treatment option in CTCL using an innovative murine model system. Human peripheral blood mononuclear cells were isolated and transfected with a lentiviral vector encoding an anti-human CCR4 minibody gene. Cells displaying high levels of surface expression of this construct were sorted by FACS and then injected into mouse models presenting with two different forms of aggressive CTCL: Mycosis Fungoides and Sézary Syndrome Lesions upon subcutaneous injection reduced considerably compared to untreated mice within 1 week of administration indicating such approach may be effective for treating patient's suffering from Cutaneous T Cell Lymphoma. Further research needs to be performed to assess whether such strategy can translate successfully from preclinical studies onto clinical practice given Minobodies are largely considered safe biopharmaceutical drugs with minimal systemic toxicity when compared conventionally used chemotherapeutics.

title: Human Cardioviruses, Meningitis, and Sudden Infant Death Syndrome in Children
abstract: This paper examines the role of human cardioviruses in relation to meningitis and sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS). With an increasing rate of SIDS, it is important to understand the impact that viruses may have on children. This study will explore the potential linkage between viral infections and immunological factors associated with these fatal illnesses in young children. By identifying connections between viral loads and physiological parameters in a clinical dataset, we can identify ways to reduce development or risk of complications from such conditions.

title: Knowledge of Avian Influenza (H5N1) among Poultry Workers, Hong Kong, China
abstract: Knowledge of risks associated with Avian Influenza (H5N1) among poultry workers in Hong Kong, China, is lacking due to the high demand for their work. This paper investigates Hong Kong poultry workers’ self-reported knowledge of H5N1 and its impact on preventive behaviour. We conducted a survey consisting of specially designed structured questionnaires to evaluate the poultry worker's level of knowledge while also acertaining attitudes towards safety guidelines and preventive practices. The results suggest that education campaigns geared towards improving understanding and awareness are needed targeting this group specifically in order to improve risk behavious related to H5N1 infection within this population.

title: Effectiveness of Integrated HIV Prevention Interventions among Chinese Men Who Have Sex with Men: Evaluation of a 16-City Public Health Program
abstract:
The HIV/AIDS pandemic has disproportionately impacted vulnerable populations including men who have sex with men (MSM). To address this, the Chinese government implemented an integrated 16-city public health program to increase access to and effectiveness of prevention interventions for MSM. This paper evaluates the impact of that program on reducing HIV prevalence among identified participant groups in representative cities. 

We begin by conducting a comprehensive review of existing datasets examining relevant factors and sociocultural differences. Building from those findings, we use a mixed methods quantitative analysis to evaluate whether planning-level changes successfully translated into actionable outcomes at both the individual level and citywide scale. Our results are then used to assess success levels and make recommendations for future integrated prevention strategies. The study provides valuable insights into public health policy efficacy in highly populated areas around China as well as identify potential obstacles which hinder effective implementation of such strategies within high risk communities like MSM populations living in urban settings across China.

title: Altered Thymic Function during Interferon Therapy in HCV-Infected Patients
abstract: This paper focuses on the alteration of thymic immunity during interferon therapy in HCV-infected patients. Persistent hepatitis C infection has been linked to an immunological imbalance due to deficient lymphoid organ function, including dysfunction within the thymus – a significant site of T-lymphocyte generation and development. This research studies the effects of interferon therapy on peripheral T-cell populations and thymic functions like naive-T conversion, new stem cell maturation, recent thymoramaer (RTE) production and antigen recognition activity in HCV patients. Investigated by analyzing perpheral blood mononuclear cells before and 30 days after peg IFN therapy was completed, our findings demonstrated a reduction in both circulating CD4+ count as well as RTE number following anti-HCV treatment in comparison with pretreatment levels. Furthermore, regular expression style quantitative PCR analysis suggested that these changes were accompanied by decreased mRNA transcription for several components involved in antigen recognition complexes — accumulation of which has been correlated with perturbed immune homeostatic function inside the thymus itself. The results provide evidence for altered peripheral manifestations associated with disruption of intraorgan immune dynamics when intestinal peptides are unable to be processed at therapeutic doses within this population subgroup – thus further emphasizing the importance for careful clinical observation and potential risk assessment for worsening clinical diseases across large patient cohorts being treated with such medications.

title: A large and accurate collection of peptidase cleavages in the MEROPS database
abstract: Peptidases are enzymes that hydrolyse peptide bonds in proteins and peptides. Peptidases are important in pathological conditions such as Alzheimer's disease, tumour and parasite invasion, and for processing viral polyproteins. The MEROPS database is an Internet resource containing information on peptidases, their substrates and inhibitors. The database now includes details of cleavage positions in substrates, both physiological and non-physiological, natural and synthetic. There are 39 118 cleavages in the collection; including 34 606 from a total of 10 513 different proteins and 2677 cleavages in synthetic substrates. The number of cleavages designated as ‘physiological’ is 13 307. The data are derived from 6095 publications. At least one substrate cleavage is known for 45% of the 2415 different peptidases recognized in the MEROPS database. The website now has three new displays: two showing peptidase specificity as a logo and a frequency matrix, the third showing a dynamically generated alignment between each protein substrate and its most closely related homologues. Many of the proteins described in the literature as peptidase substrates have been studied only in vitro. On the assumption that a physiologically relevant cleavage site would be conserved between species, the conservation of every site in terms of peptidase preference has been examined and a number have been identified that are not conserved. There are a number of cogent reasons why a site might not be conserved. Each poorly conserved site has been examined and a reason postulated. Some sites are identified that are very poorly conserved where cleavage is more likely to be fortuitous than of physiological relevance. This data-set is freely available via the Internet and is a useful training set for algorithms to predict substrates for peptidases and cleavage positions within those substrates. The data may also be useful for the design of inhibitors and for engineering novel specificities into peptidases. Database URL: http://merops.sanger.ac.uk

title: Interferon-Induced Ifit2/ISG54 Protects Mice from Lethal VSV Neuropathogenesis
abstract: This paper presents a breakthrough study on the role of interferon-induced ifit2/isg54 in protecting mice from the deadly neuroinfection caused by vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV). Using a mouse model, researchers identified that pre-treatment with recombinant Interferon α significantly reduced mortality while increases were observed in Ifit2 mRNA levels as well as its derived protein. In particular, studies demonstrated that ISG54 emerged to be an important antiviral factor and further exploration revealed this was related to VSV inhibition and efficient protection against lethal infection such as encephalomyelitis. This groundbreaking research highlights the crucial involvement of ifit2/ISG 54 for successful clearance of VSV infection demonstrating its therapeutic potential for possible applications against other emerging neurologically damaging viruses.

title: Fluorescence Competition Assay Measurements of Free Energy Changes for RNA Pseudoknots
