The findings from such investigations will reflect upon greater insight on childhood infection induced by H1N1virus paving a path for future preventive therapeutics against significant worldwide events involving novel emerging viruses.

title: Epigrass: a tool to study disease spread in complex networks
abstract: BACKGROUND: The construction of complex spatial simulation models such as those used in network epidemiology, is a daunting task due to the large amount of data involved in their parameterization. Such data, which frequently resides on large geo-referenced databases, has to be processed and assigned to the various components of the model. All this just to construct the model, then it still has to be simulated and analyzed under different epidemiological scenarios. This workflow can only be achieved efficiently by computational tools that can automate most, if not all, these time-consuming tasks. In this paper, we present a simulation software, Epigrass, aimed to help designing and simulating network-epidemic models with any kind of node behavior. RESULTS: A Network epidemiological model representing the spread of a directly transmitted disease through a bus-transportation network connecting mid-size cities in Brazil. Results show that the topological context of the starting point of the epidemic is of great importance from both control and preventive perspectives. CONCLUSION: Epigrass is shown to facilitate greatly the construction, simulation and analysis of complex network models. The output of model results in standard GIS file formats facilitate the post-processing and analysis of results by means of sophisticated GIS software.

title: Eco-cultural health, global health, and sustainability
abstract: This paper analyses the multi-layered concept of eco-cultural health, global health, and sustainability and explores how socio-economic factors impact this triad. It provides valuable insight about the complex relationship between human communities, their natural environment and overall well-being with a focus on poverty alleviation strategies. Drawing from existing research on environmental degradation in developing regions around the globe, it investigates viable strategies for improving living standards through an interdisciplinary approach to sustainable development that respects both local cultures and traditional ecological knowledge. Reflecting critically upon these issues will provide us with more effective approaches towards creating healthier societies while simultaneously maintaining biodiversity within our ever changing climate.

title: Prospective application of clinician-performed lung ultrasonography during the 2009 H1N1 influenza A pandemic: distinguishing viral from bacterial pneumonia
abstract: This paper addresses the prospective utility of clinician-performed lung ultrasonography (US) during the 2009 H1N1 pandemic to distinguish viral from bacterial pneumonia. The ability for clinicians to easily assess and differentiate between bacterial and viral pneumonias is essential in determining appropriate treatment. However, there has previously been a limited understanding of US’s role in management during influenza A epidemics. We therefore sought to systematically evaluate whether clinician-performed lung US may lead to accurate identification of etiology and improve patient care during this historic healthcare crisis. Herein we present a retrospective analysis conducted over five months that employed cohort study designs at two Chinese university hospitals for 176 adult patients with documented positive clinical diagnoses confirmed via RT-PCR tests, combined with historical control group data collected three weeks before the pandemic emergence of novel virus strain AH3N2H1N1/09 on April 27th 2009. The primary outcome measure was accurate diagnosis rates compared across groups using biomedical techniques including chest X-ray film imaging with linear measurements and B lines diagnostic sign determination coupled with point-of-care bedside clinicians performing transthoracic lung US examinations which were subjectively scored according figures 0 through 7 according International Classification of Diseases 10 supplementations criteria. We concluded that visceroelastance distortion discrimination by sonographical testing might be a reliable way in differentiating between viral or bacterial pneumonias especially when controlling factors such as ambient air pollution levels can interfere image assessment accuracy both through traditional photography comparison technique or computer aided machine learning quantitative title: Influenza A Virus Inhibits Type I IFN Signaling via NF-κB-Dependent Induction of SOCS-3 Expression
abstract: The type I interferon (IFN) system is a first line of defense against viral infections. Viruses have developed various mechanisms to counteract this response. So far, the interferon antagonistic activity of influenza A viruses was mainly observed on the level of IFNβ gene induction via action of the viral non-structural protein 1 (NS1). Here we present data indicating that influenza A viruses not only suppress IFNβ gene induction but also inhibit type I IFN signaling through a mechanism involving induction of the suppressor of cytokine signaling-3 (SOCS-3) protein. Our study was based on the observation that in cells that were infected with influenza A virus and subsequently stimulated with IFNα/β, phosphorylation of the signal transducer and activator of transcription protein 1 (STAT1) was strongly reduced. This impaired STAT1 activation was not due to the action of viral proteins but rather appeared to be induced by accumulation of viral 5′ triphosphate RNA in the cell. SOCS proteins are potent endogenous inhibitors of Janus kinase (JAK)/STAT signaling. Closer examination revealed that SOCS-3 but not SOCS-1 mRNA levels increase in an RNA- and nuclear factor kappa B (NF-κB)-dependent but type I IFN-independent manner early in the viral replication cycle. This direct viral induction of SOCS-3 mRNA and protein expression appears to be relevant for suppression of the antiviral response since in SOCS-3 deficient cells a sustained phosphorylation of STAT1 correlated with elevated expression of type I IFN-dependent genes. As a consequence, progeny virus titers were reduced in SOCS-3 deficient cells or in cells were SOCS-3 expression was knocked-down by siRNA. These data provide the first evidence that influenza A viruses suppress type I IFN signaling on the level of JAK/STAT activation. The inhibitory effect is at least in part due to the induction of SOCS-3 gene expression, which results in an impaired antiviral response.

title: Bioethical Implications of Globalization: An International Consortium Project of the European Commission
abstract: The BIG project looks at some of the ethical concerns surrounding globalization and health.

title: Screening for Influenza A(H1N1)pdm09, Auckland International Airport, New Zealand
abstract: This study looks at the prevalence of influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 in travellers using Auckland International Airport, New Zealand. Screening methods were used to determine the rate of infection for symptomatic and asymptomatic passengers entering and exiting the airport during a four-month period. Results indicate that there is an increased risk for infection through international transit amongst individuals aged 18-25 years old travelling from certain countries due to their higher likelihood of exposure to Influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 abroad. These findings further support evidence suggesting that airports should consider implementing health screenings on all incoming international flights to reduce transmission in a nation’s population.

title: Hairpin structure within the 3′UTR of DNA polymerase β mRNA acts as a post-transcriptional regulatory element and interacts with Hax-1
abstract: Aberrant expression of DNA polymerase β, a key enzyme involved in base excision repair, leads to genetic instability and carcinogenesis. Pol β expression has been previously shown to be regulated at the level of transcription, but there is also evidence of post-transcriptional regulation, since rat transcripts undergo alternative polyadenylation, and the resulting 3′UTR contain at least one regulatory element. Data presented here indicate that RNA of the short 3′UTR folds to form a strong secondary structure (hairpin). Its regulatory role was established utilizing a luciferase-based reporter system. Further studies led to the identification of a protein factor, which binds to this element—the anti-apoptotic, cytoskeleton-related protein Hax-1. The results of in vitro binding analysis indicate that the formation of the RNA–protein complex is significantly impaired by disruption of the hairpin motif. We demonstrate that Hax-1 binds to Pol β mRNA exclusively in the form of a dimer. Biochemical analysis revealed the presence of Hax-1 in mitochondria, but also in the nuclear matrix, which, along with its transcript-binding properties, suggests that Hax-1 plays a role in post-transcriptional regulation of expression of Pol β.

title: 3D QSAR Pharmacophore Modeling, in Silico Screening, and Density Functional Theory (DFT) Approaches for Identification of Human Chymase Inhibitors
abstract: This article presents a comprehensive overview of the application of 3D QSAR pharmacophore modeling, in silico screening, and Density Functional Theory (DFT) approaches to identify potential human chymase inhibitors.  Chymases are serine proteases and differ from other types of enzymes due to their uniquely active site architecture and catalytic triad - making them a relatively unexplored drug target for clinical use. A combination of computational chemistry protocols have been employed together with available experimental data to take advantage of their unique features through various bioinformatics pathways. This novel approach could lead the way forward towards clinically relevant molecules that provide treatment for several cardiovascular diseases such as hypertension or heart failure associated with increased levels of chymase activity.

title: Model-Based Design of Growth-Attenuated Viruses
abstract: Live-virus vaccines activate both humoral and cell-mediated immunity, require only a single boosting, and generally provide longer immune protection than killed or subunit vaccines. However, growth of live-virus vaccines must be attenuated to minimize their potential pathogenic effects, and mechanisms of attenuation by conventional serial-transfer viral adaptation are not well-understood. New methods of attenuation based on rational engineering of viral genomes may offer a potentially greater control if one can link defined genetic modifications to changes in virus growth. To begin to establish such links between genotype and growth phenotype, we developed a computer model for the intracellular growth of vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV), a well-studied, nonsegmented, negative-stranded RNA virus. Our model incorporated established regulatory mechanisms of VSV while integrating key wild-type infection steps: hijacking of host resources, transcription, translation, and replication, followed by assembly and release of progeny VSV particles. Generalization of the wild-type model to allow for genome rearrangements matched the experimentally observed attenuation ranking for recombinant VSV strains that altered the genome position of their nucleocapsid gene. Finally, our simulations captured previously reported experimental results showing how altering the positions of other VSV genes has the potential to attenuate the VSV growth while overexpressing the immunogenic VSV surface glycoprotein. Such models will facilitate the engineering of new live-virus vaccines by linking genomic manipulations to controlled changes in virus gene-expression and growth.

title: Proteomics Comparison of Cerebrospinal Fluid of Relapsing Remitting and Primary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis
abstract: BACKGROUND: Based on clinical representation of disease symptoms multiple sclerosis (MScl) patients can be divided into two major subtypes; relapsing remitting (RR) MScl (85–90%) and primary progressive (PP) MScl (10–15%). Proteomics analysis of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) has detected a number of proteins that were elevated in MScl patients. Here we specifically aimed to differentiate between the PP and RR subtypes of MScl by comparing CSF proteins. METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS: CSF samples (n = 31) were handled according to the same protocol for quantitative mass spectrometry measurements we reported previously. In the comparison of PP MScl versus RR MScl we observed a number of differentially abundant proteins, such as protein jagged-1 and vitamin D-binding protein. Protein jagged-1 was over three times less abundant in PP MScl compared to RR MScl. Vitamin D-binding protein was only detected in the RR MScl samples. These two proteins were validated by independent techniques (western blot and ELISA) as differentially abundant in the comparison between both MScl types. CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE: The main finding of this comparative study is the observation that the proteome profiles of CSF in PP and RR MScl patients overlap to a large extent. Still, a number of differences could be observed. Protein jagged-1 is a ligand for multiple Notch receptors and involved in the mediation of Notch signaling. It is suggested in literature that the Notch pathway is involved in the remyelination of MScl lesions. Aberration of normal homeostasis of Vitamin D, of which approximately 90% is bound to vitamin D-binding protein, has been widely implicated in MScl for some years now. Vitamin D directly and indirectly regulates the differentiation, activation of CD4+ T-lymphocytes and can prevent the development of autoimmune processes, and so it may be involved in neuroprotective elements in MScl.

title: Asymmetry in the Presence of Migration Stabilizes Multistrain Disease Outbreaks
abstract: We study the effect of migration between coupled populations, or patches, on the stability properties of multistrain disease dynamics. The epidemic model used in this work displays a Hopf bifurcation to oscillations in a single, well-mixed population. It is shown numerically that migration between two non-identical patches stabilizes the endemic steady state, delaying the onset of large amplitude outbreaks and reducing the total number of infections. This result is motivated by analyzing generic Hopf bifurcations with different frequencies and with diffusive coupling between them. Stabilization of the steady state is again seen, indicating that our observation in the full multistrain model is based on qualitative characteristics of the dynamics rather than on details of the disease model.

title: Novel Method for Isolation of Murine Clara Cell Secretory Protein-Expressing Cells with Traces of Stemness
abstract: This paper focuses on a novel method for the isolation of murine clara cell secretory protein-expressing cells with traces of stemness. In the realm of lung biology, the knowledge about airway lining epithelial properties and its heterogeneity greatly influences our understanding of diseases such as asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). As such, accurate description of various specialized pulmonary epithelia is essential which can be better achieved through appropriate cellular models that show distinct histological features. This study presents an optimized protocol to isolate functional Clara Cell Secretory Protein (CCSP)-expressing alveolar type II cell progenitors from mouse lungs in combination with their integration flows within many other context applications, including long-term culture protocols for specific omics studies. The best results have been obtained using immunofluorescence approach combined with flow cytometry analysis employing CD45-FLK1 DCX double positive markers along with CCSP staining technique generating high viable single cells featuring traceable stemness potential enabling the use in wide scale genomics projects.

title: Cloning and Sequence Analysis of the Nucleocapsid Gene of Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea Virus Chinju99
abstract: The devastating nature of Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea Virus (PEDV) and its ongoing impact on pig farms worldwide has driven the requirement for more precise medical approaches in controlling this virus. To address this issue, a team from China aimed to clone and sequence the nucleocapsid gene of PEDV strain Chinju99. Using a combination of reverse transcription quantitative PCR (RT-qPCR) and rapid amplification strategies, the study successfully cloned, sequenced and analysed the full length cDNA segment coding for M protein from PEDV Chinju99 strain. Through further analysis it was determined that there were several mutations within this region which provided new insight into routes of transmission used by this particular strain as well as providing clues towards improved therapeutical applications designed to target specific mutations present in PEDV strains. In conclusion, these findings support critical research into better ways to control vial outbreaks of Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea Virus through molecular level understanding at genetic level. This article presents an in-depth cloning and sequencing analysis of the Nucleocapsid Gene OF Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea Virus Chinju99 revealing novel insights regarding strain structure variants.'

title: The role of mast cells in the pathogenesis of pain in chronic pancreatitis
abstract: BACKGROUND: The biological basis of pain in chronic pancreatitis is poorly understood. Mast cells have been implicated in the pathogenesis of pain in other conditions. We hypothesized that mast cells play a role in the pain of chronic pancreatitis. We examined the association of pain with mast cells in autopsy specimens of patients with painful chronic pancreatitis. We explored our hypothesis further using an experimental model of trinitrobenzene sulfonic acid (TNBS) -induced chronic pancreatitis in both wild type (WT) and mast cell deficient mice (MCDM). METHODS: Archival tissues with histological diagnoses of chronic pancreatitis were identified and clinical records reviewed for presence or absence of reported pain in humans. Mast cells were counted. The presence of pain was assessed using von Frey Filaments (VFF) to measure abdominal withdrawal responses in both WT and MCDM mice with and without chronic pancreatitis. RESULTS: Humans with painful chronic pancreatitis demonstrated a 3.5-fold increase in pancreatic mast cells as compared with those with painless chronic pancreatitis. WT mice with chronic pancreatitis were significantly more sensitive as assessed by VFF pain testing of the abdomen when compared with MCDM. CONCLUSION: Humans with painful chronic pancreatitis have an increased number of pancreatic mast cells as compared with those with painless chronic pancreatitis. MCDM are less sensitive to mechanical stimulation of the abdomen after induction of chronic pancreatitis as compared with WT. Mast cells may play an important role in the pathogenesis of pain in chronic pancreatitis.

title: Spatial dynamics of the 1918 influenza pandemic in England, Wales and the United States
abstract: There is still limited understanding of key determinants of spatial spread of influenza. The 1918 pandemic provides an opportunity to elucidate spatial determinants of spread on a large scale. To better characterize the spread of the 1918 major wave, we fitted a range of city-to-city transmission models to mortality data collected for 246 population centres in England and Wales and 47 cities in the US. Using a gravity model for city-to-city contacts, we explored the effect of population size and distance on the spread of disease and tested assumptions regarding density dependence in connectivity between cities. We employed Bayesian Markov Chain Monte Carlo methods to estimate parameters of the model for population, infectivity, distance and density dependence. We inferred the most likely transmission trees for both countries. For England and Wales, a model that estimated the degree of density dependence in connectivity between cities was preferable by deviance information criterion comparison. Early in the major wave, long distance infective interactions predominated, with local infection events more likely as the epidemic became widespread. For the US, with fewer more widely dispersed cities, statistical power was lacking to estimate population size dependence or the degree of density dependence, with the preferred model depending on distance only. We find that parameters estimated from the England and Wales dataset can be applied to the US data with no likelihood penalty.

title: Clinical review: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis acute exacerbations - unravelling Ariadne's thread
abstract: This clinical review presents an analysis of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) acute exacerbations - major events that can cause a rapid decline in lung function and make prognoses difficult to predict. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a progressive and fatal disease characterised by the deposition of extracellular matrix in the alveoli, undergone by approximately 5 million people worldwide. Its management demands careful treatment decisions as well as advanced diagnostic tools for early detection. Understanding IPF acute exacerbations has been a challenging task due to their heterogeneous nature and lack of validated biomarkers of inflammation or infection associated with them. To complicate matters further, continuous developments in its diagnosis require the frequent evaluation of therapeutic strategies for IPF patients suffering from those episodes including established approaches or novel formulations such as antifibrotics are receiving promising effectiveness results on regression but still need further deep research. This paper will explore Ariadne's thread within this labyrinthine thicket through reviewing both literature reports and personal experience, appraisal valid therapeutical alternatives against insidiousness behaviour exhibited during these acutisations\ while also providing an insightful approach towards global efforts to declass yet another medical mystery surrounding modern medicine.

title: Immunogenetic Factors Associated with Severe Respiratory Illness Caused by Zoonotic H1N1 and H5N1 Influenza Viruses
abstract: This study examines the immunogenetic factors associated with severe respiratory illness caused by zoonotic H1N1 and H5N1 influenza viruses. In a world where these dangerous viruses are rapidly evolving, understanding innate immune responses and corresponding genetic variations will be key to providing effective treatments for those most vulnerable to global pandemics of this magnitude. We have systematically used genomic screening techniques and epidemiological studies to identify clinical associations between specific genetic variants of cytokine receptors, lymphocyte subsets, major histocompatibility complex (MHC) gene repertoires, Fc receptor polymorphisms, antibody production variables and other antigen-presenting molecules in individuals who were infected with either virus strain. Our research aims to shed light on how their interaction can affect host resistance or susceptibility towards such pathogenic strains of influenza A viruses during an outbreak.

title: The Dispanins: A Novel Gene Family of Ancient Origin That Contains 14 Human Members
abstract: This study investigates a novel gene family of ancient origin, known as the Dispanins. With fourteen human members (Dspns), the Dispanins are one of the oldest multi-gene families to be identified in mammals, and their distinct roles are predicted to offer important insights into mammalian evolution. A comprehensive analysis was undertaken using bioinformatics tools to identify all Human Dspn subtypes along with functional aspects including conservation and expression levels across multiple species. An exploration of evolutionary relationships highlights variations among phylogenetic classifications interpreting their roles in a variety of mammalian pathways and processes. This illuminating review provides initial evidence on salient features associated with this unique gene family most relevant for further research into those underlying mechanisms related to mammalian diversification and adaptation throughout our evolutionary history.

title: Evaluation of atherosclerotic lesions using dextran- and mannan–dextran-coated USPIO: MRI analysis and pathological findings
abstract: This paper presents an in-depth evaluation of atherosclerotic lesions and their associated characteristics, such as arterial wall thickness, necrotic core size, and inflammatory cells count through Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) analysis combined with pathological findings after administering Ultrasmall Superparamagnetic Iron Oxide nanoparticles (USPIO), coated with either dextran or mannan–dextran. The use of USPIO as contrast material for MRI has become increasingly important due to its unique properties; this procedure allows the identification of alterations in tissue structure that could not have been easily obtained before. Additionally, intra-observer variability was analysed to evaluate the accuracy of this specific technique. Our results suggest a satisfactory agreement between the various techniques used; however they also show some discrepancies which can be discussed further. Therefore, we imply that further studies are needed to improve the accuracy of USPIO administered by improving labeling agents molecules affinity towards the lesion tissues and sensitivity inside the MRI scanner, allowing us to discover more information about these structures

title: Oral application of cytokines
abstract: This study seeks to explore the potential for oral application of cytokines and their therapeutic effects. Cytokines are a family of proteins essential for regulating immune response, maintaining tissue homoeostasis, and coordinating cell growth and development. Despite impressive progress in research, few studies have focused on using oral delivery as a means to trigger these processes. The objective of this investigation is to survey the structure and functionality of various types of cytokines suitable for administration via an oral route, compare the efficacy between different methods used in delivering them by mouth, investigate whether therapeutic outcomes occur when targeting conditions enabled by each type of cytokine presented with associated risks or limitations that could affect clearance following treatment. The primary endpoints are safety profiles ensured by established criteria based on pharmacokinetic parameters, as well as targeted organ protection and changes in biochemical markers post-intervention. Ultimately it is hoped that results from this project will provide insights into new approaches involving orally administered molecules which may effectively reduce inflammation or increase systemic immunity without significant side effects or drug toxicity levels reported in standard treatments such as infusion therapy or immunoregulatory agents

title: Predicting Drug-Target Interaction Networks Based on Functional Groups and Biological Features
abstract: BACKGROUND: Study of drug-target interaction networks is an important topic for drug development. It is both time-consuming and costly to determine compound-protein interactions or potential drug-target interactions by experiments alone. As a complement, the in silico prediction methods can provide us with very useful information in a timely manner. METHODS/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS: To realize this, drug compounds are encoded with functional groups and proteins encoded by biological features including biochemical and physicochemical properties. The optimal feature selection procedures are adopted by means of the mRMR (Maximum Relevance Minimum Redundancy) method. Instead of classifying the proteins as a whole family, target proteins are divided into four groups: enzymes, ion channels, G-protein- coupled receptors and nuclear receptors. Thus, four independent predictors are established using the Nearest Neighbor algorithm as their operation engine, with each to predict the interactions between drugs and one of the four protein groups. As a result, the overall success rates by the jackknife cross-validation tests achieved with the four predictors are 85.48%, 80.78%, 78.49%, and 85.66%, respectively. CONCLUSION/SIGNIFICANCE: Our results indicate that the network prediction system thus established is quite promising and encouraging.

title: From Functional Genomics to Functional Immunomics: New Challenges, Old Problems, Big Rewards
abstract: The development of DNA microarray technology a decade ago led to the establishment of functional genomics as one of the most active and successful scientific disciplines today. With the ongoing development of immunomic microarray technology—a spatially addressable, large-scale technology for measurement of specific immunological response—the new challenge of functional immunomics is emerging, which bears similarities to but is also significantly different from functional genomics. Immunonic data has been successfully used to identify biological markers involved in autoimmune diseases, allergies, viral infections such as human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), influenza, diabetes, and responses to cancer vaccines. This review intends to provide a coherent vision of this nascent scientific field, and speculate on future research directions. We discuss at some length issues such as epitope prediction, immunomic microarray technology and its applications, and computation and statistical challenges related to functional immunomics. Based on the recent discovery of regulation mechanisms in T cell responses, we envision the use of immunomic microarrays as a tool for advances in systems biology of cellular immune responses, by means of immunomic regulatory network models.

title: Human Bocavirus – Insights into a Newly Identified Respiratory Virus
abstract: This study provides comprehensive insight into Human Bocavirus (HBoV), a recently discovered respiratory virus. HBoV is an important emerging pathogen in infants and young children, causing severe bronchiolitis-like symptoms such as coughing, wheezing and fever. There is increasing evidence of the involvement of HBoV in other acute respiratory syndromes worldwide besides bronchiolitis, but further research on its prevalence, clinical presentation and genetic diversity has been limited. This paper aims to review recent progress regarding the epidemiology, transmission route, clinical impact, risk factors for infection and laboratory diagnostic methods for this novel virus. Results obtained from this work can help promote early diagnosis with proper monitoring measures to prevent potential complications associated with HBoV infection making it an important current topic in public health inquiry.

title: Ebola Virion Attachment and Entry into Human Macrophages Profoundly Effects Early Cellular Gene Expression
abstract: 'Ebola virion attachment and entry into human macrophages profoundly effects early cellular gene expression': The Ebolavirus is a highly contagious virus that causes serious illness in humans and other primates. It belongs to the family Filoviridae, which consists of three genera – Marburgvirus, Cuevavirus and Ebolavirus itself. During infection, the virus uses its glycoproteins to enable binding onto host cells so they can be endocytosed by the cell membrane and actively penetrate them – a process known as "virion attachment and entry." This study focused on evaluating how this vital step of infection impacted immediate cellular activities within the cell. Using an integrated analysis across multiple omics data sets including transcriptomics, epigenetics, proteomics and metabolomics profiling assays we sought to gain a systematic understanding of how EBV hijacks key functions such as transcriptional regulation upon entering human macrophaging. Further analyses detected a wide spectrum alterations induced by EBV-associated gene products at early stages in simulated infections of primary monocyte-derived macrophages at high multiplicities associated with pathogenesis. Our experimental models suggest that after fusion of endosomes containing viral components with cytoplasmic organelles additional responses are initiated resulting in upregulation or downregulation for many genes involved in infiltrative pathways for immune system evasion strategies used by ebola viruses against their hosts during acute phase infections . In conclusion our results emphasize ephemeral changes occurring immediately after endothelial/macrophage invasion leading to devastating outcomes not just limited to Ebola Virus but also potentially relevant to certain other filoviral diseases like Lassa Fever Virus (LFV) as well.

title: Methods for counting particles in microfluidic applications
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive review of particle counting techniques for microfluidic applications. With the introduction of novel technologies in this field, the need for precise and reliable methods to count particles is growing rapidly. This paper evaluates common particle-counting techniques including manual counting, optical microscopy and image processing, along with more recent methods such as electrical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and dielectrophoresis (DEP). Additionally, new methods developed specifically for microfluidic applications are discussed. These include fluorescence correlation spectroscopy (FCS), dynamic light scattering (DLS), Raman imaging spectroscopy (RIS) and scanning acoustic microscopy (SAM). Their advantages, drawbacks and potential uses are detailed. Finally, future directions in research will be addressed so as to maximize accuracy and diminish errors when using any given particle - counting method in a microfluidic system.

title: Predictive and Reactive Distribution of Vaccines and Antivirals during Cross-Regional Pandemic Outbreaks
abstract: This paper presents an evaluation of the efficacy of predictive and reactive distribution models in the context of cross-regional pandemic outbreaks. Drawing upon data from a series of outbreak simulations, the authors examine how well geographic considerations are taken into account when applying both preventive strategies, while further exploring which factors have to be considered for obtaining optimal results. Analysis is conducted as to whether vaccination or antiviral therapy provide superior effectiveness in controlling a pandemic spread. Such findings may lead to improved management strategies being available in future pandemics by enabling public health policy makers with more effective distribution tools at their disposal.

title: Differential Regulation of Type I Interferon and Epidermal Growth Factor Pathways by a Human Respirovirus Virulence Factor
abstract: A number of paramyxoviruses are responsible for acute respiratory infections in children, elderly and immuno-compromised individuals, resulting in airway inflammation and exacerbation of chronic diseases like asthma. To understand the molecular pathogenesis of these infections, we searched for cellular targets of the virulence protein C of human parainfluenza virus type 3 (hPIV3-C). We found that hPIV3-C interacts directly through its C-terminal domain with STAT1 and GRB2, whereas C proteins from measles or Nipah viruses failed to do so. Binding to STAT1 explains the previously reported capacity of hPIV3-C to block type I interferon signaling, but the interaction with GRB2 was unexpected. This adaptor protein bridges Epidermal Growth Factor (EGF) receptor to MAPK/ERK pathway, a signaling cascade recently found to be involved in airway inflammatory response. We report that either hPIV3 infection or transient expression of hPIV3-C both increase cellular response to EGF, as assessed by Elk1 transactivation and phosphorylation levels of ERK1/2, 40S ribosomal subunit protein S6 and translation initiation factor 4E (eIF4E). Furthermore, inhibition of MAPK/ERK pathway with U0126 prevented viral protein expression in infected cells. Altogether, our data provide molecular basis to explain the role of hPIV3-C as a virulence factor and determinant of pathogenesis and demonstrate that Paramyxoviridae have evolved a single virulence factor to block type I interferon signaling and to boost simultaneous cellular response to growth factors.

title: Niclosamide Is a Proton Carrier and Targets Acidic Endosomes with Broad Antiviral Effects
abstract: This study examines the utility of niclosamide as a proton carrier in targeting acidic endosomes, and its broad antiviral effects. Niclosamide is an antiparasitic drug that has been employed for decades to eliminate intestinal worms. Recent evidence suggests it may also prove effective against various viruses including Influenza A, HIV-1 and Zika virus. The mechanism by which it affects viral replication remains largely unknown; however, current theories focus on niclosamide's potential role as a proton shuttle for delivering molecules across cellular membranes into endosomal compartments with controlled pH levels. Moreover, studies have demonstrated that delivery of drugs normally targeted to acidified lysosome-like structures can be improved when accompanied by this amphiphilic compound because of its ability to localize at low pHs within these organelles due to the "proton sponge" effect. This investigation therefore explores how niclosamide acts upon various types of viruses while considering its efficacy in directing drug activity through modulating membrane charge/polarity states as well as exploiting natural osmotic gradients between intracellular vesicles and their surroundings. Ultimately we aim to explain why niclosamide may represent a promising tool with broad antiviral applications against some of the most concerning human pathogens worldwide today

title: Prognosis of hospitalized patients with 2009 H1N1 influenza in Spain: influence of neuraminidase inhibitors
abstract: The timely availability of effective treatments for infectious diseases has a significant influence on the outcomes of patients. This study aims to evaluate the prognosis of hospitalized patients with 2009 H1N1 influenza in Spain and to analyze the effect of neuraminidase inhibitors, one of the main antiviral therapies used against influenza virus infection. Retrospective analysis was conducted over six years on 3,776 individuals diagnosed with or confirmed as having tested positive for 2009 H1N1 flu admitted into 27 Spanish hospitals across all Autonomous Communities from January 2013 until December 2018. Results demonstrate that neuraminidase inhibitors significantly affect survival and length-of-stay intervals among affected individuals who required intensive care units (ICUs), but their impact is less significant outside the ICU environment. Findings highlight how critical it is to utilize these medications when treating patients infected with 2009 H1N1 influenza within hospital settings in order to maximize patient recovery and reduce mortality rates associated with infections caused by this virus.

title: Feline Immunodeficiency Virus in South America
abstract: The prevalence and outbreak of Feline Immunodeficiency Virus (FIV) has caused a significant loss in cat populations across the world. In order to understand the particular impact of this virus on cats within South America, a survey was conducted among veterinarians working in three countries: Brazil, Chile and Argentina. The purpose of this experiment was to generate an accurate understanding of how many cats are currently infected with FIV as well as which demographic groups both contract and succumb more frequently to the effects of the virus. Our results provide evidence for increased risk factors associated with outdoor activity rate and neutering status amongst the surveyed cat population. This analysis can be used by animal centers resources across South America to inform policies related to care-taking measures that will help mitigate against further spread of this debilitating disease by targeting specific regions or demographics that may be impacted disproportionately due to their living situation or lifestyle habits.

title: Presentation of hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis due to a novel MUNC 13–4 mutation masked by partial therapeutic immunosuppression
abstract: This study examines the presentation of an unusually severe hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) case in a nine-year old pediatric patient, caused by a novel mutation in MUNC 13–4, which was inadvertently masked due to partial therapeutic immunosuppression. Through comprehensive genetic and phenotypic analyses, we will present data on this rare clinical condition and discuss potential treatments for HLH associated with this particular mutation.

title: A Chinese Herbal Formula to Improve General Psychological Status in Posttraumatic Stress Disorder: A Randomized Placebo-Controlled Trial on Sichuan Earthquake Survivors
abstract: The aim of this study was to investigate the effectiveness and safety of a traditional Chinese herbal formula (Bai Tou Pian) in improving general psychological status in posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The trial included 135 survivors from the 2008 Sichuan earthquake who were randomly assigned to either an intervention group or a placebo group. After 15 weeks, the self-reported questionnaires revealed improvements on psychological symptoms such as depression, anxiety and sleep disturbances compared to baseline scores for participants receiving the active treatment. Daily symptom monitoring showed no significant difference between groups during follow-up observations indicating that Bai Tou Pian is safe and well tolerated. These results suggest that Bai Tou Pian may provide promising clinical benefit for PTSD evidence by reducing psychological symptoms as well as promoting improved quality of life for trauma sufferers with satisfactory tolerance profiles.

title: Involvement of microRNAs in physiological and pathological processes in the lung
abstract: To date, at least 900 different microRNA (miRNA) genes have been discovered in the human genome. These short, single-stranded RNA molecules originate from larger precursor molecules that fold to produce hairpin structures, which are subsequently processed by ribonucleases Drosha/Pasha and Dicer to form mature miRNAs. MiRNAs play role in the posttranscriptional regulation of about one third of human genes, mainly via degradation of target mRNAs. Whereas the target mRNAs are often involved in the regulation of diverse physiological processes ranging from developmental timing to apoptosis, miRNAs have a strong potential to regulate fundamental biological processes also in the lung compartment. However, the knowledge of the role of miRNAs in physiological and pathological conditions in the lung is still limited. This review, therefore, summarizes current knowledge of the mechanism, function of miRNAs and their contribution to lung development and homeostasis. Besides the involvement of miRNAs in pulmonary physiological conditions, there is evidence that abnormal miRNA expression may lead to pathological processes and development of various pulmonary diseases. Next, the review describes current state-of-art on the miRNA expression profiles in smoking-related diseases including lung cancerogenesis, in immune system mediated pulmonary diseases and fibrotic processes in the lung. From the current research it is evident that miRNAs may play role in the posttranscriptional regulation of key genes in human pulmonary diseases. Further studies are, therefore, necessary to explore miRNA expression profiles and their association with target mRNAs in human pulmonary diseases.

title: Bioinformatic mapping of AlkB homology domains in viruses
abstract: BACKGROUND: AlkB-like proteins are members of the 2-oxoglutarate- and Fe(II)-dependent oxygenase superfamily. In Escherichia coli the protein protects RNA and DNA against damage from methylating agents. 1-methyladenine and 3-methylcytosine are repaired by oxidative demethylation and direct reversal of the methylated base back to its unmethylated form. Genes for AlkB homologues are widespread in nature, and Eukaryotes often have several genes coding for AlkB-like proteins. Similar domains have also been observed in certain plant viruses. The function of the viral domain is unknown, but it has been suggested that it may be involved in protecting the virus against the post-transcriptional gene silencing (PTGS) system found in plants. We wanted to do a phylogenomic mapping of viral AlkB-like domains as a basis for analysing functional aspects of these domains, because this could have some relevance for understanding possible alternative roles of AlkB homologues e.g. in Eukaryotes. RESULTS: Profile-based searches of protein sequence libraries showed that AlkB-like domains are found in at least 22 different single-stranded RNA positive-strand plant viruses, but mainly in a subgroup of the Flexiviridae family. Sequence analysis indicated that the AlkB domains probably are functionally conserved, and that they most likely have been integrated relatively recently into several viral genomes at geographically distinct locations. This pattern seems to be more consistent with increased environmental pressure, e.g. from methylating pesticides, than with interaction with the PTGS system. CONCLUSIONS: The AlkB domain found in viral genomes is most likely a conventional DNA/RNA repair domain that protects the viral RNA genome against methylating compounds from the environment.

title: Allo-SCT for multiple myeloma: a review of outcomes at a single transplant center
abstract: This study examines the efficacy of Allo-SCT in multiple myeloma (MM) treatment at a single transplant center. From 2010–2019, outcomes of transplants for MM patients were tracked through evaluation and monitoring of short-term graft rejection, acute toxicities, long-term graft acceptance with minimal immunosuppression maintenance therapy, and overall survival rate. Furthermore, this study compares the results to other published studies involving MM patient treatments that underwent allogeneic stem cell transplantation (Allo-SCT). Understanding how different types of regimes influence post-transplant outcomes is crucially important to providing optimal care for patients undergoing these procedures. The main objective was to evaluate Allo-SCT as an effective treatment for MM by measuring such outcomes over time at a single transplant center. This paper will discuss the current literature on responding therapies involved in regenerative medicine including Allo-SCT for treating multiple myeloma within a specific population studied at one transplant clinic from the last 9 years.

title: Nursing heroism in the 21(st )Century'
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Vivian Bullwinkel Oration honours the life and work of an extraordinary nurse. Given her story and that of her World War II colleagues, the topic of nursing heroism in the 21(st )century could not be more germane. DISCUSSION: Is heroism a legitimate part of nursing, or are nurses simply 'just doing their job' even when facing extreme personal danger? In this paper I explore the place and relevance of heroism in contemporary nursing. I propose that nursing heroism deserves a broader appreciation and that within the term lie many hidden, 'unsung' or 'unrecorded' heroisms. I also challenge the critiques of heroism that would condemn it as part of a 'militarisation' of nursing. Finally, I argue that nursing needs to be more open in celebrating our heroes and the transformative power of nursing achievements. SUMMARY: The language of heroism may sound quaint by 21(st )Century standards but nursing heroism is alive and well in the best of our contemporary nursing ethos and practice.

title: ELM—the database of eukaryotic linear motifs
abstract: This research article presents ELM—the database of eukaryotic linear motifs. ELM is a compilation of functionally relevant short protein sequences, which are the fundamental units of cellular signaling networks. This database provides detailed information about the molecular organization and interactions within known eukaryotic linear motifs, helping computational biologists to decipher complex downstream pathways encoded in regulatory proteins. The researchers demonstrate its utility by clustering experimentally validated complexes that recognize different binding sites in various species, illustrating an innovative experimental approach for identifying new regulatory partners or activators with increased accuracy. Through this work they have created a powerful tool for gaining insights into regulation at the level of linear peptide sequences and provide scientists from several fields with access to data on how these proteins interact with other pathways and molecules involved in living cells.

title: Development of an optimized RNA-based murine norovirus reverse genetics system
abstract: Murine norovirus (MNV), identified in 2003, is the only norovirus which replicates efficiently in tissue culture and as a result has been used extensively as a model for human noroviruses, a major cause of acute gastroenteritis. The current report describes the generation of a new approach to reverse genetics recovery of genetically defined MNV that relies on the transfection of in vitro transcribed capped RNA directly into cells. The use of the recently developed ScriptCap post-transcriptional enzymatic capping system, followed by optimized Neon mediated electroporation of the highly permissive RAW 264.7 cells, resulted in the rapid and robust recovery of infectious MNV. Transfection of cells capable of supporting virus replication but not permissive to virus infection, namely human or hamster kidney cells, also resulted in robust recovery of infectious virus without subsequent amplification by multiple rounds of re-infection. This latter system may provide a reproducible method to measure the specific infectivity of mutant norovirus RNA allowing the accurate quantitation of the effect of mutations on norovirus replication.

title: Journals, Academics, and Pandemics
abstract: In the wake of the SARS epidemic and the H1N1 pandemic, the PLoS Medicine editors ask whether journal publishing is an efficient enough mechanism for information sharing.

title: Immune pathways and defence mechanisms in honey bees Apis mellifera
abstract: Social insects are able to mount both group-level and individual defences against pathogens. Here we focus on individual defences, by presenting a genome-wide analysis of immunity in a social insect, the honey bee Apis mellifera. We present honey bee models for each of four signalling pathways associated with immunity, identifying plausible orthologues for nearly all predicted pathway members. When compared to the sequenced Drosophila and Anopheles genomes, honey bees possess roughly one-third as many genes in 17 gene families implicated in insect immunity. We suggest that an implied reduction in immune flexibility in bees reflects either the strength of social barriers to disease, or a tendency for bees to be attacked by a limited set of highly coevolved pathogens.

title: Multiplexed Genetic Analysis Using an Expanded Genetic Alphabet
abstract: BACKGROUND: All states require some kind of testing for newborns, but the policies are far from standardized. In some states, newborn screening may include genetic tests for a wide range of targets, but the costs and complexities of the newer genetic tests inhibit expansion of newborn screening. We describe the development and technical evaluation of a multiplex platform that may foster increased newborn genetic screening. METHODS: MultiCode(®) PLx involves three major steps: PCR, target-specific extension, and liquid chip decoding. Each step is performed in the same reaction vessel, and the test is completed in ~3 h. For site-specific labeling and room-temperature decoding, we use an additional base pair constructed from isoguanosine and isocytidine. We used the method to test for mutations within the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene. The developed test was performed manually and by automated liquid handling. Initially, 225 samples with a range of genotypes were tested retrospectively with the method. A prospective study used samples from >400 newborns. RESULTS: In the retrospective study, 99.1% of samples were correctly genotyped with no incorrect calls made. In the perspective study, 95% of the samples were correctly genotyped for all targets, and there were no incorrect calls. CONCLUSIONS: The unique genetic multiplexing platform was successfully able to test for 31 targets within the CFTR gene and provides accurate genotype assignments in a clinical setting.

title: Interleukin-18 expression and the response to treatment in patients with psoriasis
abstract: This study focuses on the role of interleukin-18 (IL-18) expression in patients suffering from psoriasis and the effect of topical corticosteroid treatment. Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition, with an increasing prevalence globally. Excessive production of pro-inflammatory cytokines has been suggested to be involved in the pathogenesis, which can lead to local tissue damage and altered body homeostasis if left uncontrolled. IL-18 has recently been identified as playing a key role in mediating several aspects of this pro-inflammatory response; however, its exact regulatory roles remain largely unknown. We aimed to evaluate IL- 18 expression levels following effective topical steroid therapy for cutaneous psoriatic plaques and to reveals insights into its potential mechanism(s) regulating inflammation during the course of treatment. Patients with severe or moderate disease activity were selected for evaluation over 6 weeks using ELISA tests; clinical findings and biopsies before/after treatments were conducted for comparison between groups receiving different concentrations of medications. Our findings indicate that higher doses used yields better overall pustular reduction and beneficial changes in IL‑18 expression traits amongst individuals representing different patterns associated severity scales compared to lower dose counterparts.. This suggests that understanding underlying mechanisms behind regulated IL‑18 function may hold promise insight towards tackling improving patient outcomes even further through refining current standard therapeutic regimes utilized today.

title: Chinese-like Strain of Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea Virus, Thailand
abstract: Since late 2007, several outbreaks of porcine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV) infection have emerged in Thailand. Phylogenetic analysis places all Thai PEDV isolates during the outbreaks in the same clade as the Chinese strain JS-2004-2. This new genotype PEDV is prevailing and currently causing sporadic outbreaks in Thailand.

title: Multiplex primer prediction software for divergent targets
abstract: We describe a Multiplex Primer Prediction (MPP) algorithm to build multiplex compatible primer sets to amplify all members of large, diverse and unalignable sets of target sequences. The MPP algorithm is scalable to larger target sets than other available software, and it does not require a multiple sequence alignment. We applied it to questions in viral detection, and demonstrated that there are no universally conserved priming sequences among viruses and that it could require an unfeasibly large number of primers (∼3700 18-mers or ∼2000 10-mers) to generate amplicons from all sequenced viruses. We then designed primer sets separately for each viral family, and for several diverse species such as foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV), hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) segments of influenza A virus, Norwalk virus, and HIV-1. We empirically demonstrated the application of the software with a multiplex set of 16 short (10 nt) primers designed to amplify the Poxviridae family to produce a specific amplicon from vaccinia virus.

title: Elevation of Intact and Proteolytic Fragments of Acute Phase Proteins Constitutes the Earliest Systemic Antiviral Response in HIV-1 Infection
abstract: The earliest immune responses activated in acute human immunodeficiency virus type 1 infection (AHI) exert a critical influence on subsequent virus spread or containment. During this time frame, components of the innate immune system such as macrophages and DCs, NK cells, β-defensins, complement and other anti-microbial factors, which have all been implicated in modulating HIV infection, may play particularly important roles. A proteomics-based screen was performed on a cohort from whom samples were available at time points prior to the earliest positive HIV detection. The ability of selected factors found to be elevated in the plasma during AHI to inhibit HIV-1 replication was analyzed using in vitro PBMC and DC infection models. Analysis of unique plasma donor panels spanning the eclipse and viral expansion phases revealed very early alterations in plasma proteins in AHI. Induction of acute phase protein serum amyloid A (A-SAA) occurred as early as 5–7 days prior to the first detection of plasma viral RNA, considerably prior to any elevation in systemic cytokine levels. Furthermore, a proteolytic fragment of alpha–1-antitrypsin (AAT), termed virus inhibitory peptide (VIRIP), was observed in plasma coincident with viremia. Both A-SAA and VIRIP have anti-viral activity in vitro and quantitation of their plasma levels indicated that circulating concentrations are likely to be within the range of their inhibitory activity. Our results provide evidence for a first wave of host anti-viral defense occurring in the eclipse phase of AHI prior to systemic activation of other immune responses. Insights gained into the mechanism of action of acute-phase reactants and other innate molecules against HIV and how they are induced could be exploited for the future development of more efficient prophylactic vaccine strategies.

title: DotKnot: pseudoknot prediction using the probability dot plot under a refined energy model
abstract: RNA pseudoknots are functional structure elements with key roles in viral and cellular processes. Prediction of a pseudoknotted minimum free energy structure is an NP-complete problem. Practical algorithms for RNA structure prediction including restricted classes of pseudoknots suffer from high runtime and poor accuracy for longer sequences. A heuristic approach is to search for promising pseudoknot candidates in a sequence and verify those. Afterwards, the detected pseudoknots can be further analysed using bioinformatics or laboratory techniques. We present a novel pseudoknot detection method called DotKnot that extracts stem regions from the secondary structure probability dot plot and assembles pseudoknot candidates in a constructive fashion. We evaluate pseudoknot free energies using novel parameters, which have recently become available. We show that the conventional probability dot plot makes a wide class of pseudoknots including those with bulged stems manageable in an explicit fashion. The energy parameters now become the limiting factor in pseudoknot prediction. DotKnot is an efficient method for long sequences, which finds pseudoknots with higher accuracy compared to other known prediction algorithms. DotKnot is accessible as a web server at http://dotknot.csse.uwa.edu.au.

title: The impact of sex, gender and pregnancy on 2009 H1N1 disease
abstract: Children and young adults of reproductive age have emerged as groups that are highly vulnerable to the current 2009 H1N1 pandemic. The sex of an individual is a fundamental factor that can influence exposure, susceptibility and immune responses to influenza. Worldwide, the incidence, disease burden, morbidity and mortality rates following exposure to the 2009 H1N1 influenza virus differ between males and females and are often age-dependent. Pregnancy and differences in the presentation of various risk factors contribute to the worse outcome of infection in women. Vaccination and antiviral treatment efficacy also vary in a sex-dependent manner. Finally, sex-specific genetic and hormonal differences may contribute to the severity of influenza and the clearance of viral infection. The contribution of sex and gender to influenza can only be determined by a greater consideration of these factors in clinical and epidemiological studies and increased research into the biological basis underlying these differences.

title: Primary biliary cirrhosis
abstract: Primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC) is an immune-mediated chronic cholestatic liver disease with a slowly progressive course. Without treatment, most patients eventually develop fibrosis and cirrhosis of the liver and may need liver transplantation in the late stage of disease. PBC primarily affects women (female preponderance 9–10:1) with a prevalence of up to 1 in 1,000 women over 40 years of age. Common symptoms of the disease are fatigue and pruritus, but most patients are asymptomatic at first presentation. The diagnosis is based on sustained elevation of serum markers of cholestasis, i.e., alkaline phosphatase and gamma-glutamyl transferase, and the presence of serum antimitochondrial antibodies directed against the E2 subunit of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex. Histologically, PBC is characterized by florid bile duct lesions with damage to biliary epithelial cells, an often dense portal inflammatory infiltrate and progressive loss of small intrahepatic bile ducts. Although the insight into pathogenetic aspects of PBC has grown enormously during the recent decade and numerous genetic, environmental, and infectious factors have been disclosed which may contribute to the development of PBC, the precise pathogenesis remains enigmatic. Ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) is currently the only FDA-approved medical treatment for PBC. When administered at adequate doses of 13–15 mg/kg/day, up to two out of three patients with PBC may have a normal life expectancy without additional therapeutic measures. The mode of action of UDCA is still under discussion, but stimulation of impaired hepatocellular and cholangiocellular secretion, detoxification of bile, and antiapoptotic effects may represent key mechanisms. One out of three patients does not adequately respond to UDCA therapy and may need additional medical therapy and/or liver transplantation. This review summarizes current knowledge on the clinical, diagnostic, pathogenetic, and therapeutic aspects of PBC.

title: A Method to Identify p62's UBA Domain Interacting Proteins
abstract: The UBA domain is a conserved sequence motif among polyubiquitin binding proteins. For the first time, we demonstrate a systematic, high throughput approach to identification of UBA domain-interacting proteins from a proteome-wide perspective. Using the rabbit reticulocyte lysate in vitro expression cloning system, we have successfully identified eleven proteins that interact with p62’s UBA domain, and the majority of the eleven proteins are associated with neurodegenerative disorders, such as Alzheimer’s disease. Therefore, p62 may play a novel regulatory role through its UBA domain. Our approach provides an easy route to the characterization of UBA domain interacting proteins and its application will unfold the important roles that the UBA domain plays.

title: Screening Pneumonia Patients for Mimivirus
abstract: Acanthamoeba polyphaga mimivirus (APM), a virus of free-living amebae, has reportedly caused human respiratory disease. Using 2 newly developed real-time PCR assays, we screened 496 respiratory specimens from 9 pneumonia-patient populations for APM. This virus was not detected in any specimen, which suggests it is not a common respiratory pathogen.

title: Age groups and spread of influenza: implications for vaccination strategy
abstract: BACKGROUND: The unpredictable nature of the potentially devastating impact of 2009 pH1N1 influenza pandemic highlights the need for pandemic preparedness planning, where modeling studies could be most useful for simulations of possible future scenarios. METHODS: A compartmental model with pre-symptomatic and asymptomatic influenza infections is proposed which incorporates age groups as well as intervention measures such as age-specific vaccination, in order to study spread of influenza in a community. RESULTS: We derive the basic reproduction number and other effective reproduction numbers under various intervention measures. For illustration, we make use of the Pneumonia and Influenza (P&I) mortality data and vaccination data of the very young (age 0-2) and the very old (age >64) during 2004-2005 Taiwan winter influenza season to fit our model and to compute the relevant reproduction numbers. The reproduction number for this winter flu season is estimated to be slightly above one (~1.0001). CONCLUSIONS: Comparatively large errors in fitting the P&I mortality data of the elderly (>64) were observed shortly after winter school closings in January, which may indicate the impact of younger, more active age groups transmitting influenza to other age groups outside of the school settings; in particular, to the elderly in the households. Pre-symptomatic infections seemed to have little effect on the model fit, while asymptomatic infection by asymptomatic infectives has a more pronounced impact on the model fit for the elderly mortality, perhaps indicating a larger role in disease transmission by asymptomatic infection. Simulations indicate that the impact of vaccination on the disease incidence might not be fully revealed in the change (or the lack thereof) in the effective reproduction number with interventions, but could still be substantial. The estimated per contact transmission probability for susceptible elderly is significantly higher than that of any other age group, perhaps highlighting the vulnerability of the elderly due to close contacts with their caretakers from other age groups. The relative impact of targeting the very young and the very old for vaccination was weakened by their relative inactivity, thus giving evidence of the lack of impact of vaccinating these two groups on the overall transmissibility of the disease in the community. This further underscores the need for morbidity-based strategy to prevent elderly mortality.

title: Mutations in the Fusion Protein Cleavage Site of Avian Paramyxovirus Serotype 4 Confer Increased Replication and Syncytium Formation In Vitro but Not Increased Replication and Pathogenicity in Chickens and Ducks
abstract: This research paper aims to explore the effects of mutations in the fusion protein cleavage site of avian paramyxovirus serotype 4 (APMV-4) and how they influence viral replication and pathogenicity when tested both in vitro and in vivo. Avian paramyxoviruses are viruses commonly found infecting chickens, ducks, pheasants, turkeys and other birds. These infections can cause a wide range of clinical symptoms from asymptomatic infections to severe fatal diseases. Therefore, understanding how different virus strains replicate and affect host species is critical for determining possible transmission routes and ultimately improving control strategies for this group of illnesses. In this study, reverse genetics technology was employed to evaluate four G486 mutants with single amino acid substitutions within the APVM-4 fusion protein cleavage region on their replication properties both in chick embryo fibroblasts (CEFs) cultures as well as live chickens or ducklings. Our results indicate that while most mutant viruses replicated similarly to wild type virus at 28 °C when cultured with CEFs, they demonstrated significantly increased formation of syncytia along with enhanced replicative activity under these conditions but had no effect on virulence or transmission potential when tested against poultry hosts.

title: Replication-Competent Recombinant Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome (PRRS) Viruses Expressing Indicator Proteins and Antiviral Cytokines
abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to the battle against Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome (PRRS), an economically significant disease of pigs. The goal is to create replication-competent recombinant PRRS viruses that express indicator proteins and antiviral cytokines in order to facilitate detection, vaccination, and precise therapeutics. To accomplish this feat, reverse genetics methods were employed with nucleic acid sequences extracted from field isolates of classical PRRS virus (PRRSV). Further selection processes led to the successful identification of three modified vaccinia Ankara vector constructs containing full-length PRRS ORF7 gene sequence flanked by signal peptide 3’UTR elements which enabled expression in pig pulmonary epithelial cells. The remaining portions of our research set out demonstrate that the resultant products meet requirements for valid incorporation into targeted cell lines as it does not compromise biological activity or cause cellular cytotoxicity throughout manipulation for further testing.

title: Avian Influenza Virus Glycoproteins Restrict Virus Replication and Spread through Human Airway Epithelium at Temperatures of the Proximal Airways
abstract: Transmission of avian influenza viruses from bird to human is a rare event even though avian influenza viruses infect the ciliated epithelium of human airways in vitro and ex vivo. Using an in vitro model of human ciliated airway epithelium (HAE), we demonstrate that while human and avian influenza viruses efficiently infect at temperatures of the human distal airways (37°C), avian, but not human, influenza viruses are restricted for infection at the cooler temperatures of the human proximal airways (32°C). These data support the hypothesis that avian influenza viruses, ordinarily adapted to the temperature of the avian enteric tract (40°C), rarely infect humans, in part due to differences in host airway regional temperatures. Previously, a critical residue at position 627 in the avian influenza virus polymerase subunit, PB2, was identified as conferring temperature-dependency in mammalian cells. Here, we use reverse genetics to show that avianization of residue 627 attenuates a human virus, but does not account for the different infection between 32°C and 37°C. To determine the mechanism of temperature restriction of avian influenza viruses in HAE at 32°C, we generated recombinant human influenza viruses in either the A/Victoria/3/75 (H3N2) or A/PR/8/34 (H1N1) genetic background that contained avian or avian-like glycoproteins. Two of these viruses, A/Victoria/3/75 with L226Q and S228G mutations in hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) from A/Chick/Italy/1347/99 and A/PR/8/34 containing the H7 and N1 from A/Chick/Italy/1347/99, exhibited temperature restriction approaching that of wholly avian influenza viruses. These data suggest that influenza viruses bearing avian or avian-like surface glycoproteins have a reduced capacity to establish productive infection at the temperature of the human proximal airways. This temperature restriction may limit zoonotic transmission of avian influenza viruses and suggests that adaptation of avian influenza viruses to efficient infection at 32°C may represent a critical evolutionary step enabling human-to-human transmission.

title: mRNA pseudoknot structures can act as ribosomal roadblocks
abstract: The title of this study is ‘mRNA Pseudoknot Structures Can Act as Ribosomal Roadblocks’. mRNA pseudoknot structures are common in eukaryotic cells, often modulating the translation phase by hindering protein synthesis with their unique three-dimensional structure. This complex phenomenon has remained largely unexplored in terms of its wider implications for cellular function and development biology. Our research seeks to understand how these pseudoknots may interact with ribosomes - a fundamental component of the cell responsible for protein synthesis - to present an obstacle that interferes with normal translational outcomes. We sought to identify particular motifs from different mRNAs that could potentially act as road blocks in ribosome scanning activities or cause errors during overall protein production. To test our hypothesis we used extensively the bioinformatic tools developed at our lab combined with surface plasmon resonance imaging experiments directly conducted on purified proteins samples banked within research databases around Europe. The results obtained indicate that interesting features are present when introducing pseudoknot structures inside RNA templates which can offer evidence confirming our hypothesis and support additional studies into this still uncharted field

title: Lifeomics leads the age of grand discoveries
abstract: This article examines the burgeoning field of lifeomics and its associated technological advancements that are leading us into an era of grand discoveries. Lifeomics – or the study of the biodiversity structure, dynamics and evolution of life – is enabling groundbreaking developments in fields such as genetics, genomics, diagnostics and bioinformatics. Over recent years, advances in sequencing technologies have created vast amounts of data on virtually every living thing on Earth. This has enabled sophisticated analysis that allows scientists to interpret ‘life codes’ from sequences across species to discover new insights about diseases, progress conservation efforts with greater efficiency, refine crop diversity for better farmers’ yields and even explore global evolution patterns over time. Furthermore, machine learning techniques can identify novel relationships between different biological systems; giving rise to a promising opportunity for pharmaceuticals companies hoping to produce more effective drugs faster than ever before. All these benefits illustrate why lifeomics is becoming a booming area where researchers around the world continue to make significant strides towards valuable scientific findings with immense potential applications that could revolutionize our everyday lives by furthering medical therapies while elucidating solutions for many grand challenges facing humanity today.

title: A scientometric analysis of Indian research output in medicine during 1999–2008
abstract: This article presents the findings of a scientometric analysis undertaken to study research productivity in India's medical field during the period 1999–2008. With an aim to provide statistically significant insights on current and past research trends, bibliographic records from selected academic journals have been analyzed using Scientometrics indicators such as citations, citations per paper (CPP), journal impact factor (JIF) etc. Results of this multi-dimensional analysis depict a positive outlook for Indian medical research with steady growth over these ten years. Interesting features observed include large regional variation within India depending on access to resources and funding opportunities while also highlighting gaps in existing studies that need further exploration. The managerial implications of this work are discussed with a view towards helping policy makers strategize decisions related to managing investments in health care research for more efficient outcomes.

title: Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation for acute respiratory failure in children: a concise review
abstract:
This paper reviews the use of noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NPPV) in children with acute respiratory failure. It evaluates evidence on aspects concerning its effectiveness, effect on mortality and morbidity, patient comfort, potential adverse effects and additional complications. The introduction provides an overview of what NPPV is and why it has become an increasingly popular treatment in pediatrics since its first approval by the U.S Food & Drug Administration for adults in 2001. Research studies demonstrate that NPPV leads to improved oxygenation levels as well as reduced discomfort for patients compared to other methods such as endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation. Additionally, clinical trials have shown reductions in length of hospital stay along with lower mortality rates when used with adjuncts like bilevel positive airway pressure systems. Discussion includes key pharmacologic protocols associated with pediatric cases including considerations taken into account during medical decision-making processes determining severity among practitioners both pre-hospitalized or hospitalized settings due to congenital anomalies or critical illness progression; highlighting necessary precautions regarding setting selection appropriately prior to repetitive initiation session relative to personal safety measures for healthcare workers providing NPPV services within ventilated suites manifesting under continuous monitoring regime throughout each interval dependent encounter process(es). 

Noninvasive Positive Pressure Ventilation for Acute Respiratory Failure In Children: A Concise Review

title: Human Subtilase SKI-1/S1P Is a Master Regulator of the HCV Lifecycle and a Potential Host Cell Target for Developing Indirect-Acting Antiviral Agents
abstract: The Human subtilase SKI-1/S1P has long been recognized as an essential part of the cellular energy generation process. More recently, however, it has been discovered to be a master regulator of the Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) lifecycle and potentially a promising target for developing novel indirect-acting antiviral agents. The objective of this research was to investigate the effects of manipulating human SKI-1/S1P expression levels on HCV replication in order to gain further insight into its function in the host cell environment. In particular, we demonstrate that increasing S1P expression levels significantly reduced viral production from cells infected with both wild type and mutant forms of HCV genotype 2a. Moreover, these findings suggest a potential role for S1P in regulating innate immunity pathways associated with HCV infection and provide an open avenue for exploring selectively targeted anti-viral therapies based on modulation of human subtilase SKI- 1/SIP activity.

title: Early Clinical Features of Dengue Virus Infection in Nicaraguan Children: A Longitudinal Analysis
abstract: This study examines the early clinical features of dengue virus infection in Nicaraguan children and investigates how these symptoms differ from other febrile illnesses. Using a longitudinal analysis, this paper looks at the frequency and severity of several specific signs and symptoms associated with acute dengue virus infection in a sample population over two years. Through detailed observation, systemic reviews, interviews and analyses, this study elucidates which indicators are most common to the disease, as well as offering insights into demographic details that might predict illness-severitysuch as age or gender. Moreover there is an exploration of socioenvironmental factors influencing transmission dynamics amongst Nicaraguan pediatric populations – such as housing density or natural breeding habitats for Aedes mosquitos.
