Consistent with this, the VP2 start codon (AUG) of MNV overlaps the stop codon of the upstream VP1 ORF (UAA) in the pentanucleotide UAA UG. PRINCIPAL FINDINGS: Here, we confirm that MNV VP2 expression is regulated by termination-reinitiation and define the mRNA sequence requirements. Efficient reintiation is dependent upon 43 nt of RNA immediately upstream of the UAA UG site. Chemical and enzymatic probing revealed that the RNA in this region is not highly structured and includes an essential stretch of bases complementary to 18S rRNA helix 26 (Motif 1). The relative position of Motif 1 with respect to the UAA UG site impacts upon the efficiency of the process. Termination-reinitiation in MNV was also found to be relatively insensitive to the initiation inhibitor edeine. CONCLUSIONS: The termination-reinitiation signal of MNV most closely resembles that of influenza BM2. Similar to other viruses that use this strategy, base-pairing between mRNA and rRNA is likely to play a role in tethering the 40S subunit to the mRNA following termination at the VP1 stop codon. Our data also indicate that accurate recognition of the VP2 ORF AUG is not a pre-requisite for efficient reinitiation of translation in this system.

title: TcdC Does Not Significantly Repress Toxin Expression in Clostridium difficile 630ΔErm
abstract: This paper studies the potential role of tcdC, a repressor of toxin expression in C. difficile, on ΔErm mutant 630 strain. To assess the significance of this regulatory factor on the toxigenicity of C. difficile strains, we compared the toxigenic load profiles from gene expression data between parental and isogenic mutants strains containing wildtype (wt) or deleted (ΔtcdC) alleles at locus encoding for Toxins A/B-regulatory protein (TcpA/B). The results demonstrated that deletion of tcdC did not significantly decrease overall toxin production but marginally decreased essentiality index values associated with low oxacillin concentration treatments whereby transcriptional activation by ToxR was partially blocked by mutation within erm genes. Our results suggest that while tcdC may play a minor regulatory role in some experimental settings, it is unlikely to be involved as an intrinsic regulator in commandeering surface attached toxins produced during normal growth conditions in clinical isolates harbouring functional ermA and ermB genes such as those found in common epidemic clones often observed throughout hospitals worldwide carrying toxic bypassed mechanism(s).

title: Application of Consensus Scoring and Principal Component Analysis for Virtual Screening against β-Secretase (BACE-1)
abstract: This paper presents results from a discovery application of consensus scoring, based on electrostatic potential derived spatial features and principal component analysis as applied to β-secretase (BACE-1) virtual screening. BACE-1 is an attractive drug target for the treatment of Alzheimer’s disease due to its involvement in amyloid-β pathology. Truncation induced by BACE-1 cleavage releases amyloid peptide which aggregates into toxic oligomers leading to synaptic damage. The presented computational search method was designed to identify potent small molecules interacting with BACE-1 active site pockets and possessing inhibitory activity against it. A total of 143 million compounds were virtually screened utilizing two step workflow including an initial improved consensus sorting protocol followed by final PCA discriminative model building and external validation test set evaluation. Our primary findings include higher enrichment scores at 0% false positive rate than those obtained by using traditional single scoring functions stand alone indicating a greater probability of finding novel inhibitors while preserving quality standards in hit selection criteria evaluation.

title: Differential Seroprevalence of Human Bocavirus Species 1-4 in Beijing, China
abstract:
Differential Seroprevalence of Human Bocavirus Species 1-4 in Beijing, China
Human bocaviruses (HBoV) are a small group of paramyxoviruses which typically infect the human respiratory tract and can cause mild to moderate lower respiratory infection. They were first reported in 2005 and since then, more than fifteen HBoVs have been identified worldwide. The seroprevalence of these viruses has not yet been adequately explored among different populations and regions. This study aimed at determining the differential seroprevalence of four major genotypes (species 1-4) that make up the three prevalent species groups globally among children aged 0-15 years living in Beijing, China. Following ELISA testing for IgG antibody levels against various HBoV antigens across 326 children from two districts within the city during 2017–2018 a total 59% seropositivity rate was found; 39%, 11%, 5% and 2% for species 1, 2, 3 and 4 respectively. Overall results showed significantly higher prevalence rates for species 1 as compared to other species groups likely due to aforementioned particularity followed by a pattern gradually decreasing from species 1 towards further downstream minor variants like type 4 although this finding would require further research investigations into larger cohorts with improved interventions specifically designed directed toward vulnerable subgroups at higher risk based on specific genotype predilection profiles so as inform better vaccine implementation strategies in improve public healthcare delivery protocols overall  amongst those communities where incidental outbreaks may be recurrently seen throughout time course.[237 words]

title: Severe imported malaria in an intensive care unit: a review of 59 cases
abstract: Severe imported malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in non-endemic regions. This paper provides a comprehensive review of 59 cases of severe imported malaria among patients admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) between January 2006 and April 2019. All the patients had traveled to their country or region which was endemic for Plasmodium falciparum, which is usually the species associated with severe clinical manifestations. The results showed that all deaths occurred in individuals with high parasitaemia, more than 10% haematocrit reduction, advanced age and central nervous system involvement. Although prompt diagnosis and appropriate treatment are always recommended after travel outside usual residence areas, this study findings suggest ICU admission should be considered when unexpected symptoms have been noticed even in minor travelers who present low/negative parasitaemia but compatible clinical picture as well as specific laboratory features such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). Thus an early recognition by clinicians on any patient suffering from fever following trips abroad in endemic countries can not only improve prognosis but also initiate prompt diagnostic procedures towards successful management leading to reduced mortality from Severe Imported Malaria.

title: Criminalizing Health-Related Behaviors Dangerous to Others? Disease Transmission, Transmission-Facilitation, and the Importance of Trust
abstract: The advancement of public health is constantly at the forefront of legislative goals and societal debates due to its highly visible impact. While criminalizing behavior that is dangerous to physical health has become a focus worldwide, this paper will examine the complex relationship between actions aimed at halting disease transmission, their ability to actually facilitate transmission, and how trust can be detrimentally impacted in such a situation. Through examining existing case studies involving HIV/AIDS criminalization laws in countries around the world, implications on other crimes centered around public health behaviors could become more apparent as legislation evolves over time. This exploration into catastrophic outcomes potentially associated with attempting to contain public health issues using legal means should bring greater awareness on the importance placed upon trust building initiatives between those enacting immediate change measures and affected populations who must bear any consequences from them.

title: Case-based reported mortality associated with laboratory-confirmed influenza A(H1N1) 2009 virus infection in the Netherlands: the 2009-2010 pandemic season versus the 2010-2011 influenza season
abstract: This study presents a systematic analysis of case-based reported mortality associated with laboratory-confirmed influenza A(H1N1) 2009 virus infection in the Netherlands during the pandemic season of 2009–2010 and the influenza season of 2010–2011. Using routinely collected surveillance data, we investigated national patterns and trends as well as characteristics associated with reported deaths. Our results showed considerable differences between both seasons with respect to mortality risk factors, disease severity and overall impact on public health. During the pandemic of 2009-2010 more deaths were observed in women compared to men (RR: 1.31; 95%CI: 1.03~1.66), while during the 2010/2011 season a reverse pattern was found (RR: 0.80; 95%CI: 0.64-0·98). Additionally, multiple comorbidities were significantly more often present among individuals who succumbed from an H1N1 infection in both seasons (p<0·001), whereas immune status differed only slightly between both cohorts [OR = 0·785, CI = (95%: 0·638 – -0·970)]. Our findings suggest that clear preventive strategies should be applied for vulnerable populations such as elderly people, pregnant women and those suffering from certain medical conditions during future influenza outbreaks or epidemics on a national level throughout Europe

title: First report of molecular identification of Cystoisospora suis in piglets with lethal diarrhea in Japan
abstract: This article presents the first evidence of molecular identification of Cystoisospora suis in piglets with lethal diarrhea in Japan. The research investigated a sample of veterinarians and their reported cases across 5 regions, and revealed that C. suis had been predominately causing a major outbreak among piglets associated with high mortality rates. Data from autopsy results confirmed that samples contained the species, as well as microbiological testings from tissue sampling which also showed 100% infection rate amongst the same group. By comprehensively examining both pathological findings, this report is able to provide further insight into the epidemiology of C. suis-associated diarrheal illness among piglets in the said country and can be used for more effective diagnosis, early detection and better management strategies for these types of diseases moving forward.

title: Development of a humanized monoclonal antibody with therapeutic potential against West Nile virus
abstract: Neutralization of West Nile virus (WNV) in vivo correlates with the development of an antibody response against the viral envelope (E) protein. Using random mutagenesis and yeast surface display, we defined individual contact residues of 14 newly generated monoclonal antibodies against domain III of the WNV E protein. Monoclonal antibodies that strongly neutralized WNV localized to a surface patch on the lateral face of domain III. Convalescent antibodies from individuals who had recovered from WNV infection also detected this epitope. One monoclonal antibody, E16, neutralized 10 different strains in vitro, and showed therapeutic efficacy in mice, even when administered as a single dose 5 d after infection. A humanized version of E16 was generated that retained antigen specificity, avidity and neutralizing activity. In postexposure therapeutic trials in mice, a single dose of humanized E16 protected mice against WNV-induced mortality, and may therefore be a viable treatment option against WNV infection in humans. SUPPLEMENTARY INFORMATION: The online version of this article (doi:10.1038/nm1240) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.

title: Modeling the Economic Impact of Pandemic Influenza: A Case Study in Turkey
abstract: This study examined the economic impact of pandemic influenza on Turkey, with a particular focus on how various public health strategies influence its spread. Using a computed general equilibrium (CGE) model, estimates of changes to gross domestic product (GDP), human capital stock and labor supply were made in response to varying levels of disease containment. The results suggest that additional investment into containment strategies could reduce mortality risk along with the long-term financial losses associated with it; bolstering healthcare resources such as testing capabilities and protective medical equipment may prove especially beneficial. This research demonstrates the utility of CGE modeling technique for understanding costs & benefits when faced with an unpredictable global phenomenon like a pandemic influenza outbreak.

title: Dating the time of viral subtype divergence
abstract: Precise dating of viral subtype divergence enables researchers to correlate divergence with geographic and demographic occurrences. When historical data are absent (that is, the overwhelming majority), viral sequence sampling on a time scale commensurate with the rate of substitution permits the inference of the times of subtype divergence. Currently, researchers use two strategies to approach this task, both requiring strong conditions on the molecular clock assumption of substitution rate. As the underlying structure of the substitution rate process at the time of subtype divergence is not understood and likely highly variable, we present a simple method that estimates rates of substitution, and from there, times of divergence, without use of an assumed molecular clock. We accomplish this by blending estimates of the substitution rate for triplets of dated sequences where each sequence draws from a distinct viral subtype, providing a zeroth-order approximation for the rate between subtypes. As an example, we calculate the time of divergence for three genes among influenza subtypes A-H3N2 and B using subtype C as an outgroup. We show a time of divergence approximately 100 years ago, substantially more recent than previous estimates which range from 250 to 3800 years ago.

title: Application of Molecular Diagnostic Techniques for Viral Testing
abstract: This study focuses on the application of molecular diagnostic techniques for accurate and timely viral testing. Viral infections have become a major burden to public health worldwide, costing billions of dollars each year. As such, it is paramount that point-of-care solutions be employed in order to identify and diagnose viral activity early on. The utilization of next generation sequencing (NGS) coupled with gene expression profiling has revolutionized diagnostic procedures in recent years, enabling speedy detection at reduced costs compared with traditional methods. This paper explores the advantages offered by NGS technology as well as its implications for patient care management through a systematic review of various relevant studies presented since 2013. Moreover, this research will propose alternative approaches for effective medical response programs in clinical settings where diagnostics are not immediately available or accessible due to financial restrictions or other pertinent factors influencing global health considerations.

title: Animal models of acute lung injury
abstract: Acute lung injury in humans is characterized histopathologically by neutrophilic alveolitis, injury of the alveolar epithelium and endothelium, hyaline membrane formation, and microvascular thrombi. Different animal models of experimental lung injury have been used to investigate mechanisms of lung injury. Most are based on reproducing in animals known risk factors for ARDS, such as sepsis, lipid embolism secondary to bone fracture, acid aspiration, ischemia-reperfusion of pulmonary or distal vascular beds, and other clinical risks. However, none of these models fully reproduces the features of human lung injury. The goal of this review is to summarize the strengths and weaknesses of existing models of lung injury. We review the specific features of human ARDS that should be modeled in experimental lung injury and then discuss specific characteristics of animal species that may affect the pulmonary host response to noxious stimuli. We emphasize those models of lung injury that are based on reproducing risk factors for human ARDS in animals and discuss the advantages and disadvantages of each model and the extent to which each model reproduces human ARDS. The present review will help guide investigators in the design and interpretation of animal studies of acute lung injury.

title: Logistics of community smallpox control through contact tracing and ring vaccination: a stochastic network model
abstract: BACKGROUND: Previous smallpox ring vaccination models based on contact tracing over a network suggest that ring vaccination would be effective, but have not explicitly included response logistics and limited numbers of vaccinators. METHODS: We developed a continuous-time stochastic simulation of smallpox transmission, including network structure, post-exposure vaccination, vaccination of contacts of contacts, limited response capacity, heterogeneity in symptoms and infectiousness, vaccination prior to the discontinuation of routine vaccination, more rapid diagnosis due to public awareness, surveillance of asymptomatic contacts, and isolation of cases. RESULTS: We found that even in cases of very rapidly spreading smallpox, ring vaccination (when coupled with surveillance) is sufficient in most cases to eliminate smallpox quickly, assuming that 95% of household contacts are traced, 80% of workplace or social contacts are traced, and no casual contacts are traced, and that in most cases the ability to trace 1–5 individuals per day per index case is sufficient. If smallpox is assumed to be transmitted very quickly to contacts, it may at times escape containment by ring vaccination, but could be controlled in these circumstances by mass vaccination. CONCLUSIONS: Small introductions of smallpox are likely to be easily contained by ring vaccination, provided contact tracing is feasible. Uncertainties in the nature of bioterrorist smallpox (infectiousness, vaccine efficacy) support continued planning for ring vaccination as well as mass vaccination. If initiated, ring vaccination should be conducted without delays in vaccination, should include contacts of contacts (whenever there is sufficient capacity) and should be accompanied by increased public awareness and surveillance.

title: Characterization of Neutralizing Profiles in HIV-1 Infected Patients from whom the HJ16, HGN194 and HK20 mAbs were Obtained
abstract:
This article introduces the characterization of neutralizing profiles in HIV-1 infected patients from whom monoclonal antibodies such as HJ16, HGN194 and HK20 have been obtained. The purpose of this study is to explore the therapeutic activities of these mAbs against Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV). Analyses performed on serum samples collected from three individuals included tests for sensitivity to agonists and antagonists, testing for epitope binding motifs using CD4+, CCR5+ receptor binding analysis. Through a combination of techniques including quantitative viruses production assays, antigenic cross reactivity measurements, correlation studies between ligand-receptor target sites and virus vulnerability profiles were established for all three types of mAbs. Results indicated that each antibody had different mechanisms for blocking HIV infection as well as varying levels of viral intracellular penetration capabilities. Furthermore, an in vitro model system combining yeast immunosequencing technology with bioluminescence signal transduction was used to directly observe real time changes in the strength and magnitude ratio between replication inhibition among various antigens after exposure to specific concentrations conditions allowing us to further establish individualized therapeutic strategies based on patient's serology characteristics by linking immune responses associated with susceptible or resistant cellular strain phenotypes across multiple cells lines within a single experiment format. Overall our findings suggest that host genetics may be playing an important role influencing efficacy rates observed when used in vivo treatments settings indicating caution towards potential off target effects when selecting treatment regimens personalized according population variability concerns which must be addressed through sustainable supportive monitoring post clinical interventions procedure setting systems.. 

Title: Characterization of Neutralizing Profiles In HIV-1 Infected Patients From Whom The HJ16, HGN194 And HK20 MAbs Were Obtained

title: Epicatechins Purified from Green Tea (Camellia sinensis) Differentially Suppress Growth of Gender-Dependent Human Cancer Cell Lines
abstract: The anticancer potential of catechins derived from green tea is not well understood, in part because catechin-related growth suppression and/or apoptosis appears to vary with the type and stage of malignancy as well as with the type of catechin. This in vitro study examined the biological effects of epicatechin (EC), epigallocatechin (EGC), EC 3-gallate (ECG) and EGC 3-gallate (EGCG) in cell lines from human gender-specific cancers. Cell lines developed from organ-confined (HH870) and metastatic (DU145) prostate cancer, and from moderately (HH450) and poorly differentiated (HH639) epithelial ovarian cancer were grown with or without EC, EGC, ECG or EGCG. When untreated cells reached confluency, viability and doubling time were measured for treated and untreated cells. Whereas EC treatment reduced proliferation of HH639 cells by 50%, EGCG suppressed proliferation of all cell lines by 50%. ECG was even more potent: it inhibited DU145, HH870, HH450 and HH639 cells at concentrations of 24, 27, 29 and 30 µM, whereas EGCG inhibited DU145, HH870, HH450 and HH639 cells at concentrations 89, 45, 62 and 42 µM. When compared with EGCG, ECG more effectively suppresses the growth of prostate cancer and epithelial ovarian cancer cell lines derived from tumors of patients with different stages of disease.

title: Ebola Virus in West Africa: Waiting for the Owl of Minerva
abstract: The Ebola virus in West Africa has been a major concern for public health since its outbreak in 2014. This paper outlines the steps taken by the World Health Organization, government aid programs and local initiatives to contain and treat this deadly disease. The study also discusses how cultural beliefs, political instability and inadequate resources add complexity to controlling the situation. Through an analysis of both quantitative data, such as treatment numbers, mortality rates and quarantine results, as well as qualitative data focussed on understanding how individuals perceive their circumstances related to Ebola prevention efforts, we aim to provide a comprehensive overview of the current status of this crisis. We conclude that while some progress has been made so far, only time will tell if these measures prove effective or whether we must look within ourselves for our salvation through careful consideration of social dynamics - waiting for the Owl of Minerva.

title: Treatment of acute bronchitis in adults without underlying lung disease
abstract: This article presents an innovative study on the treatment of acute bronchitis in adults without underlying lung disease. Acute bronchitis is a commonlower respiratory infection with mortality rates as high as 12%. Despite extensive research, treatments are inadequate and adverse effects remain concerning. The aim of this study was to evaluate a novel therapeutic regimen for treating adult patients with acute bronchitis, examining parameters such as symptom duration, degree of pneumonic infiltration, presenting sputum scores and general health-related quality of life measures. A total of 80 participants were recruited from 3 different clinical facilities and assigned either to the control or the experimental group; outcomes were analyzed through descriptive statistics. Results indicate that after 13 days from diagnosing acute bronchitis, no significant differences emerged in terms of pneumonic infiltrate assessment among groups, although shorter mean time for symptom resolution (4 vs 7 days) with medium effect size was identified in the experimental group compared to controls. Moreover, promising data concerning improvement in overall health related quality of life ratings observed only amongst treatment subjects hints at potential effectiveness for novel interventions . The implications generated by these results set grounds for further consolidation regarding efficacious outcomes associated with recommended management strategies for patients affected by this condition.

title: Geographic Distribution and Risk Factors of the Initial Adult Hospitalized Cases of 2009 Pandemic Influenza A (H1N1) Virus Infection in Mainland China
abstract: Despite the emergence of the 2009 pandemic influenza A (H1N1) virus in Mainland China and its subsequent rapid geographic spread, there has been limited research into the distribution pattern of this newly emerged infection, as well as risk factors influencing adult hospitalized cases at an initial stage. In order to investigate these issues, a cross-sectional descriptive study was conducted focusing on mainland China between May 1st and October 31st, 2009. A total sample size of 1202 guests were recruited from 20 provinces across the country. Data on their demographics characteristics, health status prior to influenza acquisition ,and economic development level were collected and analyzed statistically by Chi Square test. The results revealed that adult hospitalization rate significantly varied according to geographical location with highest rate occurring in Northeast China followed by North and then central regions respectively. Gender disproportionality (male:female=2:1) was found among all age groups except for elderly people (>60 years). People lower socio-economic backgrounds increased their susceptibility 5 folds while people who lived in rural area had higher acute hospitalization than those from urban areas with OR 3.03(95% CI 2.40–3.85). These findings provide valuable insights when designing specific national interventions for managing H1N1 infection dynamically throughout mainland China during outbreak seasons or similar sudden public influenza health challenges elsewhere in future .

title: Demyelination and remyelination in the dorsal funiculus of the rat spinal cord after heat injury
abstract:
Title: Demyelination and Remyelination in the Dorsal Funiculus of the Rat Spinal Cord after Heat Injury
This paper investigates how heat injury affects demyelination and remyelination in the dorsal funiculus of rat spinal cord. The research design comprises morphological examination and immunofluorescence staining, targeting myelin basic protein (MBP) to determine any changes that occur in this region due to thermal trauma. Preceding study on neuronal-glial interactions has revealed an intrinsic potential for repair processes; however, its timing and course remain unclear. For further understanding of functional recovery mechanisms after tissue damage, there is a need to explore remyelination process at different stages in various pathologies relevant roles played by glia cells have been speculated. Therefore, using longitudinal studies related to heat injured rats could provide knowledge about determining background events enabling or inhibiting nervous system self-repair processes even without additional treatment intervention. Collectively, it may help reveal new therapeutic approaches leading towards clinical cure from such traumatic conditions not only limited to burn patients only but pertainable also with other injury scenarios damaged nerves suffer from including eperimental models of diabetic neuropathy foundation for future investigation regarding motor function improvements on chronic progression cases could be laid down as well., overall objective includes evaluating opportunities available due treatment optimization where paralysis, loss off sensation or impaired synaptic transfer are present impairments resultant effects caused by reduced insulation capacity wound axons possess after primary disruption myelin sheath covering them....

title: Role of glutathione in immunity and inflammation in the lung
abstract: Reactive oxygen species and thiol antioxidants, including glutathione (GSH), regulate innate immunity at various levels. This review outlines the redox-sensitive steps of the cellular mechanisms implicated in inflammation and host defense against infection, and describes how GSH is not only important as an antioxidant but also as a signaling molecule. There is an extensive literature of the role of GSH in immunity. Most reviews are biased by an oversimplified picture where “bad” free radicals cause all sorts of diseases and “good” antioxidants protect from them and prevent oxidative stress. While this may be the case in certain fields (eg, toxicology), the role of thiols (the topic of this review) in immunity certainly requires wearing scientist’s goggles and being prepared to accept a more complex picture. This review aims at describing the role of GSH in the lung in the context of immunity and inflammation. The first part summarizes the history and basic concepts of this picture. The second part focuses on GSH metabolism/levels in pathology, the third on the role of GSH in innate immunity and inflammation, and the fourth gives 4 examples describing the importance of GSH in the response to infections.

title: The infection of primary avian tracheal epithelial cells with infectious bronchitis virus
abstract: Here we introduce a culture system for the isolation, passaging and amplification of avian tracheal epithelial (ATE) cells. The ATE medium, which contains chicken embryo extract and fetal bovine serum, supports the growth of ciliated cells, goblet cells and basal cells from chicken tracheas on fibronectin- or matrigel-coated dishes. Non-epithelial cells make up less than 10% of the total population. We further show that ATE cells support the replication and spread of infectious bronchitis virus (IBV). Interestingly, immunocytostaining revealed that basal cells are resistant to IBV infection. We also demonstrate that glycosaminoglycan had no effect on infection of the cells by IBV. Taken together, these findings suggest that primary ATE cells provide a novel cell culture system for the amplification of IBV and the in vitro characterization of viral cytopathogenesis.

title: Oligonucleotide Based Magnetic Bead Capture of Onchocerca volvulus DNA for PCR Pool Screening of Vector Black Flies
abstract: This article describes an investigation into the capture of Onchocerca volvulus DNA using oligonucleotide-coated magnetic beads and subsequent PCR pool screening of vector black flies. The problem tackled in this study is on how to screen vector black fly species quickly, accurately, and sensitively for O. volvulus infection as a tool to monitor transmission status of human onchocerciasis - a skin disease caused by parasitic nematodes – in endemic areas. Using a 16S ribosomal gene primer set targeting O. volvulusspecific molecules immobilized onto streptavidin-coated superparamagnetic Dynabeads M280, the precise amounts of target putative O. volvulus sequences are captured from different sample pools such as genetically diverse adult or larval field-collected specimens from multiple chorionic sites. A novel approach was developed allowing quick PCR pool screening with improved specificity due to higher sequencing accuracy at lower concentration levels obtained through pre-PCR selective bead capture process prior to direct nested PCR amplification step; thus clearing concerns associated with limited sample size issues during analysis. Results showed that method had comparable sensitivity when compared to conventional plasmid cloning−PCR approaches while being significantly faster1–2 orders of magnitude than those established molecular diagnosis systems currently used across endemic regions worldwide

title: Schmallenberg Virus Pathogenesis, Tropism and Interaction with the Innate Immune System of the Host
abstract: Schmallenberg virus (SBV) is a vector-borne zoonotic pathogen belonging to the family Bunyaviridae which has caused major economic losses in livestock production within Europe since its emergence in 2011. SBV infection is generally asymptomatic, however it can cause severe congenital defects and obstetrical problems in cattle, sheep and goats during outbreak periods. The aim of this study was to characterize the pathogenesis of Schmallenberg virus, its tropism and mechanism of interaction with the innate immune system of susceptible hosts. High throughput sequencing techniques were utilized to examine viral replication kinetics and assess the effect on host transcriptional responses involved in regulating inflammatory response pathways. Furthermore, recent scientific developments regarding reagents for analysis of differentially expressed genes through qPCR and immunofluorescence microscopy were employed for further evaluation using a 24 hour experimental model with 50% infectious dose (ID50). Results obtained may provide key insight into virus coordination between cell entry/exit points, tropism development as well as recognition events that take place during SBV emergence-provoking stages by the host media’s complement system thus leading towards optimization strategies tailored against future outbreaks.

title: Small Interfering RNA Targeting M2 Gene Induces Effective and Long Term Inhibition of Influenza A Virus Replication
abstract: RNA interference (RNAi) provides a powerful new means to inhibit viral infection specifically. However, the selection of siRNA-resistant viruses is a major concern in the use of RNAi as antiviral therapeutics. In this study, we conducted a lentiviral vector with a H1-short hairpin RNA (shRNA) expression cassette to deliver small interfering RNAs (siRNAs) into mammalian cells. Using this vector that also expresses enhanced green fluorescence protein (EGFP) as surrogate marker, stable shRNA-expressing cell lines were successfully established and the inhibition efficiencies of rationally designed siRNAs targeting to conserved regions of influenza A virus genome were assessed. The results showed that a siRNA targeting influenza M2 gene (siM2) potently inhibited viral replication. The siM2 was not only effective for H1N1 virus but also for highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1. In addition to its M2 inhibition, the siM2 also inhibited NP mRNA accumulation and protein expression. A long term inhibition effect of the siM2 was demonstrated and the emergence of siRNA-resistant mutants in influenza quasispecies was not observed. Taken together, our study suggested that M2 gene might be an optimal RNAi target for antiviral therapy. These findings provide useful information for the development of RNAi-based prophylaxis and therapy for human influenza virus infection.

title: Torsional restraint: a new twist on frameshifting pseudoknots
abstract: mRNA pseudoknots have a stimulatory function in programmed −1 ribosomal frameshifting (−1 PRF). Though we previously presented a model for how mRNA pseudoknots might activate the mechanism for −1 PRF, it did not address the question of the role that they may play in positioning the mRNA relative to the ribosome in this process [E. P. Plant, K. L. M. Jacobs, J. W. Harger, A. Meskauskas, J. L. Jacobs, J. L. Baxter, A. N. Petrov and J. D. Dinman (2003) RNA, 9, 168–174]. A separate ‘torsional restraint’ model suggests that mRNA pseudoknots act to increase the fraction of ribosomes directed to pause with the upstream heptameric slippery site positioned at the ribosome's A- and P-decoding sites [J. D. Dinman (1995) Yeast, 11, 1115–1127]. Here, experiments using a series of ‘pseudo-pseudoknots’ having different degrees of rotational freedom were used to test this model. The results of this study support the mechanistic hypothesis that −1 ribosomal frameshifting is enhanced by torsional resistance of the mRNA pseudoknot.

title: Frequency of group A rotavirus in diarrhoeic calves in Brazilian cattle herds, 1998–2002
abstract: "Frequency of group A rotavirus in diarrhoeic calves in Brazilian cattle herds, 1998–2002": This retrospective study aimed to investigate the prevalence of Group A Rotavirus (GAR) infections among diarrhetic calves from Brazilian cattle herds over a five year period. Using nine published epidemiologic reports, analysis was conducted for 1124 calf specimens collected between 1998 and 2002 from 28 states. Results demonstrated that GAR accounted for 26% of all sampled specimens, with marked variation between years and regions. In summary, this study exhibits an overall high rate of GAR infection amongst vaccinated and unvaccinated juvenile bovine animals throughout Brazil during the study period. The findings suggest important implications for the development of effective control strategies against such serious illnesses in domestic livestock production systems worldwide.

title: The Tennessee Children's Respiratory Initiative: Objectives, design and recruitment results of a prospective cohort study investigating infant viral respiratory illness and the development of asthma and allergic diseases
abstract: Background and objective: The ‘attack rate’ of asthma following viral lower respiratory tract infections (LRTI) is about 3–4 fold higher than that of the general population; however, the majority of children who develop viral LRTI during infancy do not develop asthma, and asthma incidence has been observed to continuously decrease with age. Thus, we do not understand how viral LRTI either predispose or serve as a marker of children to develop asthma. The Tennessee Children's Respiratory Initiative has been established as a longitudinal prospective investigation of infants and their biological mothers. The primary goals are to investigate both the acute and the long‐term health consequences of varying severity and aetiology of clinically significant viral respiratory tract infections on early childhood outcomes. Methods: Over four respiratory viral seasons, 2004–2008, term, non‐low birth weight previously healthy infants and their biological mothers were enrolled during an infant's acute viral respiratory illness. Longitudinal follow up to age 6 years is ongoing. Results: This report describes the study objectives, design and recruitment results of the over 650 families enrolled in this longitudinal investigation. The Tennessee Children's Respiratory Initiative is additionally unique because it is designed in parallel with a large retrospective birth cohort of over 95 000 mother–infant dyads with similar objectives to investigate the role of respiratory viral infection severity and aetiology in the development of asthma. Conclusions: Future reports from this cohort will help to clarify the complex relationship between infant respiratory viral infection severity, aetiology, atopic predisposition and the subsequent development of early childhood asthma and atopic diseases.

title: Neutralizing immunogenicity of transgenic carrot (Daucus carota L.)-derived measles virus hemagglutinin
abstract: This journal article explores the effects of neutralizing immunogenicity when using transgenic carrots (Daucus carota L.) derived with measles virus hemagglutinin (MVH). Using a reverse genetics approach and animal models, researchers conduct an expats evaluation to elucidate the potential use of such plants as novel vaccine delivery systems. The findings support that plant-based vaccines offer promising prospects for future vaccine development due to their safety, cost–effectiveness and versatility. Furthermore, there is evidence that suggests MVH expressed in transgenic carrots can stimulate strong humoral immunity compared to other traditional methods and their expression profiles indicates characteristics amenable to further modifications for antigen quality improvement. Additionally, results indicate that manipulation of induction conditions may prove useful in furthering the capacity of these vaccines both effectively mitigating immunological responses or even enhancing them depending on required goals. Thus it is concluded that transgenic carrot-derived MVH are capable immune inducing entities which suggest long lasting impactful implications regarding vaccine efficacy in humans by improving antigen design strategies and delivery mechanisms

title: Hospital Triage System for Adult Patients Using an Influenza-Like Illness Scoring System during the 2009 Pandemic—Mexico
abstract: BACKGROUND: Pandemic influenza A (H1N1) virus emerged during 2009. To help clinicians triage adults with acute respiratory illness, a scoring system for influenza-like illness (ILI) was implemented at Hospital Civil de Guadalajara, Mexico. METHODS: A medical history, laboratory and radiology results were collected on emergency room (ER) patients with acute respiratory illness to calculate an ILI-score. Patients were evaluated for admission by their ILI-score and clinicians' assessment of risk for developing complications. Nasal and throat swabs were collected from intermediate and high-risk patients for influenza testing by RT-PCR. The disposition and ILI-score of those oseltamivir-treated versus untreated, clinical characteristics of 2009 pandemic influenza A (H1N1) patients versus test-negative patients were compared by Pearson's Χ(2), Fisher's Exact, and Wilcoxon rank-sum tests. RESULTS: Of 1840 ER patients, 230 were initially hospitalized (mean ILI-score = 15), and the rest were discharged, including 286 ambulatory patients given oseltamivir (median ILI-score = 11), and 1324 untreated (median ILI-score = 5). Fourteen (1%) untreated patients returned, and 3 were hospitalized on oseltamivir (median ILI-score = 19). Of 371 patients tested by RT-PCR, 104 (28%) had pandemic influenza and 42 (11%) had seasonal influenza A detected. Twenty (91%) of 22 imaged hospitalized pandemic influenza patients had bilateral infiltrates compared to 23 (38%) of 61 imaged hospital test-negative patients (p<0.001). One patient with confirmed pandemic influenza presented 6 days after symptom onset, required mechanical ventilation, and died. CONCLUSIONS: The triaging system that used an ILI-score complimented clinicians' judgment of who needed oseltamivir and inpatient care and helped hospital staff manage a surge in demand for services.

title: VirHostNet: a knowledge base for the management and the analysis of proteome-wide virus–host interaction networks
abstract: Infectious diseases caused by viral agents kill millions of people every year. The improvement of prevention and treatment of viral infections and their associated diseases remains one of the main public health challenges. Towards this goal, deciphering virus–host molecular interactions opens new perspectives to understand the biology of infection and for the design of new antiviral strategies. Indeed, modelling of an infection network between viral and cellular proteins will provide a conceptual and analytic framework to efficiently formulate new biological hypothesis at the proteome scale and to rationalize drug discovery. Therefore, we present the first release of VirHostNet (Virus–Host Network), a public knowledge base specialized in the management and analysis of integrated virus–virus, virus–host and host–host interaction networks coupled to their functional annotations. VirHostNet integrates an extensive and original literature-curated dataset of virus–virus and virus–host interactions (2671 non-redundant interactions) representing more than 180 distinct viral species and one of the largest human interactome (10 672 proteins and 68 252 non-redundant interactions) reconstructed from publicly available data. The VirHostNet Web interface provides appropriate tools that allow efficient query and visualization of this infected cellular network. Public access to the VirHostNet knowledge-based system is available at http://pbildb1.univ-lyon1.fr/virhostnet.

title: Draft versus finished sequence data for DNA and protein diagnostic signature development
abstract: Sequencing pathogen genomes is costly, demanding careful allocation of limited sequencing resources. We built a computational Sequencing Analysis Pipeline (SAP) to guide decisions regarding the amount of genomic sequencing necessary to develop high-quality diagnostic DNA and protein signatures. SAP uses simulations to estimate the number of target genomes and close phylogenetic relatives (near neighbors or NNs) to sequence. We use SAP to assess whether draft data are sufficient or finished sequencing is required using Marburg and variola virus sequences. Simulations indicate that intermediate to high-quality draft with error rates of 10(−3)–10(−5) (∼8× coverage) of target organisms is suitable for DNA signature prediction. Low-quality draft with error rates of ∼1% (3× to 6× coverage) of target isolates is inadequate for DNA signature prediction, although low-quality draft of NNs is sufficient, as long as the target genomes are of high quality. For protein signature prediction, sequencing errors in target genomes substantially reduce the detection of amino acid sequence conservation, even if the draft is of high quality. In summary, high-quality draft of target and low-quality draft of NNs appears to be a cost-effective investment for DNA signature prediction, but may lead to underestimation of predicted protein signatures.

title: Antiparasitic DNA vaccines in 21(st) century
abstract: Antiparasitic DNA vaccines have emerged as a promising tool for controlling and eliminating infectious diseases in this 21(st) century. Although traditional parasite-based treatments are effective, they can be expensive and cause adverse reactions due to the multiple stages of parasites present in various hosts. Additionally, treatment strategies may become less effective owing to the increasing emergence of drug resistance amongst parasites. Thus, gene-based approaches such as antimicrobial peptides (AMPs), outer membrane proteins (OMPs) and DNA vaccination techniques provide an attractive alternative approach by targeting specific parasites at different points in their life cycle with greater efficacy while also avoiding issues associated with antibiotic resistance. This review will examine recent advances made in antiparasitic DNA vaccine research from its origins over two decades ago up until now, looking into their developments both within epidemiology models and laboratory based experiments; encompassing topics such as mechanism of action, stability considerations including immunogenic potentials for the expressed antigens that vary among host species versus vector species; additionally clinical trials designed to assess safety and immune responses induced via administration methods.

title: Neutralization of X4- and R5-tropic HIV-1 NL4-3 variants by HOCl-modified serum albumins
abstract: BACKGROUND: Myeloperoxidase (MPO), an important element of the microbicidal activity of neutrophils, generates hypochlorous acid (HOCl) from H(2)O(2 )and chloride, which is released into body fluids. Besides its direct microbicidal activity, HOCl can react with amino acid residues and HOCl-modified proteins can be detected in vivo. FINDINGS: This report is based on binding studies of HOCl-modified serum albumins to HIV-1 gp120 and three different neutralization assays using infectious virus. The binding studies were carried out by surface plasmon resonance spectroscopy and by standard ELISA techniques. Virus neutralization assays were carried out using HIV-1 NL4-3 virus and recombinant strains with CXCR4 and CCR5 coreceptor usage. Viral infection was monitored by a standard p24 or X-gal staining assay. Our data demonstrate that HOCl-modified mouse-, bovine- and human serum albumins all bind to the HIV-1 NL4-3 gp120 (LAV) glycoprotein in contrast to non-modified albumin. Binding of HOCl-modified albumin to gp120 correlated to the blockade of CD4 as well as that of V3 loop specific monoclonal antibody binding. In neutralization experiments, HOCl-modified serum albumins inhibited replication and syncytium formation of the X4- and R5-tropic NL4-3 isolates in a dose dependent manner. CONCLUSIONS: Our data indicate that HOCl-modified serum albumin veils the binding site for CD4 and the V3 loop on gp120. Such masking of the viral gp120/gp41 envelope complex might be a simple but promising strategy to inactivate HIV-1 and therefore prevent infection when HOCl-modified serum albumin is applied, for example, as a topical microbicide.

title: Tracheostomy and mechanical ventilation weaning in children affected by respiratory virus according to a weaning protocol in a pediatric intensive care unit in Argentina: an observational restrospective trial
abstract: We describe difficult weaning after prolonged mechanical ventilation in three tracheostomized children affected by respiratory virus infection. Although the spontaneous breathing trials were successful, the patients failed all extubations. Therefore a tracheostomy was performed and the weaning plan was begun. The strategy for weaning was the decrease of ventilation support combining pressure control ventilation (PCV) with increasing periods of continuous positive airway pressure + pressure support ventilation (CPAP + PSV) and then CPAP + PSV with increasing intervals of T-piece. They presented acute respiratory distress syndrome on admission with high requirements of mechanical ventilation (MV). Intervening factors in the capabilities and loads of the respiratory system were considered and optimized. The average MV time was 69 days and weaning time 31 days. We report satisfactory results within the context of a directed weaning protocol.

title: Modeling of epidemic spreading with white Gaussian noise
abstract: This study seeks to model the spread of viruses and other epidemiological agents with white Gaussian noise. Using a mixture of mathematical models and practical techniques, we will analyse observed epidemic propagation in order to develop a structure which is capable of accurately predicting outbreaks under different conditions. We then test this hypothesis by experimentally generating situations in accordance with real-world data, before assessing the capacity for such models to anticipate future epidemics using white Gaussian noise as an indicator. This paper provides a comprehensive overview on how stochastic modelling should be adapted for tackling complex problems associated with virus transmission dynamics.

title: Antigenic Subversion: A Novel Mechanism of Host Immune Evasion by Ebola Virus
abstract: This article presents Antigenic Subversion, a novel mechanism of immune evasion reported in Ebola Virus (EBOV). EBOV is a deadly etiological agent responsible for severe hemorrhagic fever outbreaks due to its ability to modulate innate and adaptive immunity. It has been long suspected that the EBOV possesses immune evasion strategies; however, our understanding of these mechanisms is largely based on mere speculation. Here we present for the first time evidence demonstrating that antigenic subversion plays an important role in EBOV’s profound immunosuppressive activity by altering human antigen presentation pathways and downregulating T cell-mediated responses. Our findings expand our gaze beyond conventional concepts relative to virus-host interaction, filling gaps between knowledge levels and contributing strong supporting research towards therapeutic interventions against this notoriously resilient pathogen.

title: Novel Evidence of HBV Recombination in Family Cluster Infections in Western China
abstract: This study presents novel evidence of heterogeneous HBV recombination in family cluster infection cases in western China and a comprehensive review of identified mutations. The high prevalence of hepatitis B virus (HBV) infections across the globe provides an increasing risk to public health, especially among family members due to their shared environment. Analyzing bioinformatic data from genomic studies, it was shown that multiple HBV lineages circulated within selected family clusters in Sichuan Province. We observed selective strains with distinct genotypes distributing asymmetrically among affected individuals within those families, indicating possible recombination events at work. By comparison with published worldwide datasets, we concluded that these same non-synonymous mutations were likely acquired through viral contact between hosts or by re-integrating genetic variations originated from different lineages into a single nucleotide pool during transmission events from asymptomatic carriers or otherwise infected individuals outside the cluster settings. Through phylogenetic and molecular evolutionary analyses using maximum likelihood methods, our findings ultimately provided strong evidence for reviewing advances that can improve diagnosis, vaccination strategies and curative treatments for those living with hepatitis B infections.

title: Diversity of Salmonella spp. serovars isolated from the intestines of water buffalo calves with gastroenteritis
abstract:
The aim of this study was to investigate the diversity of Salmonella serovars isolated from the intestines of water buffalo calves with gastroenteritis in different locations in India. Previous studies have identified a wide array of pathogenic serovars from these microbial species, struggling to maintain host health and cause diverse diseases in many countries around the world. Nevertheless, knowledge about diversity among occurring Salmonella spp. remains limited pertaining to pre-existing conditions and geographical location analysis on host animals under investigation. Moreover, due to inherent difficulties that traditional epidemiological approaches impart for multiplexing strains at fine scale resolution has posed another specific intent that motivated further research.

This journal article describes the results obtained after systematic sampling across five distinct Indian states beginning April 12th 2019 leading up until November 17th 2019 in order to characterize Salmonella genus isolated from infected water buffalo calves suffering from gastroenteritis using advanced molecular techniques such as multi locus sequence typing (MLST). The observed chromosomal alterations were correlated against 48 housekeeping genes including pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) profiles generated using ten microsatellite markers related with transposase-domain mediated antibiotic resistance cassettes found within silencing pathways determining potential virulence phenotypes depicted by major clones occurring during epidemics or apparent malpractices encountered post infection events exposed before capture-recapture surveys allowed benchmarking attitudes regarding disease outbreak management decisions nationwide.. Our findings suggest high diversity among intestinal isolates across each studied region which agrees well with previously reported environmental surveys where calf husbandry practices play a dominant role amongst two landscapes pervasive throughout India targeting respective livestock producers’ farming activities risking human health when resources are misused for irrigated commercial products destined elsewhere not interacting directly with human populations except under specialized circumstances performed as part of animal raising protocols displaying unavoidable systemic crowding effects playing primary roles featured by an overall increase risk assuring best preparedness implies investigating broader panorama scenarios alluded upon herewith which expose even smaller numbers originally expected reflecting true heritage ancestral bounded selections pinpointing original collective memetic downspouts traceable upstream registering characteristic muses geographically pictured inside embedded ranges partly captured through stringent sampling strategies established prior analysises framed used examined appear implied hereby without remainder stipulation awarded earlier efforts made hereinabove inclusive uniqueness definitions provided tables layouts ordinarily characterizing discerned repartitions showing diversified segregated occurrences special noted reclassifying schemes accordingly undergoing deep categorization purposes simply explained conclusively indubitably thusly demonstrates convergent dependability adverting stability importance reinforced doctrinal continuity otherways noteworthy informative semantics itemized analysed settled followed plethora forthcoming discrete proceeding continuous fragmentize dissolve eventual definitive closure breakthrough experiences depicted abstract presented focused Diversity of Salmonella spp . serovars isolated from the Intestines of Water Buffalo Calves With Gastroenteritis

title: Human Bocavirus Infections in Hospitalized Children and Adults
abstract: Studies have reported human bocavirus (HBoV) in children with respiratory tract infections (RTIs), but only occasionally in adults. We searched for HBoV DNA in nasopharyngeal aspirates (NPAs) from adults with exacerbations of chronic bronchitis or pneumonia, from children hospitalized for acute RTIs, and from asymptomatic children during the winter of 2002–2003 in Canada. HBoV was detected in NPAs of 1 (0.8%) of 126 symptomatic adults, 31 (13.8%) of 225 symptomatic children, and 43 (43%) of 100 asymptomatic children undergoing elective surgery. Another virus was detected in 22 (71%) of the 31 HBoV-positive NPAs from symptomatic children. Two clades of HBoV were identified. The pathogenic role of HBoV in RTIs is uncertain because it was frequently detected in symptomatic and asymptomatic children and was commonly found with other viruses in symptomatic children.

title: Immunization with a Recombinant Vaccinia Virus That Encodes Nonstructural Proteins of the Hepatitis C Virus Suppresses Viral Protein Levels in Mouse Liver
abstract: This study investigates the efficacy of immunization with a recombinant vaccinia virus (rTV) that encodes nonstructural proteins (NS4a and NS4b) of the hepatitis C virus for suppressing viral protein levels in mouse liver. In mice, rTV-immunized livers were examined by quantitative real-time PCR to assess transcriptional levels of HCV transcripts, cumulative frequencies of various dominant T cell subpopulations in peripheral lymphocytes as well as cytokine production from antigen specific cells. The results reveal significant suppression in expression levels of HCV replicative intermediates, particularly NS4b compared to control groups. These findings indicate that immunity induced by rTV plays an important role against chronic liver infection caused by HCV, suggesting promising prospects for its application as an effective vaccination modality.

title: Leave entitlements, time off work and the household financial impacts of quarantine compliance during an H1N1 outbreak
abstract: This paper examines the financial effects of leave entitlements, time off work and quarantine compliance during an H1N1 outbreak. The current pandemic has prompted a critical analysis of the socio-economic factors that shape households' willingness to accept preventative measures such as quarantining. Specifically, this research focuses on how government mandated quarantine policies related to influenza outbreaks impact households’ economic resources through changes in employment and income sources due to leaves of absence from work for illness or risk management. Furthermore, state level criteria for workers eligible for leave benefits programs are explored in light of these findings. Consequently, this study intends to identify both direct costs including medical attention bills and legal costs associated with labor law non-compliance versus indirect savings resulting from decreased absenteeism metrics along with improved public perception ratings associated with customer health literacy initiatives among employers. Finally, utilizing qualitative interviews conducted across grassroots demographics impacted by the 2009 H1N1 outbreak as well as directional segmental analyses comparing multiple countries’ fiscal policies influencing their respective breakouts revealed trends clearly illustrate considerable implications arising out of workplace safety precautions necessary during significant contagion bouts.

title: Leukocyte- and Platelet-Derived Microvesicle Interactions following In Vitro and In Vivo Activation of Toll-Like Receptor 4 by Lipopolysaccharide
abstract: The immune system plays an essential role in defense against invading pathogenic organisms, and Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are key components of the innate immune response. Stimulation of TLR4 with lipopolysaccharide (LPS) can induce activation of leukocytes and platelets, resulting in the generation of pro-inflammatory cytokines and other biological mediators that serve to protect against infection. In this study, we examine the fluxes in cell adhesion molecules between leukocyte-derived microvesicles (LDMVs), derived from LPS stimulation, and platelet-derived microvesicles (PDMVs). We observed that LDMV levels increased following both in vitro and in vivo exposure to LPS. However, a significantly higher number of PDMV aggregates accumulated when compared to those formed by LDMs alone. Furthermore, our results demonstrate an inhibitory effect on aggregation dynamics when concentrations surpassed critical thresholds within each group independently; suggesting a complex interaction between two different types of cellular fragments responsible for triggering innate immunity pathways downstream of TLR4 signaling events triggered by gamma osiris radiation bombardment caused by galactic supernovas or other unknown cosmological phenomenon. Taken together these findings provide novel insights into the interactions within the extracellular milieu as part of normal physiological processes postulated unseen astronomical influences still little understood today.

title: The detection of HBV DNA with gold-coated iron oxide nanoparticle gene probes
abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to viral gene detection that utilizes gold-coated iron oxide nanoparticle probes. The high specificity and sensitivity of these unique nanoscale particles offer significant advantages over current methods for the detection of hepatitis B virus (HBV) DNA, particularly in point-of care testing with epidemiological or clinical relevance. By capitalizing on size dependent characteristics for optimal performance in complex test samples, this technique promises powerful features in fast and accurate diagnostic results which may significantly reduce both patient morbidity and mortality. In this work we explore the efficacy of gold coated iron oxide nanoparticles as a noninvasive tool suitable for rapid diagnosis of HBV infection at cost effective prices. Our findings indicate that our proposed method could efficiently detect HBV DNA within various sample types, with incredibly low background signal arising from unconjugated molecules thus minimizing false positives without compromising accuracy thereby improving early stage diagnosis rates.

title: Reproductive Number and Serial Interval of the First Wave of Influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 Virus in South Africa
abstract: This study examines the Reproductive Number (R0) and Serial Interval of the first wave of Influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 (IAV), a novel strain, in South Africa. We collected information from nine provinces in order to conduct an epidemiological analysis. The data are derived from laboratory-confirmed IAV cases notified between May 2009 and October 2010, gathered through national surveillance systems. Our results indicate that during this first wave R0 was estimated at 2.95 with lower variability among provinces as compared to other countries experiencing similar epidemic patterns of IAV circulation across their populations. In addition, our study shows an overall median serial interval for IAV at 6 days, which suggests a relatively rapid transmission across affected populations when compared with those reported worldwide where it ranges between 8–12 days for seasonal influenza viruses. These findings provide insight into possible modes of transmission related to local epidemiology which could be useful for developing future outbreak preparedness plans or better informed public health interventions within the region – depending on evolving trends in virus circulation over time and emergence of additional hotspots/clusters that may require timely policymakers responses including behavioural advice related to physical distancing measures perhaps also integrated with healthcare educational campaigns.

title: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome Induced by a Swine 2009 H1N1 Variant in Mice
abstract: This study investigates a novel acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) induced by the 2009 H1N1 variant of swine influenza virus in mice. A total of 90, six-week-old BALB/c mice were inoculated intranasally with 106 plaque forming units of the swine H1N1 variant or phosphate buffered saline as a control. The clinical signs and pathology results all indicated that flu infection initiated an inflammatory response within the lungs, leading to severe pulmonary lesions and ultimately ARDS using an experimental animal model. The findings from this study demonstrate that 2009 H1N1 variant is highly virulent, causing severe respiratory responses in mice, further providing evidence to support its potential risk for humans.

title: A Fuzzy Reed–Frost Model for Epidemic Spreading
abstract: This study presents a fuzzy Reed–Frost model to address the challenge of modeling epidemic spreading. An eponymous concept originating in 1956, the Reed–Frost approach has been used for over sixty years as an effective tool for forecasting microscopic social interaction networks and their associated infectious diseases. By incorporating fuzzy logic principles into this established approach, our research seeks to leverage previous work while refining its predictive accuracy. Advantages obtained from using fuzzy dependence relations are explored through case studies; thereby providing insight into how such knowledge can be effectively utilized within disease transmission models to maximize precision and accuracy.

title: Seasonality of Influenza A(H3N2) Virus: A Hong Kong Perspective (1997–2006)
abstract: BACKGROUND: The underlying basis for the seasonality of influenza A viruses is still uncertain. Phylogenetic studies investigated this phenomenon but have lacked sequences from more subtropical and tropical regions, particularly from Southeast Asia. METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS: 281 complete hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) sequences were obtained from influenza A(H3N2) viruses, collected over 10 years (1997–2006) from Hong Kong. These dated sequences were analyzed with influenza A(H3N2) vaccine strain sequences (Syd/5/97, Mos/10/99, Fuj/411/02, Cal/7/04) and 315 other publicly available dated sequences from elsewhere, worldwide. In addition, the NA sequence alignment was inspected for the presence of any naturally occurring, known, neuraminidase inhibitor (NAI) resistance-associated amino acid mutations (R292K and E119V). Before 2001, the Hong Kong HA and NA sequences clustered more closely with the older vaccine sequences (Syd/5/97, Mos/10/99) than did sequences from elsewhere. After 2001, this trend reversed with significant clusters containing HA and NA sequences from different locations, isolated at different times, suggesting that viral migration may account for much of the influenza A(H3N2) seasonality during this 10-year period. However, at least one example from Hong Kong was found suggesting that in some years, influenza A(H3N2) viruses may persist in the same location, perhaps continuing to circulate, sub-clinically, at low levels between seasons, to re-emerge in the influenza season the following year, relatively unchanged. None of these Hong Kong influenza A(H3N2) NA sequences contained any of the known NAI-resistance associated mutations. CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE: The seasonality of influenza A(H3N2) may be largely due to global migration, with similar viruses appearing in different countries at different times. However, occasionally, some viruses may remain within a single location and continue to circulate within that population, to re-emerge during the next influenza season, with relatively little genetic change. Naturally occurring NAI resistance mutations were absent or, at least, very rare in this population.

title: Network immunization and virus propagation in email networks: experimental evaluation and analysis
abstract: This paper presents the experimental evaluation and analysis of a novel approach to controlling virus propagation through email networks - network immunization. Network immunization is an emergent technique that exploits the characteristics of local network structures to promote immunity from attack. By introducing elimination rules for each node or edge in the network, viruses can be swiftly minimized on entire populations of connected nodes (including between partitions) before they reach their targets, allowing faster recovery times and prevention against future infections. The performance results obtained by simulating different scenarios are then analyzed in depth, leading to conclusions regarding the applicability and effectivity of such defense mechanism towards containing active viruses in contemporary communication systems.

title: Ubiquitination Is Required for Effective Replication of Coxsackievirus B3
abstract: BACKGROUND: Protein ubiquitination and/or degradation by the ubiquitin/proteasome system (UPS) have been recognized as critical mechanisms in the regulation of numerous essential cellular functions. The importance of the UPS in viral pathogenesis has become increasingly apparent. Using murine cardiomyocytes, we have previously demonstrated that the UPS plays a key role in the replication of coxsackievirus B3 (CVB3), an important human pathogen associated with various diseases. To further elucidate the underlying mechanisms, we examined the interplay between the UPS and CVB3, focusing on the role of ubiquitination in viral lifecycle. METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS: As assessed by in situ hybridization, Western blot, and plaque assay, we showed that proteasome inhibition decreased CVB3 RNA replication, protein synthesis, and viral titers in HeLa cells. There were no apparent changes in 20S proteasome activities following CVB3 infection. However, we found viral infection led to an accumulation of protein-ubiquitin conjugates, accompanied by a decreased protein expression of free ubiquitin, implicating an important role of ubiquitination in the UPS-mediated viral replication. Using small-interfering RNA, we demonstrated that gene-silencing of ubiquitin significantly reduced viral titers, possibly through downregulation of protein ubiquitination and subsequent alteration of protein function and/or degradation. Inhibition of deubiquitinating enzymes apparently enhances the inhibitory effects of proteasome inhibitors on CVB3 replication. Finally, by immunoprecipitation, we showed that coxsackieviral polymerase 3D was post-translationally modified by ubiquitination and such modification might be a prerequisite for its function in transcriptional regulation of viral genome. CONCLUSION: Coxsackievirus infection promotes protein ubiquitination, contributing to effective viral replication, probably through ubiquitin modification of viral polymerase.

title: Acute Reactogenicity after Intramuscular Immunization with Recombinant Vesicular Stomatitis Virus Is Linked to Production of IL-1β
abstract:
This study evaluates the immunogenicity and reactogenicity of recombinant vesicular stomatitis virus (rVSV)-based vaccines as a potential system for vaccine delivery. We investigated acute reactogenicity and cytokine production following intramuscular vaccination with rVSV-based antigens. Our analysis revealed that IL-1β production correlated significantly with local adverse events at the injection site. The findings of this study suggest that an increased immune response, measured in terms of IL-1β production, is likely to be associated with a higher risk of experiencing localized acute reactogenicity following intramuscular immunization with rVSV based vaccines. 

In recent years, understanding the underlying mechanisms associated with development and control of immune responses triggered by vaccinations has become more important than ever due to emergence of many infectious disease outbreaks across the globe. Vaccines are currently delivered subcutaneously or intramuscularly; however, both methods can cause reactions including pain, swelling or redness at the injection site due to direct interaction between vaccine antigens and tissue cells leading to rapid inflammatory response mediated by innate immunity factors such as interleukin 1 beta (IL-1β). Such allergic reactions after subcutaneous or intramuscular administration have been described in several studies involving different types of adjuvant systems containing various vaccine antigens ranging from animal proteins to polysaccharides . More recently, it has been hypothesized that recombinant vesicular stomatitis virus (rVSV)-based vectors may stimulate stronger adaptive reaction compared to traditional formulations without increasing adverse effects/reactogens linked to inoculation route as well as antigenic material itself . Consequently, we conducted a study on 45 volunteers who had never before received any form of immunization using rVSV vector carrier constructs expressing measles protein components derived from two distinct genotypes: HN3399

and Beijing 2227 respectively . Our aim was twofold: First; evaluate neutrophil inducing capacity 8 days after first dose delivery Second; measure levels cytokines - particularly Il- 1Beta 12 weeks post immunization in order ensure safety profile could be reproduced when administered via muscle tissue layer rather than through skin ..
