title: Ebola and Localized Blame on Social Media: Analysis of Twitter and Facebook Conversations During the 2014–2015 Ebola Epidemic
abstract: This paper examines the interactions between social media conversations related to the 2014-2015 outbreak of Ebola in West Africa and how these platforms can shape discourse on localized blame. Through an analysis of a combined dataset of 54 million tweets and 462,000 Facebook posts related to the epidemic, this article investigates patterns within these conversations through sentiment analysis. Additionally, this study considers various socio-cultural attributes to offer contextual insights into how different demographic groups discuss topics around Ebola and its causes. Drawing from this data, we present evidence that suggests there is a trend towards personalized accusation on both Twitter and Facebook during significant outbreaks such as Ebola. Ultimately, it is hoped that this research will help provide further understanding into perceptions surrounding disease causation as well as potential strategies for crisis preparedness in years ahead.

title: Non-HIV Pneumocystis pneumonia: do conventional community-acquired pneumonia guidelines under estimate its severity?
abstract: This paper analyses the empirical evidence of 'Non-HIV Pneumocystis pneumonia' (NHP) and its clinical implications within community-acquired pneumonia guidelines. NHP is a rare fungal infection caused by colonization of the organism Pneumocystis jirovecii, which has become increasingly common in patients who do not have HIV over recent decades. It often presents with severe respiratory symptoms similar to those associated with bacterial infections; however, it can lead to higher morbidity and mortality than many more commonly acquired pneumonias if not correctly identified or treated promptly. This study explores whether current conventional protocols fail to account for this unusual pathogen adequately, potentially leading clinicians to underestimate the severity of NHP cases in their management approaches. The aim of this research therefore is to shed light on any potential deficits in clinical guidance available for non-HIV related pneumocystic pathogens that should be addressed or further considerated in future reviews..

title: An evaluation of Comparative Genome Sequencing (CGS) by comparing two previously-sequenced bacterial genomes
abstract: BACKGROUND: With the development of new technology, it has recently become practical to resequence the genome of a bacterium after experimental manipulation. It is critical though to know the accuracy of the technique used, and to establish confidence that all of the mutations were detected. RESULTS: In order to evaluate the accuracy of genome resequencing using the microarray-based Comparative Genome Sequencing service provided by Nimblegen Systems Inc., we resequenced the E. coli strain W3110 Kohara using MG1655 as a reference, both of which have been completely sequenced using traditional sequencing methods. CGS detected 7 of 8 small sequence differences, one large deletion, and 9 of 12 IS element insertions present in W3110, but did not detect a large chromosomal inversion. In addition, we confirmed that CGS also detected 2 SNPs, one deletion and 7 IS element insertions that are not present in the genome sequence, which we attribute to changes that occurred after the creation of the W3110 lambda clone library. The false positive rate for SNPs was one per 244 Kb of genome sequence. CONCLUSION: CGS is an effective way to detect multiple mutations present in one bacterium relative to another, and while highly cost-effective, is prone to certain errors. Mutations occurring in repeated sequences or in sequences with a high degree of secondary structure may go undetected. It is also critical to follow up on regions of interest in which SNPs were not called because they often indicate deletions or IS element insertions.

title: Increased expression levels of the pvcrt-o and pvmdr1 genes in a patient with severe Plasmodium vivax malaria
abstract: BACKGROUND: There are increasing reports of severe clinical cases exclusively associated with Plasmodium vivax infections. Notably, this severity has been recently suggested to be associated with chloroquine resistance. PATIENTS: Two different patients presented at the Hospital Clinic in Barcelona with P. vivax malaria episodes. One patient had severe symptoms and the other mild symptoms. Both patients traveled through the Brazilian Amazon (Manaus) in 2007. For both patients the current diagnosis of malaria was the first. Two other patients with mild symptoms presented to the "Centro de Pesquisa em Medicina Tropical", also in the Brazilian Amazon (Rondônia) in 2000. METHODS: To exclude the possibility that the patient's severe symptoms were due to Plasmodium falciparum, a nested PCR was performed. A magnetic method was used to purify P. vivax free of human leukocytes. Quantitative real-time PCR was performed to compare the transcript levels of two main transporters likely to be involved in chloroquine resistance in P. vivax, namely the P. vivax chloroquine resistance transporter, pvcrt-o, and the P. vivax multidrug resistance transporter, pvmdr 1. RESULTS: Results demonstrated that the severe clinical symptoms were exclusively due to P. vivax. The patient presented acute respiratory conditions requiring admission to the intensive care unit. The magnetic method showed highly purified infected-reticulocytes with mature stages. In addition, it was found that parasites obtained from the severe patient had up to 2.9-fold increase in pvmdr1 levels and up to 21.9-fold increase in pvcrt-o levels compared to expression levels of parasites from the other patients with mild symptoms. CONCLUSION: This is the first clinical case of severe disease exclusively associated with vivax malaria in Spain. Moreover, these findings suggest that clinical severity could be associated with increased expression levels of parasite genes likely involved in chloroquine resistance. It is necessary to further explore the potential of pvmdr1 and particularly pvcrt-o expression levels as molecular markers of severe disease in P. vivax.

title: DC-SIGN (CD209) Promoter −336 A/G (rs4804803) Polymorphism Associated with Susceptibility of Kawasaki Disease
abstract:
This study looked at the DC-SIGN (CD209) promoter −336 A/G polymorphism and its effect on the susceptibility of Kawasaki Disease. To investigate this hypothesis, a case–control study was conducted consisting of 191 Kawasaki Disease patients and 192 healthy subjects in South Korea population. Genotyping methods of polymerase chain reaction-restriction fragment length polymorphism (PCR-RFLP) were used to analyze the presence or absence of DC-SIGN (CD209) promoter −336 A/G allele in both groups’ DNA samples. Statistical results indicate that compared with wildtype G allele carriers, AG+GG variant genotypes are associated with increased risk for development GD Incidence [odds ratio (OR)=2.117; 95% confidence interval (CI): 1.376–3.266; P=0). Our results suggest that heterozygous and homozygous mutation confer an increase risk for KD among South Korean populations which may imply a significant role of environmental factor failure by DC-SIGN (CD209) Promoter −336 A/G Polymorphism Associated with Susceptibility of Kawasaki Disease

title: Experimental infection of H5N1 HPAI in BALB/c mice
abstract: BACKGROUND: In 2005 huge epizooty of H5N1 HPAI occurred in Russia. It had been clear that territory of Russia becoming endemic for H5N1 HPAI. In 2006 several outbreaks have occurred. To develop new vaccines and antiviral therapies, animal models had to be investigated. We choose highly pathogenic strain for these studies. RESULTS: A/duck/Tuva/01/06 belongs to Quinghai-like group viruses. Molecular markers – cleavage site, K627 in PB2 characterize this virus as highly pathogenic. This data was confirmed by direct pathogenic tests: IVPI = 3.0, MLD(50 )= 1,4Log10EID(50). Also molecular analysis showed sensivity of the virus to adamantanes and neuraminidase inhibitors. Serological analysis showed wide cross-reactivity of this virus with sera produced to H5N1 HPAI viruses isolated earlier in South-East Asia. Mean time to death of infected animals was 8,19+/-0,18 days. First time acute delayed hemorrhagic syndrome was observed in mice lethal model. Hypercytokinemia was determined by elevated sera levels of IFN-gamma, IL-6, IL-10. CONCLUSION: Assuming all obtained data we can conclude that basic model parameters were characterized and virus A/duck/Tuva/01/06 can be used to evaluate anti-influenza vaccines and therapeutics.

title: Nodeomics: Pathogen Detection in Vertebrate Lymph Nodes Using Meta-Transcriptomics
abstract: The ongoing emergence of human infections originating from wildlife highlights the need for better knowledge of the microbial community in wildlife species where traditional diagnostic approaches are limited. Here we evaluate the microbial biota in healthy mule deer (Odocoileus hemionus) by analyses of lymph node meta-transcriptomes. cDNA libraries from five individuals and two pools of samples were prepared from retropharyngeal lymph node RNA enriched for polyadenylated RNA and sequenced using Roche-454 Life Sciences technology. Protein-coding and 16S ribosomal RNA (rRNA) sequences were taxonomically profiled using protein and rRNA specific databases. Representatives of all bacterial phyla were detected in the seven libraries based on protein-coding transcripts indicating that viable microbiota were present in lymph nodes. Residents of skin and rumen, and those ubiquitous in mule deer habitat dominated classifiable bacterial species. Based on detection of both rRNA and protein-coding transcripts, we identified two new proteobacterial species; a Helicobacter closely related to Helicobacter cetorum in the Helicobacter pylori/Helicobacter acinonychis complex and an Acinetobacter related to Acinetobacter schindleri. Among viruses, a novel gamma retrovirus and other members of the Poxviridae and Retroviridae were identified. We additionally evaluated bacterial diversity by amplicon sequencing the hypervariable V6 region of 16S rRNA and demonstrate that overall taxonomic diversity is higher with the meta-transcriptomic approach. These data provide the most complete picture to date of the microbial diversity within a wildlife host. Our research advances the use of meta-transcriptomics to study microbiota in wildlife tissues, which will facilitate detection of novel organisms with pathogenic potential to human and animals.

title: Human Anti-Plague Monoclonal Antibodies Protect Mice from Yersinia pestis in a Bubonic Plague Model
abstract: Yersinia pestis is the etiologic agent of plague that has killed more than 200 million people throughout the recorded history of mankind. Antibiotics may provide little immediate relief to patients who have a high bacteremia or to patients infected with an antibiotic resistant strain of plague. Two virulent factors of Y. pestis are the capsid F1 protein and the low-calcium response (Lcr) V-protein or V-antigen that have been proven to be the targets for both active and passive immunization. There are mouse monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) against the F1- and V-antigens that can passively protect mice in a murine model of plague; however, there are no anti-Yersinia pestis monoclonal antibodies available for prophylactic or therapeutic treatment in humans. We identified one anti-F1-specific human mAb (m252) and two anti-V-specific human mAb (m253, m254) by panning a naïve phage-displayed Fab library against the F1- and V-antigens. The Fabs were converted to IgG1s and their binding and protective activities were evaluated. M252 bound weakly to peptides located at the F1 N-terminus where a protective mouse anti-F1 mAb also binds. M253 bound strongly to a V-antigen peptide indicating a linear epitope; m254 did not bind to any peptide from a panel of 53 peptides suggesting that its epitope may be conformational. M252 showed better protection than m253 and m254 against a Y, pestis challenge in a plague mouse model. A synergistic effect was observed when the three antibodies were combined. Incomplete to complete protection was achieved when m252 was given at different times post-challenge. These antibodies can be further studied to determine their potential as therapeutics or prophylactics in Y. pestis infection in humans.

title: Symptomatic Venous Thromboembolism Is a Disease Related to Infection and Immune Dysfunction
abstract: This paper focuses on symptomatic venous thromboembolism (VTE) as a disease related to infection and immune dysfunction. It aims to better understand the etiology of VTE by examining its prevalence among two patient groups, those with an infectious disease or without any underlying inflammatory condition, and then discussing the potential mechanisms involving both infections and immune dysregulation in the development of this disorder. This research will employ various means of data analysis including descriptive epidemiological studies, laboratory tests, and detailed case studies. The findings may provide important new insight into the pathogenesis of VTE that could lead to improved clinical management strategies for patients suffering from this complex disorder.

title: Deconstructing host-pathogen interactions in Drosophila
abstract: This study investigates the Drosophila host-pathogen interactions to gain a greater understanding of these complex relationships. A range of approaches will be employed to assess differences between species and within families, including genome sequencing and gene expression analysis using advanced molecular techniques. Through further research into how different organisms interact with one another, this work can inform on critical disease control strategies in humans. With an interdisciplinary approach, it is hoped that outcomes from this study could have implications beyond just the fundamental genomic understanding provided. By breaking down traditional boundaries between disciplines such as genetics, epidemiology, evolutionary biology and immunology in order to better understand these dynamics, important insights into future therapies can be gained. Therefore we aim to deconstruct host-pathogen interactions in Drosophila in order to progress our exploration of the mechanisms behind human health issues caused by pathogens.

title: Functional Analysis of Rift Valley Fever Virus NSs Encoding a Partial Truncation
abstract: This article presents a functional analysis of the gene encoding a partial truncation (NSs) of the Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV). The study was conducted in order to understand how RVFV causes disease and infection, as well as how aberrant NSs expression can affect viral growth and pathogenicity. In addition, we sought to identify possible targets for therapeutic interventions that could ameliorate the effects of this poor prognosis disease associated with an emerging infectious agent. Through molecular characterization of RVFV genomes from infected cells, our findings provide evidence for distinct changes in NSs protein structure linked to replication defectiveness and decreased ablation potential. Our data suggest that alterations at the nucleotide level led to reduced transcriptional levels resulting in diminished replicative fitness gains by assembled particles being released from transfected stationery cultures. Thus, it is likely that subtleties mediate specific mechanisms relevant to functionality of trimmed proteins impact overall survival characteristic like pathogenesis patterns observed for RVF strains identified worldwide. This research will provide insights into manipulating virological pathways during development or outbreak scenario compromising patient care initiatives attempting prevention strategies against title: Transcriptomics of In Vitro Immune-Stimulated Hemocytes from the Manila Clam Ruditapes philippinarum Using High-Throughput Sequencing
abstract: This study presents a detailed analysis of the transcriptome in immune-stimulated hemocytes from Ruditapes philippinarum (Manila clam) using high-throughput sequencing. The species R. philippinarum is an ecologically and economically important marine bivalve mollusk found throughout Southeast Asia and numerous other regions worldwide, making it a valuable model organism for understanding the effects of environmental changes on immunological responses within aquatic systems. To investigate the molecular mechanisms implicated in immune functioning, total RNA was isolated from clams subjected to specific immune challenges prior to being sequenced using Illumina HiSeq 4000 technology. Differential expression analyses were then assessed to identify genes responding to challenged stimuli including molecules associated with innate immunity pathways such as prophenoloxidases, signaling cascades related to proinflammatory cytokines, and mucin-associated proteins involved in recognition processes across multiple tissues. Furthermore, functional annotation of gene expression patterns enabled classification among diverse categories according to major involvement during response activation events under different cellular compartments or developmentally driven processes. Overall results revealed clear distinctions among all treatment classes that best represent several crucial aspects of adaptive mechanisms following natural exposures associated with diseases or wounds. The current findings provide further insights into interplay between temporal dynamics governing systemic transcriptional rearrangements followed by response modulation upon natural injury incidents title: Clinical review: Update of avian influenza A infections in humans
abstract: Influenza A viruses have a wide host range for infection, from wild waterfowl to poultry to humans. Recently, the cross-species transmission of avian influenza A, particularly subtype H5N1, has highlighted the importance of the non-human subtypes and their incidence in the human population has increased over the past decade. During cross-species transmission, human disease can range from the asymptomatic to mild conjunctivitis to fulminant pneumonia and death. With these cases, however, the risk for genetic change and development of a novel virus increases, heightening the need for public health and hospital measures. This review discusses the epidemiology, host range, human disease, outcome, treatment, and prevention of cross-transmission of avian influenza A into humans.

title: Reliability of case definitions for public health surveillance assessed by Round-Robin test methodology
abstract: BACKGROUND: Case definitions have been recognized to be important elements of public health surveillance systems. They are to assure comparability and consistency of surveillance data and have crucial impact on the sensitivity and the positive predictive value of a surveillance system. The reliability of case definitions has rarely been investigated systematically. METHODS: We conducted a Round-Robin test by asking all 425 local health departments (LHD) and the 16 state health departments (SHD) in Germany to classify a selection of 68 case examples using case definitions. By multivariate analysis we investigated factors linked to classification agreement with a gold standard, which was defined by an expert panel. RESULTS: A total of 7870 classifications were done by 396 LHD (93%) and all SHD. Reporting sensitivity was 90.0%, positive predictive value 76.6%. Polio case examples had the lowest reporting precision, salmonellosis case examples the highest (OR = 0.008; CI: 0.005–0.013). Case definitions with a check-list format of clinical criteria resulted in higher reporting precision than case definitions with a narrative description (OR = 3.08; CI: 2.47–3.83). Reporting precision was higher among SHD compared to LHD (OR = 1.52; CI: 1.14–2.02). CONCLUSION: Our findings led to a systematic revision of the German case definitions and build the basis for general recommendations for the creation of case definitions. These include, among others, that testable yes/no criteria in a check-list format is likely to improve reliability, and that software used for data transmission should be designed in strict accordance with the case definitions. The findings of this study are largely applicable to case definitions in many other countries or international networks as they share the same structural and editorial characteristics of the case definitions evaluated in this study before their revision.

title: No Longer an Innocent Bystander: Epithelial Toll-Like Receptor Signaling in the Development of Mucosal Inflammation
abstract: Diseases of mucosal inflammation represent important causes of morbidity and mortality, and have led to intense research efforts to understand the factors that lead to their development. It is well accepted that a breakdown of the normally impermeant epithelial barrier of the intestine, the lung, and the kidney is associated with the development of inflammatory disease in these organs, yet significant controversy exists as to how this breakdown actually occurs, and how such a breakdown may lead to inflammation. In this regard, much work has focused upon the role of the epithelium as an “innocent bystander,” a target of a leukocyte-mediated inflammatory cascade that leads to its destruction in the mucosal inflammatory process. However, recent evidence from a variety of laboratories indicates that the epithelium is not merely a passive component in the steps that lead to mucosal inflammation, but is a central participant in the process. In addressing this controversy, we and others have determined that epithelial cells express Toll-like receptors (TLRs) of the innate immune system, and that activation of TLRs by endogenous and exogenous ligands may play a central role in determining the balance between a state of “mucosal homeostasis,” as is required for optimal organ function, and “mucosal injury,” leading to mucosal inflammation and barrier breakdown. In particular, activation of TLRs within intestinal epithelial cells leads to the development of cellular injury and impairment in mucosal repair in the pathogenesis of intestinal inflammation, while activation of TLRs in the lung and kidney may participate in the development of pneumonitis and nephritis respectively. Recent work in support of these concepts is extensively reviewed, while essential areas of further study that are required to determine the significance of epithelial TLR signaling during states of health and disease are outlined.

title: The role of infections in the pathogenesis and course of multiple sclerosis
abstract: Interplay between susceptibility genes and environmental factors is considered important player in the genesis of multiple sclerosis (MS). Among environmental factors, a role for an infectious pathogen has long been considered central to the disease process. This opinion has support both from epidemiological data and the findings of immunological abnormalities in spinal fluid that reflect an immune response to an as yet undetermined antigen, possibly a pathogen, in the cerebrospinal fluid. Our review will outline the current understanding of the role of infection in the causation and progression of MS. We will review the data that point to an infectious cause of MS and consider the specific agents Chlamydophila (Chlamydia) pneumoniae, Human Herpes Virus 6, and Epstein-Barr Virus, that are implicated in either the development or progression of MS.

title: Global stressors and the global decline of amphibians: tipping the stress immunocompetency axis
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive evaluation of the impacts of global stressors on amphibian immunocompetency in order to identify preferable tipping points. The effects of climate change, ultraviolet radiation, species introductions and habitat fragmentation are examined within the context of individual species' susceptibility to environmental perturbations. By considering how small environmental shocks can escalate into large-scale declines in population health status at varying levels of intensity and management strategies, it is possible to make informed conservation decisions for sustainably managing populations worldwide. Using data from multiple sources across fifty-five different regions around the world, this article offers unique insights into those areas where disturbances have caused amphibian populations to suffer greatest harm and suggests ways for reviving both community resilience and population vitality. These findings provide crucial information that policymakers can use when formulating proactive approaches towards mitigating future harm to biodiverse habitats home to sensitive organisms like amphibians before they find themselves under threat from any number of global stressors.

title: Smallpox and Season: Reanalysis of Historical Data
abstract: Seasonal variation in smallpox transmission is one of the most pressing ecological questions and is relevant to bioterrorism preparedness. The present study reanalyzed 7 historical datasets which recorded monthly cases or deaths. In addition to time series analyses of reported data, an estimation and spectral analysis of the effective reproduction number at calendar time t, R(t), were made. Meteorological variables were extracted from a report in India from 1890–1921 and compared with smallpox mortality as well as R(t). Annual cycles of smallpox transmission were clearly shown not only in monthly reports but also in the estimates of R(t). Even short-term epidemic data clearly exhibited an annual peak every January. Both mortality and R(t) revealed significant negative association (P < .01) and correlation (P < .01), respectively, with humidity. These findings suggest that smallpox transmission greatly varies with season and is most likely enhanced by dry weather.

title: Detection of Mycobacterium ulcerans by the Loop Mediated Isothermal Amplification Method
abstract: This article presents a study of the Loop-mediated Isothermal Amplification (LAMP) method for the rapid and precise detection of Mycobacterium ulcerans. M. ulcerans is an environmental pathogen that causes Buruli ulcers, a neglected disease afflicting populations in some tropical and subtropical regions worldwide. This bacterial infection typically reveals skin lesions with significant disability, reducing productivity in individuals living in highly endemic zones with limited medical resources. Existing diagnostic criteria require complex culturing techniques which may not be feasible in many resource-limited settings due to their lengthy duration, as well as stringent laboratory requirements. Therefore there lies an urgent need to identify effective alternatives that are rapid and simple to perform while maintaining adequate sensitivity and specificity, such as LAMP technology We present evidence based on analytical results of optimization studies Testing samples were analyzed using LAMP detector primers targeting IS2404 gene sequence specific to M.ulceranus showing improved accuracy and shortening processing times considerably compared exams used conventionally such PCR software programs.. The excellent performance capabilities attained through our experiments provide a positive outlook towards potential applications aiding patients seeking diagnosis of Buruli Ulcers via implementation of practical clinical use The Looped Mediated Isotherma l Amlification strategy represents new benchmark tool for direct detection M .ulceranus DNA from different sources .

title: Predicting pseudoknotted structures across two RNA sequences
abstract: This paper presents a new computational method for predicting pseudoknotted structures that span two distinct RNA sequences. The focus of this work is on developing an efficient yet accurate tool that accelerates the process of pseudoknot prediction, enabling its use in various scenarios where knowledge regarding these complex secondary structures can impact elucidation of their biological roles. Additionally, this research aimed to minimise false positive predictions by introducing an algorithm incorporating both thermodynamic and phylogenetic approaches which applies to sequences with known or unknown base pairing information. In-depth evaluations demonstrate the capacity of our developed technique to identify true positive patterns and minimise false positives in comparison to existing methods. These findings provide strong evidence supporting the use of our approach for practical analysis towards uncovering structural elements contained within large genomic datasets.

title: Pulmonary sequelae in a patient recovered from swine flu
abstract: This paper examines the long-term pulmonary sequelae of severe swine flu in a patient who has recovered. Although it is well established that swine flu infection can cause significant acute respiratory illness, little is known about the chronic consequences in individuals affected. Our findings suggest that even if a full recovery from an episode of severe swine flu may be achieved over time, ongoing physiological changes to the lungs resulting from prior episodes remain with associated physiological and psychological impacts on general health and quality of life. The implications for clinical management are discussed.

title: Heme oxygenase-1 and carbon monoxide in pulmonary medicine
abstract: Heme oxygenase-1 (HO-1), an inducible stress protein, confers cytoprotection against oxidative stress in vitro and in vivo. In addition to its physiological role in heme degradation, HO-1 may influence a number of cellular processes, including growth, inflammation, and apoptosis. By virtue of anti-inflammatory effects, HO-1 limits tissue damage in response to proinflammatory stimuli and prevents allograft rejection after transplantation. The transcriptional upregulation of HO-1 responds to many agents, such as hypoxia, bacterial lipopolysaccharide, and reactive oxygen/nitrogen species. HO-1 and its constitutively expressed isozyme, heme oxygenase-2, catalyze the rate-limiting step in the conversion of heme to its metabolites, bilirubin IXα, ferrous iron, and carbon monoxide (CO). The mechanisms by which HO-1 provides protection most likely involve its enzymatic reaction products. Remarkably, administration of CO at low concentrations can substitute for HO-1 with respect to anti-inflammatory and anti-apoptotic effects, suggesting a role for CO as a key mediator of HO-1 function. Chronic, low-level, exogenous exposure to CO from cigarette smoking contributes to the importance of CO in pulmonary medicine. The implications of the HO-1/CO system in pulmonary diseases will be discussed in this review, with an emphasis on inflammatory states.

title: Development of a Plastic-Based Microfluidic Immunosensor Chip for Detection of H1N1 Influenza
abstract: This abstract outlines a study concerning the development of an innovative plastic-based microfluidic immunosensor chip (MICS) for detection of H1N1 influenza. This MICS was created using digital fabrication technologies and exhibits both cost-effectiveness and higher throughput rates than traditional methods used in antigen sensing assays. Despite its promising capabilities, the performance of this device still needs to be tested against complex biological matrices containing H1N1 antigens. Through optimization experiments involving surface properties, optimal antibody immobilization strategies and analysis parameters, this work provides valuable insight into how to further improve the overall operation of such biosensors for specific applications in health diagnostics.

title: The influence of locked nucleic acid residues on the thermodynamic properties of 2′-O-methyl RNA/RNA heteroduplexes
abstract: The influence of locked nucleic acid (LNA) residues on the thermodynamic properties of 2′-O-methyl RNA/RNA heteroduplexes is reported. Optical melting studies indicate that LNA incorporated into an otherwise 2′-O-methyl RNA oligonucleotide usually, but not always, enhances the stabilities of complementary duplexes formed with RNA. Several trends are apparent, including: (i) a 3′ terminal U LNA and 5′ terminal LNAs are less stabilizing than interior and other 3′ terminal LNAs; (ii) most of the stability enhancement is achieved when LNA nucleotides are separated by at least one 2′-O-methyl nucleotide; and (iii) the effects of LNA substitutions are approximately additive when the LNA nucleotides are separated by at least one 2′-O-methyl nucleotide. An equation is proposed to approximate the stabilities of complementary duplexes formed with RNA when at least one 2′-O-methyl nucleotide separates LNA nucleotides. The sequence dependence of 2′-O-methyl RNA/RNA duplexes appears to be similar to that of RNA/RNA duplexes, and preliminary nearest-neighbor free energy increments at 37°C are presented for 2′-O-methyl RNA/RNA duplexes. Internal mismatches with LNA nucleotides significantly destabilize duplexes with RNA.

title: Therapeutic Vaccination in Chronic Hepatitis B: Preclinical Studies in the Woodchuck
abstract: Recommended treatment of chronic hepatitis B with interferon-α and/or nucleos(t)ide analogues does not lead to a satisfactory result. Induction of HBV-specific T cells by therapeutic vaccination or immunotherapies may be an innovative strategy to overcome virus persistence. Vaccination with commercially available HBV vaccines in patients did not result in effective control of HBV infection, suggesting that new formulations of therapeutic vaccines are needed. The woodchuck (Marmota monax) is a useful preclinical model for developing the new therapeutic approaches in chronic hepadnaviral infections. Several innovative approaches combining antiviral treatments with nucleos(t)ide analogues, DNA vaccines, and protein vaccines were tested in the woodchuck model. In this paper we summarize the available data concerning therapeutic immunization and gene therapy using recombinant viral vectors approaches in woodchucks, which show encouraging results. In addition, we present potential innovations in immunomodulatory strategies to be evaluated in this animal model.

title: A Pilot Study of Host Genetic Variants Associated with Influenza-associated Deaths among Children and Young Adults
abstract: This study presents a novel evaluation of host genetic variants in relation to the fatal outcome of influenza virus infections among children and young adults. Analyzing multiple independent cohorts, we performed epidemiologic and genetic analyses with the aim of characterizing gene-specific risks associated with severe influenza outcomes. Our investigation revealed 12 host genetic polymorphisms significantly associated with an increased risk for fatal outcomes after adjusting for other risk factors such as age, sex, pre-existing chronic medical condition, virulence markers, treatment regimens and year or birth cohort. This study provides preliminary insights on the potential role of human genetics variations conferring protection or increase susceptibilities to death from influenza infection among pediatric patients and young adults.

title: Globalization and emerging governance modalities
abstract: This paper explores the possibilities for global governance effectively dealing with the international transmission of disease. First, zoonotic regulation and control pose a special case for public health agencies, and this paper proposes a propositional model for an effective public health stance. Second, globalization dynamics are briefly reviewed in terms of an emerging consensus on the need for global governance in public health. Third, a brief examination of global governance modalities suggests that a strong global governance case has distinct limitations (despite its possible justification); an exploration of contemporary directions in global governance follows. Finally, the paper examines the phenomenon of contemporary zoonotic control within the conditions of an effective regulatory regime.

title: Outdoor environments and human pathogens in air
abstract: Are pathogens in outdoor air a health issue at present or will they become a problem in the future? A working group called AirPath - Outdoor Environments and Human Pathogens in Air was set up in 2007 at University College London, UK with the aim of opening new discussion and creating a research network to investigate the science and impacts of outdoor pathogens. Our objective in this paper is to review and discuss the following areas: What is the source of human pathogens in outdoor air? What current, developing and future techniques do we need? Can we identify at-risk groups in relation to their activities and environments? How do we prepare for the anticipated challenges of environmental change and new and emerging diseases? And how can we control for and prevent pathogens in outdoor environments? We think that this work can benefit the wider research community and policy makers by providing a concise overview of various research aspects and considerations which may be important to their work.

title: Seasonal influenza vaccination knowledge, risk perception, health beliefs and vaccination behaviours of nurses
abstract: This study explores the Seasonal Influenza Vaccination Knowledge, Risk Perception, Health Beliefs and Vaccination Behaviours of nurses. Amidst demands to reduce cost and maximize efficiency frequently questioning vaccines’ value due to potential risk associated with their usage, nurses are in a unique position providing healthcare services and information to individuals receiving the vaccine. This research investigates how nurse vaccination knowledge is related to specific health beliefs which might increase or decrease the intent to vaccinate against influenza virus annually. The results will provide an insight into what drives some nurses’ decision making on this issue; enabling health organisations more effectively target communications for increased vaccinations across vulnerable groups in winter season when her immunity could be compromised by various conditions including influenza virus.

title: Synthesis of an antiviral drug precursor from chitin using a saprophyte as a whole-cell catalyst
abstract: This paper presents a novel synthesis of an antiviral drug precursor from chitin, with the help of a saprophyte as a whole-cell catalyst. Chitin is widely available in nature and because of its thermal stability has been recognised as an environmentally friendly alternative to synthetic polymers. In this study, it was demonstrated that by using olivicolchine salt concentration alone or in combination with other reagents such as paraformaldehyde (PFA) and ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), one can readily obtain satisfactory yields for synthesis of 5'-O-(2-methoxyethyl)-N-[(3R)-3-methylbutanoyl]uridine (MU). The unique contribution of this paper lies in the use of Lipomyces starkeyi imp6–1 mutant strain which serves simultaneously both as the grower organism for production of MU and also acts as an effective catalyst for improving the efficiency and yield up to 50%. Further optimisation studies are needed to make MU synthesis more cost efficient, yielding higher product quality with reduced environmental pollution.

title: Dectin-1 and DC-SIGN Polymorphisms Associated with Invasive Pulmonary Aspergillosis Infection
abstract: This journal article studies the association between Dectin-1 and DC-SIGN polymorphisms with invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) infection. Through a comprehensive analysis of 200 patients suffering from IPA, researchers were able to determine the frequency of two genetic single nucleotide polymorphism variants relative to IPA diagnosis. It was observed that individuals with specific mutations in both Dectin-1 and DC-SIGN had an increased risk for developing IPA infection compared to those without these particular SNPs. This research demonstrates a crucial relationship between two gene loci carrying immunity related traits and susceptibility for IA infection, suggesting variation in individual responses against this fungi pathogen is linked to altered receptor activity levels leading to immune evasion or susceptibility resulting in systemic fungal aggression. The findings presented here can provide insights into immunological aspects of Aspergillus infections and could potentially assist towards improved prophylactic strategies against life threatening fungal pathogens like A. fumigatus seen in young adults and other vulnerable patient populations.

title: Naturally-Occurring Genetic Variants in Human DC-SIGN Increase HIV-1 Capture, Cell-Transfer and Risk of Mother-To-Child Transmission
abstract: This article presents a novel study on the effects of naturally-occurring genetic variants in human DC-SIGN (CD209), focusing specifically on their influence in increasing HIV-1 capture, cell transfer and risk of mother to child transmission. DC-SIGN is a C type lectin expressed by antigen presenting cells that plays an important role in innate immune responses and its role as gateway receptor for HIV has been extensively studied. However, while it has been speculated that germline polymorphism of this particular gene may affect HIV susceptibility, the reported studies have focused mainly on Asian populations. The present study thus set out to comprehensively analyze variation at this adapter molecule across various global regions from diverse Georgraphic backgrounds with special emphasis towards understanding its effect on disease progression with regards to MTC transmission. This evaluation is expected to contribute valuable insights into our knowledge regarding greater understanding of US patients' propensity towards different afflictions pertaining to AIDS/HIV virus spread thereby increasing measures directed towards curbing further disease dynamics helping manage high risk individuals worse affected during pandemics like Covid-19 epidemic prevailing today.

title: Lung tissue bioenergetics and caspase activity in rodents
abstract: This article provides an overview of the research exploring lung tissue bioenergetics and caspase activity in rodent models. Lung tissue is especially important for understanding issues such as pulmonary diseases, organ development and physiology due to its complex composition and non-replaceable function for oxygen processing. Caspases are key players in apoptosis or programmed cell death, providing critical functions during illness, injury or aging. Therefore, investigating their role in the context of lung biology and disease has great potential for advancing our knowledge about these processes. Our study explored how changes in caspase activity could be used to modulate lung behaviour through experimental protocols involving two rodent models: Rattus norvegicus (Norway rat) and Mus musculus (house mouse). Results from this experiment showed that increasing levels of caspase activity correlated with greater energy production associated with cellular maintenance while decreasing levels had a negative effect on energy balance. Furthermore, findings suggested that different species may have unique bioenergetic responses related to the modulation of metabolic pathways by specific pro-apoptotic enzymes such as those belonging to the family of caspases we studied here. Overall, this work will help guide future studies that are concerned with manipulating metabolic responses involved in apoptotic signalling cascades within various organs which can aid us better understand utilisation chain reactions at play when organisms become ill or age naturally.

title: Evolutionarily Conserved Herpesviral Protein Interaction Networks
abstract: Herpesviruses constitute a family of large DNA viruses widely spread in vertebrates and causing a variety of different diseases. They possess dsDNA genomes ranging from 120 to 240 kbp encoding between 70 to 170 open reading frames. We previously reported the protein interaction networks of two herpesviruses, varicella-zoster virus (VZV) and Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV). In this study, we systematically tested three additional herpesvirus species, herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1), murine cytomegalovirus and Epstein-Barr virus, for protein interactions in order to be able to perform a comparative analysis of all three herpesvirus subfamilies. We identified 735 interactions by genome-wide yeast-two-hybrid screens (Y2H), and, together with the interactomes of VZV and KSHV, included a total of 1,007 intraviral protein interactions in the analysis. Whereas a large number of interactions have not been reported previously, we were able to identify a core set of highly conserved protein interactions, like the interaction between HSV-1 UL33 with the nuclear egress proteins UL31/UL34. Interactions were conserved between orthologous proteins despite generally low sequence similarity, suggesting that function may be more conserved than sequence. By combining interactomes of different species we were able to systematically address the low coverage of the Y2H system and to extract biologically relevant interactions which were not evident from single species.

title: Unraveling the structural complexity in a single-stranded RNA tail: implications for efficient ligand binding in the prequeuosine riboswitch
abstract: This paper seeks to uncover the critical structural features of a single-stranded RNA tail that are essential for effective ligand binding by the prequeuosine riboswitch. Recent advances in NMR and biochemical techniques have enabled us to identify key elements involved in conformational changes associated with this regulatory element, yet relatively little is known about how specific tertiary motifs affect ligand recognition and binding efficiency. Drawing from an exhaustive analysis of three-dimensional structures, computer simulations, and kinetic measurements, we probe the energetic landscape in order to gain further insight into long-range communication between functionally important sites within these RNAs. Informed by our findings, we propose a mechanism for efficient ligand binding involving interplay between global conformation rearrangements at distant sites and local regulatory surface adjustments brought about through induced fit interactions upon base pairing with its target molecule or ions. Our research illuminates an unexplored area pertinent not only to elucidating principles behind riboregulation but also applications such as near infrared imaging agents (NIRIs).

title: Exposure of cats to low doses of FeLV: seroconversion as the sole parameter of infection
abstract: In felids, feline leukemia virus (FeLV) infection results in a variety of outcomes that range from abortive (virus readily eliminated and never detectable) to progressive infection (persistent viremia and viral shedding). Recently, a novel outcome was postulated for low FeLV infectious doses. Naïve cats exposed to faeces of persistently infected cats seroconverted, indicating infection, but remained negative for provirus and p27 antigen in blood. FeLV provirus was found in some tissues but not in the bone marrow, infection of which is usually considered a necessary stage for disease progression. To investigate the impact of low FeLV doses on young cats and to test the hypothesis that low dose exposure may lead to an unknown pathogenesis of infection without involvement of the bone marrow, 21 cats were infected oronasally with variable viral doses. Blood p27, proviral and viral loads were followed until week 20 post-infection. Tissue proviral loads were determined as well. The immune response was monitored by measuring FeLV whole virus and p45 antibodies; and feline oncornavirus-associated cell membrane antigen (FOCMA) assay. One cat showed regressive infection (transient antigenemia, persistent provirus-positivity, and seroconversion) with provirus only found in some organs at sacrifice. In 7 of the 20 remaining cats FOCMA assay positivity was the only sign of infection, while all other tests were negative. Overall, the results show that FeLV low dose exposure can result in seroconversion during a presumed abortive infection. Therefore, commonly used detection methods do not detect all FeLV-infected animals, possibly leading to an underestimation of the prevalence of infection.

title: Reflections on Pandemic (H1N1) 2009 and the International Response
abstract: Gabriel Leung and Angus Nicoll provide their reflections on the international response to the 2009 H1N1 influenza pandemic, including what went well and what changes need to be made in anticipation of future flu pandemics.

title: Deletion of human metapneumovirus M2-2 increases mutation frequency and attenuates growth in hamsters
abstract: BACKGROUND: Human metapneumovirus (hMPV) infection can cause acute lower respiratory tract illness in infants, the immunocompromised, and the elderly. Currently there are no licensed preventative measures for hMPV infections. Using a variant of hMPV/NL/1/00 that does not require trypsin supplementation for growth in tissue culture, we deleted the M2-2 gene and evaluated the replication of rhMPV/ΔM2-2 virus in vitro and in vivo. RESULTS: In vitro studies showed that the ablation of M2-2 increased the propensity for insertion of U nucleotides in poly-U tracts of the genomic RNA. In addition, viral transcription was up-regulated although the level of genomic RNA remained comparable to rhMPV. Thus, deletion of M2-2 alters the ratio between hMPV genome copies and transcripts. In vivo, rhMPV/ΔM2-2 was attenuated compared to rhMPV in the lungs and nasal turbinates of hamsters. Hamsters immunized with one dose of rhMPV/ΔM2-2 were protected from challenge with 10(6 )PFU of wild type (wt) hMPV/NL/1/00. CONCLUSION: Our results suggest that hMPV M2-2 alters regulation of transcription and influences the fidelity of the polymerase complex during viral genome replication. In the hamster model, rhMPVΔM2-2 is attenuated and protective suggesting that deletion of M2-2 may result in a potential live vaccine candidate. A more thorough knowledge of the hMPV polymerase complex and the role of M2-2 during hMPV replication are being studied as we develop a potential live hMPV vaccine candidate that lacks M2-2 expression.

title: Marine Organism Cell Biology and Regulatory Sequence Discoveryin Comparative Functional Genomics
abstract: This article presents a comprehensive review of the impact of comparative functional genomics to better understand marine organism cells and elucidate their regulatory sequences. Specifically, previous work in process-oriented gene regulation has been used to discover patterns relevant to cell biology, clarify fundamental aspects of transcriptional control (e.g., basal complex networks and signaling pathways), as well as developing new insights into genome organization across multiple cellular compartments. We present detailed accounts on how this information augments our understanding of biological regulation in diverse taxa, while also providing valuable insight into general principles applicable beyond just one species or tissue type. Furthermore, this integrative framework enables us to recognize evolutionary trajectories defining long-term adaptation between various cell types at different anatomical levels. Additionally, from sequence analysis data obtained from these studies we can deduce interorganellar dependencies between genomic elements that manifest under specific physiological conditions or environmental cues; facilitating an increased capacity for discovering novel conserved motifs among marine organism genomes influencing interlinked physiological processes within these organisms via newly developed meta-analysis toolsets. It is clear that utilizing such integrative approaches will provide greater resolution for uncovering dynamic interactions shaping genetic makeup across various phyla; ultimately contributing towards a more nuanced approach towards mapping out global trends observed across trait–environment interface relationships using comparative functional genomics principles applied to marine organisms cell biology research programs worldwide.

title: Both TLR2 and TRIF Contribute to Interferon-β Production during Listeria Infection
abstract: This study investigates the roles of toll-like receptor 2 (TLR2) and Toll/interleukin 1 receptor domain containing adaptor inducing interferon-β (TRIF), two innate immune transmembrane proteins, during Listeria infection. The research established that TLR2 and TRIF both contribute to the production of interferon-β, a key cytokine in host defense against intracellular bacterial pathogens such as Listeria monocytogenes. By evaluating changes in gene expression levels following treatment with either compound or both, this work presents new evidence for the integral role these receptors play in immune response to listerial invasion. Consequently, further understanding of their involvement may reveal potential drug targets for improving treatments against pathogenic infections by Listeria species.

title: C-reactive protein, haptoglobin, serum amyloid A and pig major acute phase protein response in pigs simultaneously infected with H1N1 swine influenza virus and Pasteurella multocida
abstract:
This study investigates the response of four pig acute phase proteins (APP) to dual infection with H1N1 swine influenza virus (SIV) and Pasteurella multocida. Serological assays were carried out on more than 200 pigs divided into different groups receiving either SIV, P.multocida or a combination of both bacterial and viral matter in order to measure the app levels in blood serum pre-and post-infection. The results indicate that c-reactive protein, haptoglobin, serum amyloid A and major acute phase protein show distinct alterations depending on the type of infection received. 

The interplay between host immune response against pathogens is well known but much remains unknown about how organisms respond to multiple simultaneous infections mediated through diverse routes especially when virulence factors vary considerably among causative agents responsible for triggering inflammation cascade pathways leading several cooperative APP changes at once. To gain insight into this complexity, this paper attempts to provide evidence regarding whether proinflammatory apoplipoproteins similarly mount up a heightened defense efforts towards managing dual infection together or rather separately depending on precise immunostimulant configurations synthesized by cells engaging modulate molecular networks attempting to sequester challenge concurrently presented before an immune system overwhelmed by multiple aggregated assaults simultaneously occurring over time capable altering overall defensive strategies not discernible under single pathogen exposure events alone.

title: Tamiflu-Resistant but HA-Mediated Cell-to-Cell Transmission through Apical Membranes of Cell-Associated Influenza Viruses
abstract: This study presents the investigation into Tamiflu-resistant but HA-mediated cell-to-cell transmission through apical membranes of cell-associated influenza viruses. Influenza represents a major public health concern due to its potential for seasonal pandemics, causing wide scale morbidity and mortality. Given current strategies focus on infection control measures, antiviral drugs such as Tamiflu are mainly used in preventive and therapeutic treatments against infections caused by influenza virus strains previously known not to be resistant. However, several cases of high level resistance have been reported in recent years, leading to urgent research into alternative strategies for combating Tamiflu resistance. In this study we examined how tamiflu resistant influenza viruses are able to leverage host proteins such as Hemagglutinin (HA) protein mediators to enable the intercellular spread through apical membrane interactions with other cells harbouring resistive viral strains in close proximity which can then raise the possibility of successful transmission of our results should provide more data towards existing prevention techniques targeting high risk environments with knowledge regarding interventions that could limit further spread and persistence amongst hosts already infected with these immunoevasive variants thus safeguarding human populations from endemic or pandemic outbreaks caused by such closely interacting strains bearing tamiflu resistant properties..

title: Clinical use of exhaled volatile organic compounds in pulmonary diseases: a systematic review
abstract: This review aims to evaluate the clinical utility of exhaled volatile organic compounds (VOCs) for the early detection, prognosis and treatment monitoring of pulmonary diseases. Recent advances in breath analysis technology have enabled non-invasive diagnosis and management of respiratory illnesses, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), asthma and lung cancer. By investigating VOC concentrations in expelled air over time through a systematic review, this study seeks to establish whether they could be used as diagnostic or prognostic biomarkers of these common pulmonary diseases. A meta-analysis was also conducted to compare medical practice with various existing panels consisting of differentially expressed VOCs linked to each disease. Our findings suggest that novel metabolomics-based methods based on VOC concentration can help identify potential pathogenic signatures indicative of individual conditions, thereby enabling risk stratification among patients diagnosed with acute or chronic respiratory illness. Furthermore, recent evidence suggests that extracellular metabolites produced by the airway are closely associated with modest alterations in lung function and unique environmental exposure signatures which could enable personalized treatment strategies for better therapeutic outcomes. In conclusion, our data supports the clinical use of exhaled volatile organic compounds for optimal prevention and management protocols in order to improve patient care for individuals affected by pulmonary diseases across multiple settings.

title: Tylosema esculentum (Marama) Tuber and Bean Extracts Are Strong Antiviral Agents against Rotavirus Infection
abstract: Tylosema esculentum (marama) beans and tubers are used as food, and traditional medicine against diarrhoea in Southern Africa. Rotaviruses (RVs) are a major cause of diarrhoea among infants, young children, immunocompromised people, and domesticated animals. Our work is first to determine anti-RV activity of marama bean and tuber ethanol and water extracts; in this case on intestinal enterocyte cells of human infant (H4), adult pig (CLAB) and adult bovine (CIEB) origin. Marama cotyledon ethanolic extract (MCE) and cotyledon water extract (MCW) without RV were not cytotoxic to all cells tested, while seed coat and tuber extracts showed variable levels of cytotoxicity. Marama cotyledon ethanolic and water extracts (MCE and MCW, resp.) (≥0.1 mg/mL), seed coat extract (MSCE) and seed coat water extract (MSCW) (0.01 to 0.001 mg/mL), especially ethanolic, significantly increased cell survival and enhanced survival to cytopathic effects of RV by at least 100% after in vitro co- and pre-incubation treatments. All marama extracts used significantly enhanced nitric oxide release from H4 cells and enhanced TER (Ω/cm(2)) of enterocyte barriers after coincubation with RV. Marama cotyledon and seed coat extracts inhibited virion infectivity possibly through interference with replication due to accumulation of nitric oxide. Marama extracts are therefore promising microbicides against RV.

title: General Practice and Pandemic Influenza: A Framework for Planning and Comparison of Plans in Five Countries
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although primary health care, and in particular, general practice will be at the frontline in the response to pandemic influenza, there are no frameworks to guide systematic planning for this task or to appraise available plans for their relevance to general practice. We aimed to develop a framework that will facilitate planning for general practice, and used it to appraise pandemic plans from Australia, England, USA, New Zealand and Canada. METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS: We adapted the Haddon matrix to develop the framework, populating its cells through a multi-method study that incorporated the peer-reviewed and grey literature, interviews with general practitioners, practice nurses and senior decision-makers, and desktop simulation exercises. We used the framework to analyse 89 publicly-available jurisdictional plans at similar managerial levels in the five countries. The framework identifies four functional domains: clinical care for influenza and other needs, public health responsibilities, the internal environment and the macro-environment of general practice. No plan addressed all four domains. Most plans either ignored or were sketchy about non-influenza clinical needs, and about the contribution of general practice to public health beyond surveillance. Collaborations between general practices were addressed in few plans, and inter-relationships with the broader health system, even less frequently. CONCLUSIONS: This is the first study to provide a framework to guide general practice planning for pandemic influenza. The framework helped identify critical shortcomings in available plans. Engaging general practice effectively in planning is challenging, particularly where governance structures for primary health care are weak. We identify implications for practice and for research.

title: The effect of network mixing patterns on epidemic dynamics and the efficacy of disease contact tracing
abstract: In networks, nodes may preferentially contact other nodes with similar (assortatively mixed) or dissimilar (disassortatively mixed) numbers of contacts. Different patterns of contact support different epidemic dynamics, potentially affecting the efficacy of control measures such as contact tracing, which aims to identify and isolate nodes with infectious contacts. We used stochastic simulations to investigate the effects of mixing patterns on epidemic dynamics and contact-tracing efficacy. For uncontrolled epidemics, outbreaks occur at lower infection rates for more assortatively mixed networks, with faster initial epidemic growth rate and shorter epidemic duration than for disassortatively mixed networks. Contact tracing performs better for assortative mixing where epidemic size is large and tracing rate low, but it performs better for disassortative mixing at higher contact rates. For assortatively mixed networks, disease spreads first to highly connected nodes, but this is balanced by contact tracing quickly identifying these same nodes. The converse is true for disassortative mixing, where both disease and tracing are less likely to target highly connected nodes. For small epidemics, contact tracing is more effective on disassortative networks due to the greater resilience of assortative networks to link removal. Multi-step contact tracing is more effective than single-step tracing for assortative mixing, but this effect is smaller for disassortatively mixed networks.

title: Novel Paramyxoviruses in Free-Ranging European Bats
abstract: The recent years' emergence of a novel family of paramyxoviruses associated with bat populations worldwide is raising questions about their role in human-related disease burden. In this article, the authors provide a comprehensive overview of their findings on the presence and characteristics of novel paramyxoviruses carried by European bats. Following detailed literature review and exploratory field work using serum samples from 890 free-ranging bat species across four countries (Austria, Croatia, Hungary and Romania), it was revealed that 17 different types of novel paramyxovirus are ubiquitously present in European bats. Major differences were found between sites within each country regarding prevalence and type of virus detected among various species on site. This indicates that further surveillance activities should be suggested to further investigate the importance and impact of these viruses to both public health as well as local wildlife conservation efforts.

title: Pattern formation of an epidemic model with diffusion
abstract: This study presents a novel analysis of the pattern formation of an epidemic model with diffusion. We focus on how the topography of spatial density change, and develop a spatially explicit individual-based model to track the spread and progression of epidemics in two coupled habitat types. Through extensive simulations, we examine how the number and size distribution of patches evolves through time, ultimately leading to distinctive patterns across different scenarios. Our results reveal that epiphenomena like "edge effects" can measurably impact within-host dynamics, highlighting their potential impacts for disease transmission. These findings offer valuable insights into both understanding existing data sets involving multiple habitats as well as influencing future interventions directed towards reducing such outbreaks.

title: Analysis on the Pathogenesis of Symptomatic Pulmonary Embolism with Human Genomics
abstract: This paper presents an innovative analysis of the pathogenesis of symptomatic pulmonary embolism (PE) using human genomics. It is well-established that PE results from a combination of inherited or acquired thromboembolic risk factors and environmental influences, but there remains incomplete understanding of the pathways involved in this complex disorder. Through high-throughput genomic sequencing data combined with systems genetics approaches, we performed an integrative analysis to investigate the genetic regulation underlying symptomatic PE. Our findings indicate that distinct gene expression levels across various tissues can be implicated in developing the disease by modulating various protective mechanisms against its formation. In particular, our study suggests alterations in key genes associated with clotting and fibrinolysis play decisive roles within various cellular contexts for a variety of individuals with symptomatic PE. This research provides substantial insight towards furthering our understanding on how different complicating factors can contribute tosymptomatology asociated with this serious respiratory condition as well as bridges current medical knowledge gaps concerning its molecular underpinnings and paths toward potential treatments..

title: A Human PrM Antibody That Recognizes a Novel Cryptic Epitope on Dengue E Glycoprotein
abstract: This study presents an antibody that can specifically recognize a novel human-restricted cryptic epitope within the envelope (E) glycoprotein of Dengue virus. An extensive analysis based on molecular, immunological, and biochemical approaches was undertaken to characterize this specific monoclonal antibody obtained from murine hybridoma clone 6G1A6—the only one found to react with this putative epitope among 30 other prM-reactive antibodies generated by random screening. Superimposed onto 3D structural models and aided by mutagenesis experiments, our findings demonstrate the precise architecture of this hitherto unidentified cryptic epitope and confer great potential for its use as a diagnostic biomarker in both laboratory research studies and clinical settings.

title: TLR agonist–Stat3 siRNA conjugates: cell-specific gene silencing and enhanced antitumor immune responses
abstract: Efficient delivery of siRNA to specific cell populations in vivo remains a formidable challenge to its successful therapeutic application. We describe a novel siRNA-based approach – synthetically linking siRNA to an oligonucleotide TLR9 agonist – that targets and silences genes in TLR9(+) myeloid cells and B cells, both of which are key components of the tumor microenvironment. Because Stat3 in tumor-associated immune cells suppresses antitumor immune responses and hinders TLR9-induced immune stimulation, we tested CpG-Stat3siRNA conjugates for anti-tumor effects. When injected locally at the tumor site or systemically through an intravenous route, the CpG-Stat3siRNA conjugates access tumor-associated dendritic cells, macrophages and B cells, inhibit Stat3 expression, leading to activation of tumor-associated immune cells, and ultimately potent anti-tumor immune responses. Our findings demonstrate the potential of TLR agonist-siRNA conjugates for targeted gene silencing coupled with TLR stimulation and immune activation in the tumor microenvironment.

title: Analysing the eosinophil cationic protein - a clue to the function of the eosinophil granulocyte
abstract: Eosinophil granulocytes reside in respiratory mucosa including lungs, in the gastro-intestinal tract, and in lymphocyte associated organs, the thymus, lymph nodes and the spleen. In parasitic infections, atopic diseases such as atopic dermatitis and asthma, the numbers of the circulating eosinophils are frequently elevated. In conditions such as Hypereosinophilic Syndrome (HES) circulating eosinophil levels are even further raised. Although, eosinophils were identified more than hundred years ago, their roles in homeostasis and in disease still remain unclear. The most prominent feature of the eosinophils are their large secondary granules, each containing four basic proteins, the best known being the eosinophil cationic protein (ECP). This protein has been developed as a marker for eosinophilic disease and quantified in biological fluids including serum, bronchoalveolar lavage and nasal secretions. Elevated ECP levels are found in T helper lymphocyte type 2 (atopic) diseases such as allergic asthma and allergic rhinitis but also occasionally in other diseases such as bacterial sinusitis. ECP is a ribonuclease which has been attributed with cytotoxic, neurotoxic, fibrosis promoting and immune-regulatory functions. ECP regulates mucosal and immune cells and may directly act against helminth, bacterial and viral infections. The levels of ECP measured in disease in combination with the catalogue of known functions of the protein and its polymorphisms presented here will build a foundation for further speculations of the role of ECP, and ultimately the role of the eosinophil.

title: Clinical Assessment and Improved Diagnosis of Bocavirus-induced Wheezing in Children, Finland
abstract: Human bocavirus (HBoV) is a widespread respiratory virus. To improve diagnostic methods, we conducted immunoglobulin (Ig) G and IgM enzyme immunoassays with recombinant virus–like particles of HBoV as antigen. Acute-phase and follow-up serum samples from 258 wheezing children and single serum samples from 115 healthy adults in Finland were examined. Our assays had a sensitivity of 97% and a specificity of 99.5%. Of adults, 96% had immunity; none had an acute infection. Of 48 children with serologically diagnosed acute HBoV infections, 45 were viremic and 35 had virus in nasopharyngeal aspirates (NPAs). Of 39 HBoV NPA PCR–positive children co-infected with another virus, 64% had a serologically verified HBoV infection. HBoV caused illness of longer duration than rhinovirus and of equal severity to that of respiratory syncytial virus. Among children with bronchiolitis, >25% had acute HBoV infections. Accurate HBoV diagnosis requires serologic analysis or PCR of serum; PCR of NPAs alone is insufficient.

title: Key Role of Splenic Myeloid DCs in the IFN-αβ Response to Adenoviruses In Vivo
abstract: The early systemic production of interferon (IFN)-αβ is an essential component of the antiviral host defense mechanisms, but is also thought to contribute to the toxic side effects accompanying gene therapy with adenoviral vectors. Here we investigated the IFN-αβ response to human adenoviruses (Ads) in mice. By comparing the responses of normal, myeloid (m)DC- and plasmacytoid (p)DC-depleted mice and by measuring IFN-αβ mRNA expression in different organs and cells types, we show that in vivo, Ads elicit strong and rapid IFN-αβ production, almost exclusively in splenic mDCs. Using knockout mice, various strains of Ads (wild type, mutant and UV-inactivated) and MAP kinase inhibitors, we demonstrate that the Ad-induced IFN-αβ response does not require Toll-like receptors (TLR), known cytosolic sensors of RNA (RIG-I/MDA-5) and DNA (DAI) recognition and interferon regulatory factor (IRF)-3, but is dependent on viral endosomal escape, signaling via the MAP kinase SAPK/JNK and IRF-7. Furthermore, we show that Ads induce IFN-αβ and IL-6 in vivo by distinct pathways and confirm that IFN-αβ positively regulates the IL-6 response. Finally, by measuring TNF-α responses to LPS in Ad-infected wild type and IFN-αβR(−/−) mice, we show that IFN-αβ is the key mediator of Ad-induced hypersensitivity to LPS. These findings indicate that, like endosomal TLR signaling in pDCs, TLR-independent virus recognition in splenic mDCs can also produce a robust early IFN-αβ response, which is responsible for the bulk of IFN-αβ production induced by adenovirus in vivo. The signaling requirements are different from known TLR-dependent or cytosolic IFN-αβ induction mechanisms and suggest a novel cytosolic viral induction pathway. The hypersensitivity to components of the microbial flora and invading pathogens may in part explain the toxic side effects of adenoviral gene therapy and contribute to the pathogenesis of adenoviral disease.

title: Diagnosis and treatment of severe sepsis
abstract: The burden of infection in industrialized countries has prompted considerable effort to improve the outcomes of patients with sepsis. This has been formalized through the Surviving Sepsis Campaign 'bundles', derived from the recommendations of 11 professional societies, which have promoted global improvement in those practices whose primary goal it is to reduce sepsis-related death. However, difficulties remain in implementing all of the procedures recommended by the experts, despite the apparent pragmatism of those procedures. We summarize the main proposals made by the Surviving Sepsis Campaign and focus on the difficulties associated with making a proper diagnosis and supplying adequate treatment promptly to septic patients.

title: Retrovirus Entry by Endocytosis and Cathepsin Proteases
abstract: This study presents a novel exploration into the molecular mechanisms that allow retroviruses to enter cells. Previously, it has been shown that entry of such viruses is largely achieved by endocytosis and fusion with acidic organelles in the host’s cell membrane. However, while this process is known to be catalyzed by specific proteases, how they are regulated remains unknown. This paper aims to elucidate on the role of particular cathepsin proteases in retrovirus entry by exploring their kinetic properties and affinity toward viral capsids during surface scanning events preceding viral fusion activities. Using documented data from extensive studies over the last decade as well as intensive laboratory-based examinations revolving around mutagenesis experiments, along with cutting edge computational tools for structure/function analysis; we aim to systematically analyze key elements contributing to efficient viral translocation across cellular membranes induced exclusively via endocytic pathways at both genetic and mechanistic levels. Our results will provide further insight into efficient delivery systems of therapeutic cargo based on highly selective uptake through clinical grade virus-like particles (VLPs).

title: Treatment of Neuroterrorism
abstract: This paper will explore the novel research and approaches to tackle the increasingly preeminent issue of neuroterrorism – terrorists who use psychological tactics to induce fear, manipulate individuals and propagate false information. In recent years, the diversifying forms of modern terrorism have necessitated a shift in our approach to treatment so that effective counter measures can be taken against this growing threat. This article focuses on existing methods as well as upcoming treatments for countering neuroterrorism. It reviews psychotherapeutic interventions such as Critical Incident Stress De-briefings (CISD) which focus on building resilience and harnessing social support networks in order to prevent reoccurring or recurring instances of terrorist attacks motivated by psychosocial power dynamics. Further developments outlined address how technology including internet platforms are being used engage heavily with affected populations. At present, there is a limited understanding of what constitutes successful therapies when treating victims or perpetrators of neurological trauma associated with political terroristic attacks therefore this review provides an essential foundation from which we can build evidence based strategies more tailored towards meeting the distinctive challenges posed by modernity's globalized climate where ideological warfare transcends physical boundaries .

title: Real Time Bayesian Estimation of the Epidemic Potential of Emerging Infectious Diseases
abstract: BACKGROUND: Fast changes in human demographics worldwide, coupled with increased mobility, and modified land uses make the threat of emerging infectious diseases increasingly important. Currently there is worldwide alert for H5N1 avian influenza becoming as transmissible in humans as seasonal influenza, and potentially causing a pandemic of unprecedented proportions. Here we show how epidemiological surveillance data for emerging infectious diseases can be interpreted in real time to assess changes in transmissibility with quantified uncertainty, and to perform running time predictions of new cases and guide logistics allocations. METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS: We develop an extension of standard epidemiological models, appropriate for emerging infectious diseases, that describes the probabilistic progression of case numbers due to the concurrent effects of (incipient) human transmission and multiple introductions from a reservoir. The model is cast in terms of surveillance observables and immediately suggests a simple graphical estimation procedure for the effective reproductive number R (mean number of cases generated by an infectious individual) of standard epidemics. For emerging infectious diseases, which typically show large relative case number fluctuations over time, we develop a Bayesian scheme for real time estimation of the probability distribution of the effective reproduction number and show how to use such inferences to formulate significance tests on future epidemiological observations. CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE: Violations of these significance tests define statistical anomalies that may signal changes in the epidemiology of emerging diseases and should trigger further field investigation. We apply the methodology to case data from World Health Organization reports to place bounds on the current transmissibility of H5N1 influenza in humans and establish a statistical basis for monitoring its evolution in real time.

title: Synthesis and biological activity of water-soluble polymer complexes of arbidol
abstract: This article outlines the findings of an investigative study conducted to analyze the synthesis and biological activity of water-soluble polymer complexes of arbidol as a new drug carrier for medical delivery.
