The research focused on synthesizing a novel form of arbidol - a broad-spectrum antiviral agent - utilizing water-soluble polymers in order to improve solubility, bioavailability, circulation time and stability while establishing potential therapeutic efficacy. Results were obtained through spectroscopic analysis, critical micelle concentration (CMC), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and X-ray crystallography. Evaluating the cytotoxicity by means of MTT assay revealed no observable toxic effects when exposed to human liver carcinoma HepG2 cells and embryonic kidney 293Tcells at reduced concentrations introduced with natural physiological buffers providing an evidence that water soluble polymer complexes hold great promise for biopharmaceutical applications due to their good biocompatibility. 'Synthesis and Biological Activity of Water Soluble Polymer Complexes Of Arbidol': This article elucidates the successful synthesis, characterization and preliminary evaluation for their in vitro anti viral properties showing enhanced properties over unbound compound architectures which are promising indications against various diseases like influenza virus infections, offering robust platform starting point for preclinical investigations towards development as functional nanomedicines in humans.

title: Cost effective strategies for completing the Interactome
abstract: Comprehensive protein interaction mapping projects are underway for many model species and humans. A key step in these projects is estimating the time, cost, and personnel required for obtaining an accurate and complete map. Here, we model the cost of interaction map completion across a spectrum of experimental designs. We show that current efforts may require up to 20 independent tests covering each protein pair to approach completion. We explore designs for reducing this cost substantially, including prioritization of protein pairs, probability thresholding, and interaction prediction. The best designs lower cost by four-fold overall and >100-fold in early stages of mapping. We demonstrate the best strategy in an ongoing project in Drosophila, in which we map 450 high-confidence interactions using 47 microtiter plates, versus thousands of plates expected using current designs. This study provides a framework for assessing the feasibility of interaction mapping projects and for future efforts to increase their efficiency.

title: New Cardiovascular and Pulmonary Therapeutic Strategies Based on the Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme 2/Angiotensin-(1–7)/Mas Receptor Axis
abstract: This paper aims to elucidate the potential therapeutic strategies of targeting Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme 2/Angiotensin-(1–7)/Mas receptor axis in combating cardiovascular and pulmonary diseases. It has been recently revealed that this pathway not only plays significant roles in physiological functions, such as endothelial function and vascular remodelling, but also provides opportunities for precise treatments of a broad spectrum of disorders. Thus, identifying key components within the signalling cascade is pivotal to developing effective therapeutics for these illnesses. In order to achieve this goal, current experimental methods used both in vitro and in vivo studies are critically discussed with a view into understanding its complex relationships. This research will provide new insights into this pathway’s impact on pulmonology and cardiology allied health professionals drug development designs, while providing alternative therapies whereby individuals suffering from related conditions may benefit greatly.

title: ORMA: a tool for identification of species-specific variations in 16S rRNA gene and oligonucleotides design
abstract: 16S rRNA gene is one of the preferred targets for resolving species phylogenesis issues in microbiological-related contexts. However, the identification of single-nucleotide variations capable of distinguishing a sequence among a set of homologous ones can be problematic. Here we present ORMA (Oligonucleotide Retrieving for Molecular Applications), a set of scripts for discriminating positions search and for performing the selection of high-quality oligonucleotide probes to be used in molecular applications. Two assays based on Ligase Detection Reaction (LDR) are presented. First, a new set of probe pairs on cyanobacteria 16S rRNA sequences of 18 different species was compared to that of a previous study. Then, a set of LDR probe pairs for the discrimination of 13 pathogens contaminating bovine milk was evaluated. The software determined more than 100 candidate probe pairs per dataset, from more than 300 16S rRNA sequences, in less than 5 min. Results demonstrated how ORMA improved the performance of the LDR assay on cyanobacteria, correctly identifying 12 out of 14 samples, and allowed the perfect discrimination among the 13 milk pathogenic-related species. ORMA represents a significant improvement from other contexts where enzyme-based techniques have been employed on already known mutations of a single base or on entire subsequences.

title: Evaluation of Five Decontamination Methods for Filtering Facepiece Respirators
abstract: Concerns have been raised regarding the availability of National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH)-certified N95 filtering facepiece respirators (FFRs) during an influenza pandemic. One possible strategy to mitigate a respirator shortage is to reuse FFRs following a biological decontamination process to render infectious material on the FFR inactive. However, little data exist on the effects of decontamination methods on respirator integrity and performance. This study evaluated five decontamination methods [ultraviolet germicidal irradiation (UVGI), ethylene oxide, vaporized hydrogen peroxide (VHP), microwave oven irradiation, and bleach] using nine models of NIOSH-certified respirators (three models each of N95 FFRs, surgical N95 respirators, and P100 FFRs) to determine which methods should be considered for future research studies. Following treatment by each decontamination method, the FFRs were evaluated for changes in physical appearance, odor, and laboratory performance (filter aerosol penetration and filter airflow resistance). Additional experiments (dry heat laboratory oven exposures, off-gassing, and FFR hydrophobicity) were subsequently conducted to better understand material properties and possible health risks to the respirator user following decontamination. However, this study did not assess the efficiency of the decontamination methods to inactivate viable microorganisms. Microwave oven irradiation melted samples from two FFR models. The remainder of the FFR samples that had been decontaminated had expected levels of filter aerosol penetration and filter airflow resistance. The scent of bleach remained noticeable following overnight drying and low levels of chlorine gas were found to off-gas from bleach-decontaminated FFRs when rehydrated with deionized water. UVGI, ethylene oxide (EtO), and VHP were found to be the most promising decontamination methods; however, concerns remain about the throughput capabilities for EtO and VHP. Further research is needed before any specific decontamination methods can be recommended.

title: Cancer Biomarker Discovery: The Entropic Hallmark
abstract: BACKGROUND: It is a commonly accepted belief that cancer cells modify their transcriptional state during the progression of the disease. We propose that the progression of cancer cells towards malignant phenotypes can be efficiently tracked using high-throughput technologies that follow the gradual changes observed in the gene expression profiles by employing Shannon's mathematical theory of communication. Methods based on Information Theory can then quantify the divergence of cancer cells' transcriptional profiles from those of normally appearing cells of the originating tissues. The relevance of the proposed methods can be evaluated using microarray datasets available in the public domain but the method is in principle applicable to other high-throughput methods. METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS: Using melanoma and prostate cancer datasets we illustrate how it is possible to employ Shannon Entropy and the Jensen-Shannon divergence to trace the transcriptional changes progression of the disease. We establish how the variations of these two measures correlate with established biomarkers of cancer progression. The Information Theory measures allow us to identify novel biomarkers for both progressive and relatively more sudden transcriptional changes leading to malignant phenotypes. At the same time, the methodology was able to validate a large number of genes and processes that seem to be implicated in the progression of melanoma and prostate cancer. CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE: We thus present a quantitative guiding rule, a new unifying hallmark of cancer: the cancer cell's transcriptome changes lead to measurable observed transitions of Normalized Shannon Entropy values (as measured by high-througput technologies). At the same time, tumor cells increment their divergence from the normal tissue profile increasing their disorder via creation of states that we might not directly measure. This unifying hallmark allows, via the the Jensen-Shannon divergence, to identify the arrow of time of the processes from the gene expression profiles, and helps to map the phenotypical and molecular hallmarks of specific cancer subtypes. The deep mathematical basis of the approach allows us to suggest that this principle is, hopefully, of general applicability for other diseases.

title: Influenza activity in Europe during eight seasons (1999–2007): an evaluation of the indicators used to measure activity and an assessment of the timing, length and course of peak activity (spread) across Europe
abstract: BACKGROUND: The European Influenza Surveillance Scheme (EISS) has collected clinical and virological data on influenza since 1996 in an increasing number of countries. The EISS dataset was used to characterise important epidemiological features of influenza activity in Europe during eight winters (1999–2007). The following questions were addressed: 1) are the sentinel clinical reports a good measure of influenza activity? 2) how long is a typical influenza season in Europe? 3) is there a west-east and/or south-north course of peak activity ('spread') of influenza in Europe? METHODS: Influenza activity was measured by collecting data from sentinel general practitioners (GPs) and reports by national reference laboratories. The sentinel reports were first evaluated by comparing them to the laboratory reports and were then used to assess the timing and spread of influenza activity across Europe during eight seasons. RESULTS: We found a good match between the clinical sentinel data and laboratory reports of influenza collected by sentinel physicians (overall match of 72% for +/- 1 week difference). We also found a moderate to good match between the clinical sentinel data and laboratory reports of influenza from non-sentinel sources (overall match of 60% for +/- 1 week). There were no statistically significant differences between countries using ILI (influenza-like illness) or ARI (acute respiratory disease) as case definition. When looking at the peak-weeks of clinical activity, the average length of an influenza season in Europe was 15.6 weeks (median 15 weeks; range 12–19 weeks). Plotting the peak weeks of clinical influenza activity reported by sentinel GPs against the longitude or latitude of each country indicated that there was a west-east spread of peak activity (spread) of influenza across Europe in four winters (2001–2002, 2002–2003, 2003–2004 and 2004–2005) and a south-north spread in three winters (2001–2002, 2004–2005 and 2006–2007). CONCLUSION: We found that: 1) the clinical data reported by sentinel physicians is a valid indicator of influenza activity; 2) the length of influenza activity across the whole of Europe was surprisingly long, ranging from 12–19 weeks; 3) in 4 out of the 8 seasons, there was a west-east spread of influenza, in 3 seasons a south-north spread; not associated with type of dominant virus in those seasons.

title: Resource Allocation during an Influenza Pandemic
abstract: Resource Allocation during an Influenza Pandemic

title: Rift Valley Fever Virus NSs Protein Promotes Post-Transcriptional Downregulation of Protein Kinase PKR and Inhibits eIF2α Phosphorylation
abstract: Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) (genus Phlebovirus, family Bunyaviridae) is a negative-stranded RNA virus with a tripartite genome. RVFV is transmitted by mosquitoes and causes fever and severe hemorrhagic illness among humans, and fever and high rates of abortions in livestock. A nonstructural RVFV NSs protein inhibits the transcription of host mRNAs, including interferon-β mRNA, and is a major virulence factor. The present study explored a novel function of the RVFV NSs protein by testing the replication of RVFV lacking the NSs gene in the presence of actinomycin D (ActD) or α-amanitin, both of which served as a surrogate of the host mRNA synthesis suppression function of the NSs. In the presence of the host-transcriptional inhibitors, the replication of RVFV lacking the NSs protein, but not that carrying NSs, induced double-stranded RNA-dependent protein kinase (PKR)–mediated eukaryotic initiation factor (eIF)2α phosphorylation, leading to the suppression of host and viral protein translation. RVFV NSs promoted post-transcriptional downregulation of PKR early in the course of the infection and suppressed the phosphorylated eIF2α accumulation. These data suggested that a combination of RVFV replication and NSs-induced host transcriptional suppression induces PKR-mediated eIF2α phosphorylation, while the NSs facilitates efficient viral translation by downregulating PKR and inhibiting PKR-mediated eIF2α phosphorylation. Thus, the two distinct functions of the NSs, i.e., the suppression of host transcription, including that of type I interferon mRNAs, and the downregulation of PKR, work together to prevent host innate antiviral functions, allowing efficient replication and survival of RVFV in infected mammalian hosts.

title: Eosinophilic infiltrate in a patient with severe Legionella pneumonia as a levofloxacin-related complication: a case report
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Legionella pneumonia can appear with different levels of severity and it can often present with complications such as acute respiratory distress syndrome. CASE PRESENTATION: We report the case of a 44-year-old Caucasian man with Legionella pneumonia with successive development of severe acute respiratory distress syndrome. During his stay in intensive care the clinical and radiological situation of the previously observed acute respiratory distress syndrome unexpectedly worsened due to acute pulmonary eosinophilic infiltrate of iatrogenic origin. CONCLUSION: Levofloxacin treatment caused the occurrence of acute eosinophilic infiltrate. Diagnosis was possible following bronchoscopic examination using bronchoaspirate and transbronchial biopsy.

title: Cytomegalovirus infection in critically ill patients: a systematic review
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The precise role of cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection in contributing to outcomes in critically ill immunocompetent patients has not been fully defined. METHODS: Studies in which critically ill immunocompetent adults were monitored for CMV infection in the intensive care unit (ICU) were reviewed. RESULTS: CMV infection occurs in 0 to 36% of critically ill patients, mostly between 4 and 12 days after ICU admission. Potential risk factors for CMV infection include sepsis, requirement of mechanical ventilation, and transfusions. Prolonged mechanical ventilation (21 to 39 days vs. 13 to 24 days) and duration of ICU stay (33 to 69 days vs. 22 to 48 days) correlated significantly with a higher risk of CMV infection. Mortality rates in patients with CMV infection were higher in some but not all studies. Whether CMV produces febrile syndrome or end-organ disease directly in these patients is not known. CONCLUSIONS: CMV infection frequently occurs in critically ill immunocompetent patients and may be associated with poor outcomes. Further studies are warranted to identify subsets of patients who are likely to develop CMV infection and to determine the impact of antiviral agents on clinically meaningful outcomes in these patients.

title: Development of a large-scale isolation chamber system for the safe and humane care of medium-sized laboratory animals harboring infectious diseases
abstract: The close phylogenetic relationship between humans and non-human primates makes non-human primates an irreplaceable model for the study of human infectious diseases. In this study, we describe the development of a large-scale automatic multi-functional isolation chamber for use with medium-sized laboratory animals carrying infectious diseases. The isolation chamber, including the transfer chain, disinfection chain, negative air pressure isolation system, animal welfare system, and the automated system, is designed to meet all biological safety standards. To create an internal chamber environment that is completely isolated from the exterior, variable frequency drive blowers are used in the air-intake and air-exhaust system, precisely controlling the filtered air flow and providing an air-barrier protection. A double door transfer port is used to transfer material between the interior of the isolation chamber and the outside. A peracetic acid sterilizer and its associated pipeline allow for complete disinfection of the isolation chamber. All of the isolation chamber parameters can be automatically controlled by a programmable computerized menu, allowing for work with different animals in different-sized cages depending on the research project. The large-scale multi-functional isolation chamber provides a useful and safe system for working with infectious medium-sized laboratory animals in high-level bio-safety laboratories.

title: Viral lower urinary tract infections
abstract: Lower urinary tract infections (UTIs) are caused when bacteria progress through the urethra and ascend into the bladder and can significantly impair quality of life. Viral UTIs present a significant challenge to clinicians as they share similar symptoms with bacterial UTIs without responding to antibiotic treatments. This review provides an in-depth examination of viral lower urinary tract infections, including epidemiology, clinical characteristics, diagnosis, management and prevention strategies. It is hoped that this article will provide current insights into understanding this condition so clinicians may improve their management techniques for those affected by these disabling conditions.

title: Establishment of a Reverse Genetics System for Studying Human Bocavirus in Human Airway Epithelia
abstract: This paper presents the first robust reverse genetics system for Human Bocavirus (HBoV), which has been of interest to virologists due to its role in causing a number of clinical conditions. Through exploitation of CRISPR/Cas9 technology, it is now possible to rapidly generate recombinant viruses and explore their potential pathogenic properties. In this study, a novel platform was developed that can introduce specific mutations into wild-type HBoV genome and test its effects on human airway epithelia models. Expression levels of attachment and entry factors in presence or absence of mutated pathogens were monitored using quantitative real-time PCR assemblies. A luciferase reporter system maintained by bicistronic reporters preconfigured with neomycin cassette and Renilla luciferase gene cassettes further demonstrated the stable packaging capacity of derived particles in vitro. This integrated approach allowed us to screen multiple parameters simultaneously under both replication competent or deficient regimes, demonstrating new insights into HBoV biology in terms of infectious factor expression dynamics in airway cells imported from humans ex vivo and cultured over extended timescales.

title: Pathogenesis of rotavirus-induced diarrhea: Preliminary studies in miniature swine piglet
abstract: This paper presents the preliminary findings of an ongoing study on the pathogenesis of rotavirus-induced diarrhea in miniature swine piglets. The effect of several enteric viruses, including rotavirus, on intestinal homeostasis and the host response to them has long been under investigation. The present study aims to evaluate if rotaviral pigs show any differences in severity or pathogenicity when compared with other infection models in this species. In a controlled experiment, 30 miniature swine piglets were administered orally with different levels of attenuated or wild-type virus strains and monitored for up to 28 days post-inoculation (pI). Histological observations along with serum samples collected pI and at weekly intervals demonstrated distinctive profiles between viral doses as well as responses between volunteers during the course of natural infections verses inoculated subjects over varied time periods following exposure. This research suggests that further studies should be conducted utilizing selective challenges towards elucidating microenvironmental signals, immunomodulatory patterns within peripheral lymphoid organs upon diversion while evaluating key pathways leading up to susceptibility versus resistance among multiple animal models involving avirulent versus virulent variations.

title: Lower Respiratory Tract Infection in a Renal Transplant Recipient: Do not Forget Metapneumovirus
abstract: This article examines the importance of diagnosing and treating metabolic pneumovirus (MPV) in renal transplant recipients who experience lower respiratory tract infections (LRTIs). LRTI results due to MPV can be severe, often leading to serious complications such as organ rejection, a decreased response to immunosuppressive therapy or even death. Thus, it is essential that healthcare professionals become aware of the dangers posed by this virus and make adequate attempts to determine its presence within their patients. This paper looks at previous cases where MPV was found amongst renal transplant patients with an LRTI and defines key methods for diagnosing this virus based on these examples. Comprehensive diagnosis practices can help prevent unnecessary morbidity and mortality associated with late detection or treatment failure of MPV among LRTI-suffering RTRs worldwide.

title: HIV-1 Fusion Is Blocked through Binding of GB Virus C E2D Peptides to the HIV-1 gp41 Disulfide Loop
abstract: This study provides evidence for HIV-1 fusion inhibition by a novel mechanism: the binding of GB Virus C E2D peptides to gp41 disulfide loop of HIV-1. Our findings demonstrate an unprecedented process, which is mediated by structural rearrangement and stabilization of the Env complex between glycoprotein 120 (gp120) and transmembrane glycoprotein 41 (GP41). This is achieved through rigidifying interactions between the GP41 disulphide loop and protective envelope (Env). Results from electron microscopy confirm that these interactions are crucial in inhibiting the oligomerization necessary for viral entry into host cells. Furthermore, computational analysis suggests that certain amino acid sequences present on GbV-C E2D peptides favourably shift entropic contributions and contribute to enhanced stability of the complex. Taken together, our research presents a new strategy with promising properties to limit or even stop human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) transmission.

title: Distinguishing Molecular Features and Clinical Characteristics of a Putative New Rhinovirus Species, Human Rhinovirus C (HRV C)
abstract: BACKGROUND: Human rhinoviruses (HRVs) are the most frequently detected pathogens in acute respiratory tract infections (ARTIs) and yet little is known about the prevalence, recurrence, structure and clinical impact of individual members. During 2007, the complete coding sequences of six previously unknown and highly divergent HRV strains were reported. To catalogue the molecular and clinical features distinguishing the divergent HRV strains, we undertook, for the first time, in silico analyses of all available polyprotein sequences and performed retrospective reviews of the medical records of cases in which variants of the prototype strain, HRV-QPM, had been detected. METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPLE FINDINGS: Genomic analyses revealed that the six divergent strains, residing within a clade we previously called HRV A2, had the shortest polyprotein of all picornaviruses investigated. Structure-based amino acid alignments identified conserved motifs shared among members of the genus Rhinovirus as well as substantive deletions and insertions unique to the divergent strains. Deletions mostly affected regions encoding proteins traditionally involved in antigenicity and serving as HRV and HEV receptor footprints. Because the HRV A2 strains cannot yet be cultured, we created homology models of predicted HRV-QPM structural proteins. In silico comparisons confirmed that HRV-QPM was most closely related to the major group HRVs. HRV-QPM was most frequently detected in infants with expiratory wheezing or persistent cough who had been admitted to hospital and required supplemental oxygen. It was the only virus detected in 65% of positive individuals. These observations contributed to an objective clinical impact ranging from mild to severe. CONCLUSIONS: The divergent strains did not meet classification requirements for any existing species of the genus Rhinovirus or Enterovirus. HRV A2 strains should be partitioned into at least one new species, putatively called Human rhinovirus C, populated by members detected with high frequency, from individuals with respiratory symptoms requiring hospital admission.

title: Common Variants in CDKN2B-AS1 Associated with Optic-Nerve Vulnerability of Glaucoma Identified by Genome-Wide Association Studies in Japanese
abstract: This article presents a genome-wide association study to identify common variants in CDKN2B-AS1, an antisense non-coding RNA that maps to the adjacent intron of the cyclin dependent kinase inhibitor 2B (CDKN2B) gene and is associated with optic nerve vulnerability in glaucoma. The comprehensive investigation was conducted among Japanese subjects and included diagnosis of 223 individuals with primary open angle glaucoma (POAG), 620 control participants from Japan Biobank, as well as 300 additional healthy controls from a US cohort. Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) reported to associate Glaucoma were included for verification of genetic loci for POAG risk. Genotyping revealed significant association between one SNP rs7221196 on chromosome 6p21 and POAG susceptibility compared to both Japanese ethnically matched and ethnically diverse controls; however, other SNPs previously suggested to be involved in Glaucoma exacebration were not confirmed by this study. These results suggest that implications regarding optic nerve vulnerability in POAG may differ depending on ethnic background, which could prove valuable in future clinical applications specifically targeting Asian populations at risk for glaucomatous neovascularization.

title: Adaptive Contact Networks Change Effective Disease Infectiousness and Dynamics
abstract: Human societies are organized in complex webs that are constantly reshaped by a social dynamic which is influenced by the information individuals have about others. Similarly, epidemic spreading may be affected by local information that makes individuals aware of the health status of their social contacts, allowing them to avoid contact with those infected and to remain in touch with the healthy. Here we study disease dynamics in finite populations in which infection occurs along the links of a dynamical contact network whose reshaping may be biased based on each individual's health status. We adopt some of the most widely used epidemiological models, investigating the impact of the reshaping of the contact network on the disease dynamics. We derive analytical results in the limit where network reshaping occurs much faster than disease spreading and demonstrate numerically that this limit extends to a much wider range of time scales than one might anticipate. Specifically, we show that from a population-level description, disease propagation in a quickly adapting network can be formulated equivalently as disease spreading on a well-mixed population but with a rescaled infectiousness. We find that for all models studied here – SI, SIS and SIR – the effective infectiousness of a disease depends on the population size, the number of infected in the population, and the capacity of healthy individuals to sever contacts with the infected. Importantly, we indicate how the use of available information hinders disease progression, either by reducing the average time required to eradicate a disease (in case recovery is possible), or by increasing the average time needed for a disease to spread to the entire population (in case recovery or immunity is impossible).

title: Blow Flies Were One of the Possible Candidates for Transmission of Highly Pathogenic H5N1 Avian Influenza Virus during the 2004 Outbreaks in Japan
abstract: This review explores the potential transmission pathways for Highly Pathogenic (HP) H5N1 Avian Influenza Virus during its emergence in Japan in 2004. Through analysing available data, this paper concludes that Blow Flies were a credible candidate of infection vector. By highlighting the ecological and geographical minutiae associated with HP H5N1 virus, we aim to illustrate how considerably Blow Flies contributed to expanding this disease’s reach throughout Asia-Pacific region after original outbreak sites at poultry farms. This report derives information from literature already published on infection rises of HP H5N1 strain due to migratory birds as well as recent development considering transmission routes through insect vectors alongside domestic fowl rearing practices adopted by farming communities across Japan precluding incidents of reintroduction post control measures in place by 2005.

title: Diagnostic Devices for Isothermal Nucleic Acid Amplification
abstract: This article presents a review of available diagnostic devices for Isothermal Nucleic Acid Amplification (INAA). The current market offers a wide range of products that can serve as accurate and efficient tools for nucleic acid diagnostics. We present an overview of the different manufacturers, designs, and performance specifications associated with these diagnostic devices so that customers can make informed decisions when selecting a product to suit their needs. Advances in INAA have resulted in greater accuracy, sensitivity and cost-effectiveness for both clinical laboratories and point-of-care settings. With various models now commercially available to meet specific requirements, we discuss how users may benefit from the selection of appropriate devices suitable for optimal accuracy in nucleic acid testing.

title: Retroviral Env Glycoprotein Trafficking and Incorporation into Virions
abstract: This paper presents new insights into the mechanism of retroviral Env glycoprotein trafficking and incorporation into virions. By using a combination of advanced imaging techniques, biochemical approaches and reverse genetics, we monitored distinct steps in protein transport from endoplasmic reticulum to plasma membrane as well as the integration of Env proteins into viral membranes during particle assembly. Our findings have revealed a novel pathway for organelle-spanning multimerization at late stages of viral entry that is necessary for efficient virus fusion with target cells via host cell surface receptors. Furthermore, this study has identified two compartments inside infected cells that are involved in Env glycoprotein trafficking namely post endosomes and recycling endosome. Ultimately, our results provide an enhanced understanding of how viruses subvert cellular energy sources to generate infectious particles capable of transmitting information between hosts efficiently for successful replication within their lifetime.

title: Immunizations in the elderly: do they live up to their promise?
abstract: This article investigates the effectiveness of immunization interventions in elderly populations. It focuses on the utility and efficacy of such vaccination strategies in improving long-term health outcomes for demographically aged individuals aged 60 or older with regards to disease prevention and well-being maintenance. Analyses encompass a review of epidemiological data, comparative analysis between cohorts of vaccinated versus unvaccinated seniors, and qualitative interviews among high risk elder demographics focusing on personal knowledge about vaccine uptake rates as per age related physiological constraints. This investigation endeavors to cover research gaps associated with this aging demographic by contributing novel findings towards current public health policy recommendations regarding proactive life course preventive medicine initiatives targeted towards elderly citizens worldwide.

title: Proteolytic processing of a precursor protein for a growth-promoting peptide by a subtilisin serine protease in Arabidopsis
abstract: Phytosulfokines (PSKs) are secreted, sulfated peptide hormones derived from larger prepropeptide precursors. Proteolytic processing of one of the precursors, AtPSK4, was demonstrated by cleavage of a preproAtPSK4–myc transgene product to AtPSK4–myc. Cleavage of proAtPSK4 was induced by placing root explants in tissue culture. The processing of proAtPSK4 was dependent on AtSBT1.1, a subtilisin-like serine protease, encoded by one of 56 subtilase genes in Arabidopsis. The gene encoding AtSBT1.1 was up-regulated following the transfer of root explants to tissue culture, suggesting that activation of the proteolytic machinery that cleaves proAtPSK4 is dependent on AtSBT1.1 expression. We also demonstrated that a fluorogenic peptide representing the putative subtilase recognition site in proAtPSK4 is cleaved in vitro by affinity-purified AtSBT1.1. An alanine scan through the recognition site peptide indicated that AtSBT1.1 is fairly specific for the AtPSK4 precursor. Thus, this peptide growth factor, which promotes callus formation in culture, is proteolytically cleaved from its precursor by a specific plant subtilase encoded by a gene that is up-regulated during the process of transfering root explants to tissue culture.

title: Protein Reporter Bioassay Systems for the Phenotypic Screening of Candidate Drugs: A Mouse Platform for Anti-Aging Drug Screening
abstract: This article explores the use of Protein Reporter Bioassay Systems as a new platform for anti-aging drug screening in mouse models. Protein Reporter Bioassays are immuno-reporter assays based on bioluminescent imaging that can detect biomarkers associated with aging and reveal how much these markers change during exposure to drug compounds. The objective of this study was to evaluate and compare the sensitivity, accuracy, specificity, reproducibility and cost-effectiveness of these systems in terms of detecting age-associated phenotypes. The data obtained from this approach could potentially open up novel therapeutic indices for developing effective personalized treatments against work diseases related to aging such as Alzheimer’s disease or cardiovascular disease, which have been proven difficult to tackle using current technology alone. Through both theoretical research and mice experiments, our assessment revealed that protein reporter bioassay systems are suitable for evaluating candidate drugs for anti-aging treatment across multiple organisms including mus musculus (mouse). Overall, we suggest that these systems utilized be used in future as an essential tool in preclinical screening studies where evaluation is required against large cohorts induced by various treatments at different ages or stages throughout life or conditions caused due to stressors due illness development through aging stage.

title: Ebola virus disease: any risk for oral and maxillo-facial surgery? An overview
abstract: The Ebolavirus Disease (EVD) has been a major global health concern for decades as it continues to cause serious illness and even death in some cases. This report investigates the potential risks posed by EVD for Oral and Maxillo-facial Surgery. By including evidence from a comprehensive literature search of pertinent studies, this overview aims to provide an updated assertion on what is known about the risk of EVD infection during oral and maxillofacial surgical interventions. A discussion of current recommended safety protocols are presented along with suggestions that may aid operative clinicians in making prudent decisions regarding their own practice. Understanding EVDs’s implications on oral surgery can potentially help surgeons make sound clinical judgements when assessing patients that would benefit from such treatment or perform necessary operations while managing patient concerns safely and reducing risk exposure among medical staff members involved in these tasks.

title: Host Modulators of H1N1 Cytopathogenicity
abstract: The novel H1N1 influenza virus re-emerged in 2009 and continues to cause substantial morbidity, mortality and economic losses worldwide. Understanding the nuances of its infection process has been a major focus for research communities over the past decade. This article investigates host modulators that act as crucial elements in regulating cytopathogenicity of H1N1 within human hosts. Using an integrated approach combining epidemiological modelling with widespread surveys across large populations, numerous physiological parameters have been evaluated using statistical models to determine their impact on overall disease severity. We present evidence that suggests dysregulation of several cytokines alongside aberrant immune responses influence the pathogenesis of H1N1 infection significantly. Furthermore, we discuss pharmacological interventions that might dampen this pro-inflammatory response while preserving essential T cell functions which govern protection against secondary infections or recurrence in newly infected individuals after recovery from primary infection.

title: Label-Free Electrochemical Diagnosis of Viral Antigens with Genetically Engineered Fusion Protein
abstract: This paper presents a novel methodology for label-free electrochemical diagnosis of viral antigens using genetically engineered fusion proteins. The method involves the combination of single protein domains with different recognition elements to create a unique cellulase/antibody hybrid enzyme. By targeting and bonding to specific antigen molecules, this hybrid enzyme can rapidly detect and distinguish viral antigens in samples without any additional labels or dyes. This study offers a major technical advance for disease diagnostics due to its potentials for point-of-care testing at low cost and high sensitivity. To validate the robustness of this new assay, multiple validation tests were carried out on five different pathogenic viruses showing good agreement with reference values in all cases. Overall, our findings demonstrate that this new label-free technique provides reliable data in an efficient manner necessary to enable outbreaks' monitoring at early stages while addressing the global needs in point-of care detection systems of infectious diseases.

title: Bacteriophage T7 morphogenesis and gene 10 frameshifting in Escherichia coli showing different degrees of ribosomal fidelity
abstract: This study examines the effects of bacteriophage T7 morphogenesis and frameshifting at gene 10 on ribosomal fidelity in Escherichia coli. Bacteria, one of the oldest forms of life, are continuously challenged by invading viruses known as phages. While some phages can be beneficial to bacteria, others such as T7 bring about changes that lead to localized infection or death for their hosts. We studied current literature describing potential impacts of T7 which is known to cause mutations via frameshifting following DNA replication in E.coli specifically at gene 10 located on the large chromosome. Results from our experiment show that change made with respect to rate-limiting energy generated during translation through shifts in ribosome structure varies depending upon local conditions encountered by the cell when under attack by T7 Abrupt transitions between open and closed states occurring through reorganization within affected parts of a given chromosome increase risks associated with misreading genetic code resulting in production of improperly broken down proteins leading eventually to disruption mutation profiles found within various segments making up bacterial genome showing different degrees of efficiency related particularly contrasting performances observed with respect universally accepted measures determining positional accuracy occur accordingly throughout densest collection mRNA codons present along strands hence used herein constrain sequence assembly existing definitive frame we hypothesized when specific thresholds become exceeded an increased number defective ca probiotic delivery systems able deliver compatible coatings engineered facilitate non pathogenic susceptibilities this metagenomes value demonstrated needs further research extend understanding functioning protein synthesis ribosometry discuss implications future development reactive pharmacological vectors potentially attenuation colonization strong pathogens elsewhere contributing general public health .

title: Lethal Nipah Virus Infection Induces Rapid Overexpression of CXCL10
abstract: The lethal Nipah virus, first identified in Malaysia in 1998 and now globalized, is a zoonotic pathogen for humans. This study focuses on the remarkable rapid over-expression of CXCL10—chemokine ligand 10—in individuals affected by the virus. Using cell culture models coupled with highly sensitive ELISA assays, we demonstrated that exposure to nipah mediated through silent transmission systems such as aerosols or respiratory secretions triggers cellular response pathways leading to increased production of CXCL10. Our results emphasize an urgent need to develop targeted therapies that target not only the Nipah virus but also this upregulated chemokine secretion pathway associated with fatal infection symptoms. We propose a prophylactic strategy combined with extensive vaccination programs which may reduce human exposure and deaths due to Nipah Virus Infection.

title: Hypoxia-regulated target genes implicated in tumor metastasis
abstract: Hypoxia, a state of reduced oxygen concentrations in the environment, has long been attributed to tumor progression and metastasis. In this study, we investigate the role of hypoxia-regulated target genes in these two processes. Using an innovative array-based technique we identified 15 target genes which were differentially expressed under low oxygen concentrations associated with tumor tissues compared to normal conditions. After further experimentation, it became evident that these targets are integral components of signal transduction pathways involved in cell proliferation, invasion and migration - core functions driving tumor progression and metastasis. We thus show that altering gene expression levels according to hypoxia could signal unfavorable conditions conducive to potentially malignant cells gain autonomy over their niche through uncontrolled growth and movement into other areas of the body leading to cancer spread.

title: Childhood Tuberculosis Presenting with Haemophagocytic Syndrome
abstract: This study examines the case of a six-year-old child with an atypical presentation of tuberculosis and associated haemophagocytic syndrome (HPS). The investigations showed that childhood tuberculosis in a low endemic country was complicated by HPS, transformed into macrophage activation syndrome (MAS) after immunosuppressive treatment. This paper aims to define the clinical features at diagnosis, discuss unconventional presentations and highlight management challenges for subspecialists treating MAS patients. Further research is required to identify genetic associations between MAS/HPS reactivation due to emerging primary infections such as tuberculous mycobacteria or other pathogens triggering TB‐like clinical manifestations.

title: Effects of Pulsed Electromagnetic Fields on Human Osteoblastlike Cells (MG-63): A Pilot Study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although pulsed electromagnetic fields (PEMFs) are used to treat delayed unions and nonunions, their mechanisms of action are not completely clear. However, PEMFs are known to affect the expression of certain genes. QUESTIONS/PURPOSES: We asked (1) whether PEMFs affect gene expression in human osteoblastlike cells (MG63) in vitro, and (2) whether and to what extent stimulation by PEMFs induce cell proliferation and differentiation in MG-63 cultures. METHODS: We cultured two groups of MG63 cells. One group was treated with PEMFs for 18 hours whereas the second was maintained in the same culture condition without PEMFs (control). Gene expression was evaluated throughout cDNA microarray analysis containing 19,000 genes spanning a substantial fraction of the human genome. RESULTS: PEMFs induced the upregulation of important genes related to bone formation (HOXA10, AKT1), genes at the transductional level (CALM1, P2RX7), genes for cytoskeletal components (FN1, VCL), and collagenous (COL1A2) and noncollagenous (SPARC) matrix components. However, PEMF induced downregulation of genes related to the degradation of extracellular matrix (MMP-11, DUSP4). CONCLUSIONS AND CLINICAL RELEVANCE: PEMFs appear to induce cell proliferation and differentiation. Furthermore, PEMFs promote extracellular matrix production and mineralization while decreasing matrix degradation and absorption. Our data suggest specific mechanisms of the observed clinical effect of PEMFs, and thus specific approaches for use in regenerative medicine.

title: Advances in the diagnosis and management of influenza
abstract: This paper reviews recent advances in the diagnosis and management of influenza. With the ever-increasing prevalence of the pandemic caused by multiple subgroups of Influenza A, it has become essential to develop a better understanding of clinical and laboratory techniques for diagnosis as well as optimizing treatments. Clinical manifestations and epidemiological considerations are discussed, based on research conducted over several years across multiple countries. Challenges such as lack of access to vaccination, delayed diagnosis due to non-specific symptoms, drug resistance among strains, persistent cases despite existing therapeutics warrant further exploration. The review also highlights opportunities for healthcare intervention strategies utilizing immunization and antiviral drugs along with effective public health policies. In conclusion this paper provides an overview regarding important updates in recognition, investigation and interventions related to influenza infections worldwide in order to aid clinicians diagnose accurately in time and optimally manage patients who have or at risk from infection.

title: Communicable Diseases Prioritized for Surveillance and Epidemiological Research: Results of a Standardized Prioritization Procedure in Germany, 2011
abstract: This paper describes the results of standardized prioritization procedure utilized to identify communicable diseases for surveillance and epidemiological research in Germany, 2011. For this purpose, 51 diseases were assigned four risk factors including disease burden, infectivity rate, control measures available and implications for public health response. After evaluating these criteria using a multicriteria decision analysis (MCDA) tool which was supported by evidentiary information from statistical databases and literature review, 8 diseases emerged as priority cases ranging briefly from tuberculosis to HIV/AIDS etc. This MCDA-based methodology could help allocate resources effectively providing a broader insight in terms of improving strategies concerned with infection control specifically in Germany. By adopting a systematic evidence-based approach it can contribute towards prioritizations of future threats.

title: Bayesian Phylogeography Finds Its Roots
abstract: As a key factor in endemic and epidemic dynamics, the geographical distribution of viruses has been frequently interpreted in the light of their genetic histories. Unfortunately, inference of historical dispersal or migration patterns of viruses has mainly been restricted to model-free heuristic approaches that provide little insight into the temporal setting of the spatial dynamics. The introduction of probabilistic models of evolution, however, offers unique opportunities to engage in this statistical endeavor. Here we introduce a Bayesian framework for inference, visualization and hypothesis testing of phylogeographic history. By implementing character mapping in a Bayesian software that samples time-scaled phylogenies, we enable the reconstruction of timed viral dispersal patterns while accommodating phylogenetic uncertainty. Standard Markov model inference is extended with a stochastic search variable selection procedure that identifies the parsimonious descriptions of the diffusion process. In addition, we propose priors that can incorporate geographical sampling distributions or characterize alternative hypotheses about the spatial dynamics. To visualize the spatial and temporal information, we summarize inferences using virtual globe software. We describe how Bayesian phylogeography compares with previous parsimony analysis in the investigation of the influenza A H5N1 origin and H5N1 epidemiological linkage among sampling localities. Analysis of rabies in West African dog populations reveals how virus diffusion may enable endemic maintenance through continuous epidemic cycles. From these analyses, we conclude that our phylogeographic framework will make an important asset in molecular epidemiology that can be easily generalized to infer biogeogeography from genetic data for many organisms.

title: A Single Residue Substitution in the Receptor-Binding Domain of H5N1 Hemagglutinin Is Critical for Packaging into Pseudotyped Lentiviral Particles
abstract: The research paper, titled 'A Single Residue Substitution in the Receptor-Binding Domain of H5N1 Hemagglutinin Is Critical for Packaging into Pseudotyped Lentiviral Particles', presents an extensive evaluation resulting from a substitution mutation of the receptor-binding domain in avian influenza virus. By using genetic engineering techniques to substitute specific sites within the receptor binding domain, the researchers were able to identify and confer efficient pseudovirion packaging that can be used as a tool for vaccine development. This study outlines multiple observations conducted on lentivirus pseudotypes containing substituted strains of wild type or mutant haemagglutinin genes from conserving both vector capacity/functionality and antigenic properties desired for developing effective vaccines. Furthermore, it confirms how these pseudo viruses modified with a single residue substitution at 13 amino acids position located in HR2 region constitute rare finding that help explains how wide range polarizing substitutions are critical for maintaining viral functioning upon minimal changes . The conclusion of this analysis contributes important insights towards enhancing virus structure stability through small mutational modifications which will aid our understanding on following designs intended to improve functional capabilities upscaled production

title: Hybridization properties of long nucleic acid probes for detection of variable target sequences, and development of a hybridization prediction algorithm
abstract: One of the main problems in nucleic acid-based techniques for detection of infectious agents, such as influenza viruses, is that of nucleic acid sequence variation. DNA probes, 70-nt long, some including the nucleotide analog deoxyribose-Inosine (dInosine), were analyzed for hybridization tolerance to different amounts and distributions of mismatching bases, e.g. synonymous mutations, in target DNA. Microsphere-linked 70-mer probes were hybridized in 3M TMAC buffer to biotinylated single-stranded (ss) DNA for subsequent analysis in a Luminex® system. When mismatches interrupted contiguous matching stretches of 6 nt or longer, it had a strong impact on hybridization. Contiguous matching stretches are more important than the same number of matching nucleotides separated by mismatches into several regions. dInosine, but not 5-nitroindole, substitutions at mismatching positions stabilized hybridization remarkably well, comparable to N (4-fold) wobbles in the same positions. In contrast to shorter probes, 70-nt probes with judiciously placed dInosine substitutions and/or wobble positions were remarkably mismatch tolerant, with preserved specificity. An algorithm, NucZip, was constructed to model the nucleation and zipping phases of hybridization, integrating both local and distant binding contributions. It predicted hybridization more exactly than previous algorithms, and has the potential to guide the design of variation-tolerant yet specific probes.

title: Genomic Signatures of Strain Selection and Enhancement in Bacillus atrophaeus var. globigii, a Historical Biowarfare Simulant
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite the decades-long use of Bacillus atrophaeus var. globigii (BG) as a simulant for biological warfare (BW) agents, knowledge of its genome composition is limited. Furthermore, the ability to differentiate signatures of deliberate adaptation and selection from natural variation is lacking for most bacterial agents. We characterized a lineage of BGwith a long history of use as a simulant for BW operations, focusing on classical bacteriological markers, metabolic profiling and whole-genome shotgun sequencing (WGS). RESULTS: Archival strains and two “present day” type strains were compared to simulant strains on different laboratory media. Several of the samples produced multiple colony morphotypes that differed from that of an archival isolate. To trace the microevolutionary history of these isolates, we obtained WGS data for several archival and present-day strains and morphotypes. Bacillus-wide phylogenetic analysis identified B. subtilis as the nearest neighbor to B. atrophaeus. The genome of B. atrophaeus is, on average, 86% identical to B. subtilis on the nucleotide level. WGS of variants revealed that several strains were mixed but highly related populations and uncovered a progressive accumulation of mutations among the “military” isolates. Metabolic profiling and microscopic examination of bacterial cultures revealed enhanced growth of “military” isolates on lactate-containing media, and showed that the “military” strains exhibited a hypersporulating phenotype. CONCLUSIONS: Our analysis revealed the genomic and phenotypic signatures of strain adaptation and deliberate selection for traits that were desirable in a simulant organism. Together, these results demonstrate the power of whole-genome and modern systems-level approaches to characterize microbial lineages to develop and validate forensic markers for strain discrimination and reveal signatures of deliberate adaptation.

title: Antibody-Based HIV-1 Vaccines: Recent Developments and Future Directions: A summary report from a Global HIV Vaccine Enterprise Working Group
abstract: The authors discuss humoral immune responses to HIV and approaches to designing vaccines that induce viral neutralizing and other potentially protective antibodies.

title: Induction of GADD34 Is Necessary for dsRNA-Dependent Interferon-β Production and Participates in the Control of Chikungunya Virus Infection
abstract: “Induction of GADD34 Is Necessary for dsRNA-Dependent Interferon-β Production and Participates in the Control of Chikungunya Virus Infection” investigates how cellular proteins coordinate responses to chikungunya virus (CHIKV) infections. The growth kinetics and dynamics between CHIKVs and the host organism is complex; however, a specific type of protein known as GADD34 has emerged as particularly relevant. Using a combination of reverse genetics, biochemical assays, cell cultures, lentiviral expression technology and CRISPR/Cas9 engineering this study determined that induction of GADD34 facilitates viral sensing via an interferon signaling pathway upon recognition of double stranded RNA (dsRNA). Upon successful induction it was observed that GADD34 supports sustained antiviral efficacy through exacerbation of multiple viruses including CHIKV. Consequently these findings suggest that this studied protein could serve as novel drug target in order to create effective antiviral treatments for CHIKV infection.

title: Low-Cost HIV-1 Diagnosis and Quantification in Dried Blood Spots by Real Time PCR
abstract: BACKGROUND: Rapid and cost-effective methods for HIV-1 diagnosis and viral load monitoring would greatly enhance the clinical management of HIV-1 infected adults and children in limited-resource settings. Recent recommendations to treat perinatally infected infants within the first year of life are feasible only if early diagnosis is routinely available. Dried blood spots (DBS) on filter paper are an easy and convenient way to collect and transport blood samples. A rapid and cost effective method to diagnose and quantify HIV-1 from DBS is urgently needed to facilitate early diagnosis of HIV-1 infection and monitoring of antiretroviral therapy. METHODS AND FINDINGS: We have developed a real-time LightCycler (rtLC) PCR assay to detect and quantify HIV-1 from DBS. HIV-1 RNA extracted from DBS was amplified in a one-step, single-tube system using primers specific for long-terminal repeat sequences that are conserved across all HIV-1 clades. SYBR Green dye was used to quantify PCR amplicons and HIV-1 RNA copy numbers were determined from a standard curve generated using serially diluted known copies of HIV-1 RNA. This assay detected samples across clades, has a dynamic range of 5 log(10), and %CV <8% up to 4 log(10) dilution. Plasma HIV-1 RNA copy numbers obtained using this method correlated well with the Roche Ultrasensitive (r = 0.91) and branched DNA (r = 0.89) assays. The lower limit of detection (95%) was estimated to be 136 copies. The rtLC DBS assay was 2.5 fold rapid as well as 40-fold cheaper when compared to commercial assays. Adaptation of the assay into other real-time systems demonstrated similar performance. CONCLUSIONS: The accuracy, reliability, genotype inclusivity and affordability, along with the small volumes of blood required for the assay suggest that the rtLC DBS assay will be useful for early diagnosis and monitoring of pediatric HIV-1 infection in resource-limited settings.

title: Wearing face masks in public during the influenza season may reflect other positive hygiene practices in Japan
abstract:
The purpose of this study is to identify if wearing face masks in public during the influenza season reflects other positive hygiene practices among adults in Japan. It has long been thought that the practice of wearing masks is a reflection of societal norms, with some perceiving it as an indication of heightened attention to hygiene. This study aims to analyze the correlations between mask use and habits such as frequent hand-washing or avoiding shared food items at meal times from adult survey respondents aged 20-65 within Nara prefecture in Japan over two different influenza seasons (2018/19 & 2019/20). Our results indicate that Japanese adults who reported regularly wearing a face covering also tended to report more positive hygienic behaviours than those who did not wear one. Furthermore, significant differences were observed during periods when influenza outbreaks are elevated compared to seasons without increased virus circulation. Thus these data serve as evidence that facial coverings may be related to greater awareness towards infection prevention measures among individuals in this particular area which can inform future health policy decisions relevant for similar locations particularly within periods when coronavirus begins circulating again throughout communities. 

Wearing Face Masks In Public During The Influenza Season May Reflect Other Positive Hygiene Practices In Japan

title: Viral Proteins Acquired from a Host Converge to Simplified Domain Architectures
abstract: Viruses have been rapidly evolving their protein architectures since the first identification facilitated by structural biology-based approaches. The objective of this paper is to investigate how viruses acquire complex functional protein domains from hosts during pathogenesis and through evolutionary processes, with a focus on discovering any simplification in the acquired architectures. Our research centers around answering two questions: (1) How do viruses obtain highly structured noncoding sequence elements from their host genomes? and (2) Does obtaining those novel structures converge towards more simplified designs over time? Through the use of robust modeling techniques based within molecular dynamics simulations, phylogenetic trees analysis & pattern recognition analysis we elucidate our suppositions about how proteins are acquired and subsequently adapted into modified domain structures. By utilizing numerous real world examples, as well as data gathered form multiple biological studies, such as genomics of virus-host interactions, results designate proteins gaining an architecture far simpler than what was formerly observed; displaying that viral design has not only advanced but be refined over tangible time periods. With findings further proving this phenomenon can be universally applied to all known families; Viral Proteins Acquired From a Host Converge To Simplified Domain Architectures promises intriguing implications surrounding the advancement in biochemical understanding within infective agents  enhancing future discourse between virologists in the effort towards combative treatments against deadly infectious diseases

title: Protective Immunity to Listeria Monocytogenes Infection Mediated by Recombinant Listeria innocua Harboring the VGC Locus
abstract: This study presents a new approach to developing protective immunity against Listeria monocytogenes infections by harnessing the power of genetically modified bacteria. The research team explored the potential of recombinant non-pathogenic Listeria innocua harboring vgc loci as an effective immunization strategy and how this novel vaccination could contribute to improved vaccine efficacy, specificity, and safety in humans. Research on mice demonstrated that the delivered inoculum conferred enhanced resistance to challenge with virulent strains of Listeria monocytogenes compared to conventional vaccines currently available. This promising result suggests that further development of this novel immunization technique could be highly beneficial for public health intervention strategies offering protection from listeriosis infection.

title: Immune Response to Lactobacillus plantarum Expressing Borrelia burgdorferi OspA Is Modulated by the Lipid Modification of the Antigen
abstract: BACKGROUND: Over the past decade there has been increasing interest in the use of lactic acid bacteria as mucosal delivery vehicles for vaccine antigens, microbicides and therapeutics. We investigated the mechanism by which a mucosal vaccine based in recombinant lactic acid bacteria breaks the immunological tolerance of the gut in order to elicit a protective immune response. METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS: We analyzed how the lipid modification of OspA affects the localization of the antigen in our delivery vehicle using a number of biochemistry techniques. Furthermore, we examined how OspA-expressing L. plantarum breaks the oral tolerance of the gut by stimulating human intestinal epithelial cells, peripheral blood mononuclear cells and monocyte derived dendritic cells and measuring cytokine production. We show that the leader peptide of OspA targets the protein to the cell envelope of L. plantarum, and it is responsible for protein export across the membrane. Mutation of the lipidation site in OspA redirects protein localization within the cell envelope. Further, we show that lipidated-OspA-expressing L. plantarum does not induce secretion of the pro-inflammatory cytokine IL-8 by intestinal epithelial cells. In addition, it breaks oral tolerance of the gut via Th1/Th2 cell mediated immunity, as shown by the production of pro- and anti-inflammatory cytokines by human dendritic cells, and by the production of IgG2a and IgG1 antibodies, respectively. CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE: Lipid modification of OspA expressed in L. plantarum modulates the immune response to this antigen through a Th1/Th2 immune response.

title: Time-series analysis in imatinib-resistant chronic myeloid leukemia K562-cells under different drug treatments
abstract: Time-series analysis of imatinib-resistant chronic myeloid leukemia K562-cells under different drug treatments is an important research topic in the field of cancer biology. Imatinib, a targeted inhibitor, confers acquired resistance in K562 cells upon extended treatment against progressive human chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML). In order to better understand the biological basis underlying such behaviour and study potential novel treatments to counter this effect, this research aims to observe the temporal evolution of gene expression levels following diverse treatments utilizing long time series data obtained from imatinib resistant CML K562 cell lines. The results generated by this technique will be compared with baseline states for each patient's original CML phenotype as well as other therapies employed on them. This comparison would provide insights regarding which drugs are most effective at treating the advanced stages of CML and preventing relapse. These valuable findings may accelerate progress towards developing a more refined personalized approach to anti-cancer therapy, thus providing essential assistance for medical practitioners struggling to improve quality of life for elderly or terminally ill patients requiring constant medication regimes and intensive monitoring regimens.

title: Severe Childhood Malaria Syndromes Defined by Plasma Proteome Profiles
abstract: This study examines the use of plasma proteome profiling to define severe childhood malaria syndromes. Recent advances in mass spectrometry and data analysis techniques have enabled comprehensive characterization of the proteins present in a biological sample, making proteomics an attractive strategy for accurate diagnosis and prognosis of disease states. This work is particularly relevant for diagnosing severe forms of malaria associated with high mortality rates among young children in endemic regions. We therefore analyzed baseline plasma samples from 80 acutely ill African children with highly-pathogenic Plasmodium falciparum infection, distinguishing between those with uncomplicated or complicated malaria syndromes using multi-parametric measurements composed by clinical features, hematological parameters and protein expression profiles derived from pyrosequencing assays prepared on blood spot cards. Our results demonstrate that it is feasible to identify unique plasma proteomes that are biomarkers for several severe malaria syndromes including cerebral malarial encephalopathy (CME). Furthermore, our findings underpin potential strategies for identifying more broadly defined subtypes relative to both demographic factors as well as other concurrent infections prevalent within these endemic populations.

title: A Statistical Framework for the Adaptive Management of Epidemiological Interventions
abstract: BACKGROUND: Epidemiological interventions aim to control the spread of infectious disease through various mechanisms, each carrying a different associated cost. METHODOLOGY: We describe a flexible statistical framework for generating optimal epidemiological interventions that are designed to minimize the total expected cost of an emerging epidemic while simultaneously propagating uncertainty regarding the underlying disease model parameters through to the decision process. The strategies produced through this framework are adaptive: vaccination schedules are iteratively adjusted to reflect the anticipated trajectory of the epidemic given the current population state and updated parameter estimates. CONCLUSIONS: Using simulation studies based on a classic influenza outbreak, we demonstrate the advantages of adaptive interventions over non-adaptive ones, in terms of cost and resource efficiency, and robustness to model misspecification.

title: Examining the knowledge, attitudes and practices of domestic and international university students towards seasonal and pandemic influenza
abstract: This paper is about examining the knowledge, attitudes and practices of domestic and international university students towards seasonal and pandemic influenza. Research has suggested that university populations are at a high risk of contracting infectious diseases such as seasonal or pandemic influenza due to their close contact with international classmates, sharing of public areas and dormitories, lack of hygiene education, overcrowded living conditions, long hours spent indoors studying in libraries, etc. This research seeks to identify what domestic and international university students currently know about influenza viruses (both seasonal and pandemic), how they perceive it both personally as well as public health wise – what sort of preventive measures they practice both professionally (on-campus) and domestically; , whether or not they feel anxiety regarding an outbreak on campus; if different ethnicities/cultural backgrounds would alter these perceptions. The goal is to evaluate existing beliefs concerning flu vaccines so that better targeted strategies may be formulated for universities aiming to reduce their student population’s vulnerability from contracting any form of the virus in order to increase awareness levels during outbreaks - prevent transmission one person to another. Data will include semi-structured interviews with facial expressions among a representative sample size ranging from 1000 domestically stationed undergraduates across each state in Australia alongside other qualitative data gathered via an online survey targeting 500 international undergraduate exchange students based at three Universities - Monash University Malaysia, Murdoch University Dubai & Queensland University Singapore Campus over 6 months period..

title: Development of a Humanized Antibody with High Therapeutic Potential against Dengue Virus Type 2
abstract: This study presents the development of a humanized antibody for therapeutic potential against Dengue virus type 2 (DENV2). The research is based on an approach employing advanced molecular engineering techniques to modify IgG antibodies and optimize their binding affinity to viral antigens. We evaluated the efficacy of these engineered variants and determined their structural conformation using X-ray crystallography. The results show that despite possessing highly complex yet stable conformations, all four antibodies bind specifically to DENV2 antigen with nanomolar affinities, paving the way for novel clinical applications in areas such as control and prevention of chronic diseases caused by related virus strains. Meanwhile, we also measured antiviral activity endpoint assays whereby each variant demonstrated remarkable anti-viral potential in vivo with high precision. In conclusion, this work marks a major milestone in understanding DENV2 pathogenesis on detailed level and lays out evidence for elaborated vaccine design or immunotherapeutic drug formulation with improved potency against other related disease causing viruses.

title: Recode-2: new design, new search tools, and many more genes
abstract: ‘Recoding’ is a term used to describe non-standard read-out of the genetic code, and encompasses such phenomena as programmed ribosomal frameshifting, stop codon readthrough, selenocysteine insertion and translational bypassing. Although only a small proportion of genes utilize recoding in protein synthesis, accurate annotation of ‘recoded’ genes lags far behind annotation of ‘standard’ genes. In order to address this issue, provide a service to researchers in the field, and offer training data for developers of gene-annotation software, we have gathered together known cases of recoding within the Recode database. Recode-2 is an improved and updated version of the database. It provides access to detailed information on genes known to utilize translational recoding and allows complex search queries, browsing of recoding data and enhanced visualization of annotated sequence elements. At present, the Recode-2 database stores information on approximately 1500 genes that are known to utilize recoding in their expression—a factor of approximately three increase over the previous version of the database. Recode-2 is available at http://recode.ucc.ie

title: Dengue Virus Infection Perturbs Lipid Homeostasis in Infected Mosquito Cells
abstract: The dengue virus (DENV) is an arbovirus and a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, largely due to its ability to cause severe clinical symptoms in humans. However, the means by which DENV exerts pathogenesis within infected cells remains poorly understood. In this study, we aimed to determine whether virus infection perturbs lipid metabolism in mosquito cell lines that act as vector hosts for the transmission cycle of DENV. Lipidomic analyses revealed drastically altered levels of lipids associated with DENV-infection, indicating dramatic disruption in cellular homeostasis caused by viral intrusion into mosquito cells. Collectively our findings provide insight on how infected mosquitoes may be metabolically handicapped during the acute stages of virus infection thus altering their capacity for transmitting arboviruses like DENV – an important factor contributing to epidemiology globally. Dengue Virus Infection Perturbs Lipid Homeostasis in Infected Mosquito Cells

title: Quantitative Phosphoproteomics of Proteasome Inhibition in Multiple Myeloma Cells
abstract: BACKGROUND: The proteasome inhibitor bortezomib represents an important advance in the treatment of multiple myeloma (MM). Bortezomib inhibits the activity of the 26S proteasome and induces cell death in a variety of tumor cells; however, the mechanism of cytotoxicity is not well understood. METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS: We investigated the differential phosphoproteome upon proteasome inhibition by using stable isotope labeling by amino acids in cell culture (SILAC) in combination with phosphoprotein enrichment and LC-MS/MS analysis. In total 233 phosphoproteins were identified and 72 phosphoproteins showed a 1.5-fold or greater change upon bortezomib treatment. The phosphoproteins with expression alterations encompass all major protein classes, including a large number of nucleic acid binding proteins. Site-specific phosphopeptide quantitation revealed that Ser38 phosphorylation on stathmin increased upon bortezomib treatment, suggesting new mechanisms associated to bortezomib-induced apoptosis in MM cells. Further studies demonstrated that stathmin phosphorylation profile was modified in response to bortezomib treatment and the regulation of stathmin by phosphorylation at specific Ser/Thr residues participated in the cellular response induced by bortezomib. CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE: Our systematic profiling of phosphorylation changes in response to bortezomib treatment not only advanced the global mechanistic understanding of the action of bortezomib on myeloma cells but also identified previously uncharacterized signaling proteins in myeloma cells.

title: Binding of HIV-1 gp120 to DC-SIGN Promotes ASK-1-Dependent Activation-Induced Apoptosis of Human Dendritic Cells
abstract: This paper describes the consequences of HIV-1 gp120 binding to DC-SIGN when expressed on human dendritic cells. Specifically, it elucidates how this process leads to a novel form of activation-induced apoptosis through ASK-1-dependent pathways. By elucidating molecular events during the binding and biochemical changes associated with cell death and signaling cascades, this paper promises insight into the basic physiological principles underlying DC homeostasis under viral invasion and immune regulation in health and disease states. Detailed studies quantifying these endpoints will provide opportunity for developing new therapeutic approaches as well as preventive strategies against immunodeficiencies associated with HIV infection.

title: Design Novel Dual Agonists for Treating Type-2 Diabetes by Targeting Peroxisome Proliferator-Activated Receptors with Core Hopping Approach
abstract: This study seeks to propose a dual agonist drug design approach for treating type-2 diabetes by targeting peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs) using core hopping. The burden of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) is increasing global public health problem due to the modern sedentary lifestyle and an unbalanced diet. Over recent decade, treatments including antidiabetic agents such as PPARγ agonists have been introduced in this scenario, yet durable therapeutic effects are mostly not achieved with long-term usage accompanied by unwanted toxic side effects. To address these challenges, here we present our concept of utilizing merotonic core hopping strategy for designing dual selective PPARγδ/α ligands using molecular docking simulations combined with the synergistic effect based pharmacophoric score analysis technique. Optimized compounds will be further tested in vitro systems before moving into tests on animal models due to their relatively specific binding profiles towards PPAR subtypes compared with traditional ligands or panagonists. Ultimately this research should contribute novel insights about how multi-drug treatment is more potent than single therapy against DM.

title: Electron Tomography Reveals the Steps in Filovirus Budding
abstract: The filoviruses, Marburg and Ebola, are non-segmented negative-strand RNA viruses causing severe hemorrhagic fever with high mortality rates in humans and nonhuman primates. The sequence of events that leads to release of filovirus particles from cells is poorly understood. Two contrasting mechanisms have been proposed, one proceeding via a “submarine-like” budding with the helical nucleocapsid emerging parallel to the plasma membrane, and the other via perpendicular “rocket-like” protrusion. Here we have infected cells with Marburg virus under BSL-4 containment conditions, and reconstructed the sequence of steps in the budding process in three dimensions using electron tomography of plastic-embedded cells. We find that highly infectious filamentous particles are released at early stages in infection. Budding proceeds via lateral association of intracellular nucleocapsid along its whole length with the plasma membrane, followed by rapid envelopment initiated at one end of the nucleocapsid, leading to a protruding intermediate. Scission results in local membrane instability at the rear of the virus.
