After prolonged infection, increased vesiculation of the plasma membrane correlates with changes in shape and infectivity of released viruses. Our observations demonstrate a cellular determinant of virus shape. They reconcile the contrasting models of filovirus budding and allow us to describe the sequence of events taking place during budding and release of Marburg virus. We propose that this represents a general sequence of events also followed by other filamentous and rod-shaped viruses.

title: Prolonged extracorporeal membrane oxygenation therapy for severe acute respiratory distress syndrome in a child affected by rituximab-resistant autoimmune hemolytic anemia: a case report
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia in children younger than 2 years of age is usually characterized by a severe course, with a mortality rate of approximately 10%. The prolonged immunosuppression following specific treatment may be associated with a high risk of developing severe infections. Recently, the use of monoclonal antibodies (rituximab) has allowed sustained remissions to be obtained in the majority of pediatric patients with refractory autoimmune hemolytic anemia. CASE PRESENTATION: We describe the case of an 8-month-old Caucasian girl affected by a severe form of autoimmune hemolytic anemia, which required continuous steroid treatment for 16 months. Thereafter, she received 4 weekly doses of rituximab (375 mg/m(2)/dose) associated with steroid therapy, which was then tapered over the subsequent 2 weeks. One month after the last dose of rrituximab, she presented with recurrence of severe hemolysis and received two more doses of rrituximab. The patient remained in clinical remission for 7 months, before presenting with a further relapse. An alternative heavy immunosuppressive therapy was administered combining cyclophosphamide 10 mg/kg/day for 10 days with methylprednisolone 40 mg/kg/day for 5 days, which was then tapered down over 3 weeks. While still on steroid therapy, the patient developed an interstitial pneumonia with Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome, which required immediate admission to the intensive care unit where extracorporeal membrane oxygenation therapy was administered continuously for 37 days. At 16-month follow-up, the patient is alive and in good clinical condition, with no organ dysfunction, free from any immunosuppressive treatment and with a normal Hb level. CONCLUSIONS: This case shows that aggressive combined immunosuppressive therapy may lead to a sustained complete remission in children with refractory autoimmune hemolytic anemia. However, the severe life-threatening complication presented by our patient indicates that strict clinical monitoring must be vigilantly performed, that antimicrobial prophylaxis should always be considered and that experienced medical and nursing staff must be available, to deliver highly specialized supportive salvage therapies, if necessary, during intensive care monitoring.

title: Structural Origins for the Loss of Catalytic Activities of Bifunctional Human LTA4H Revealed through Molecular Dynamics Simulations
abstract: This article presents an in-depth study of the structural origins for the loss of catalytic activities in human leukotriene A4 hydrolase (LTA4H). Using advanced molecular dynamics simulations, this research offers a comprehensive investigation into how mutations at key sites lead to different functional outcomes and potential therapeutic strategies. Through a systematic analysis of mutation events in LTA4H, combined with essential biochemical properties, atomic force spectroscopy measurements and linear free energy relationships, the authors have developed predictive models that reveal realistic mechanisms associated with catalysis optimization and deactivation. This critical insight provides invaluable information for developing novel drugs targeting LTA4H enzyme activity related diseases such as asthma and allergies.

title: Using Support Vector Machine and Evolutionary Profiles to Predict Antifreeze Protein Sequences
abstract: This study introduces a newly developed method to predict and analyze Antifreeze Protein (AFP) sequence using Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Evolutionary Profiles. The source of AFPs is an important factor for the evaluation of these proteins' promotion as cryoprotectants, as many organisms living in subzero temperatures have adapted to their extreme environment by producing diverse variants of such molecules. We applied both SVM-based method and evolutionary profile analysis with back-propagation network toward the development of algorithms that can reliably assess related protein data and modeled this system against a comprehensive collection of known antifreeze sequences. Our results showed an improved accuracy rate on predicting AFP sequences relative to existing programs, thus offering greater insight into the characteristics behind these naturally occurring cold adaptors.

title: Influenza in Refugees on the Thailand–Myanmar Border, May–October 2009
abstract: This study presents an analysis of the prevalence of influenza amongst refugees on the Thailand-Myanmar border during the period May to October 2009. Through a survey and laboratory testing, we determined that among 1,082 registered refugee households, there were 270 cases (25%) ranging from mild symptoms of seasonal influenza A & B. Among those infected with influenza virus only 48 received adequate treatment consisting of antiviral medications, rest and fluids. The results suggest inadequate healthcare infrastructure for refugees in rural areas such as these without access to vaccinations or appropriate treatments for acute infections like influenza. Our findings highlight the need for increased focus on preventive healthcare measures among migrant populations living in conflict settings worldwide.

title: Prevalence of human herpesvirus 6 antibodies and DNA in allogeneic stem cell transplant patients: two-year single centre experience
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) has been recognized as a potentially significant pathogen in hemopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) recipients. Different clinical manifestations have been described, including fever, skin rash, bone marrow suppression, and encephalitis. MATERIALS AND METHODS: A retrospective review of a group of 26 adult recipients of allogeneic HSCTs was conducted. Serum samples taken before transplant were examined for the presence of specific anti-HHV-6 IgM and IgG antibodies. After transplantation, quantitative real-time PCR was used to determine viral load in plasma samples from days 0–80 post-transplant. RESULTS: HHV-6 DNA was detected in plasma samples in 8 (30%) of the 26 recipients between days 18 and 40 after transplantation. All of them developed fever of unknown origin and over 50% had graft-versus-host disease features. Three individuals from this group died during detectable HHV-6 viremia. Another two recipients showed a single positive PCR result at a later time. Infection with HHV-6 was thus confirmed in 10 (38.5%) of the 26 graft recipients. CONCLUSIONS: There is a high frequency of detectable HHV-6 viral load in stem cell transplant recipients in Poland. Further investigation to monitor HHV-6 reactivation in graft recipients will be important to improve outcome for these patients.

title: Structural Optimization and De Novo Design of Dengue Virus Entry Inhibitory Peptides
abstract: Viral fusogenic envelope proteins are important targets for the development of inhibitors of viral entry. We report an approach for the computational design of peptide inhibitors of the dengue 2 virus (DENV-2) envelope (E) protein using high-resolution structural data from a pre-entry dimeric form of the protein. By using predictive strategies together with computational optimization of binding “pseudoenergies”, we were able to design multiple peptide sequences that showed low micromolar viral entry inhibitory activity. The two most active peptides, DN57opt and 1OAN1, were designed to displace regions in the domain II hinge, and the first domain I/domain II beta sheet connection, respectively, and show fifty percent inhibitory concentrations of 8 and 7 µM respectively in a focus forming unit assay. The antiviral peptides were shown to interfere with virus:cell binding, interact directly with the E proteins and also cause changes to the viral surface using biolayer interferometry and cryo-electron microscopy, respectively. These peptides may be useful for characterization of intermediate states in the membrane fusion process, investigation of DENV receptor molecules, and as lead compounds for drug discovery.

title: Assessing the human immune system through blood transcriptomics
abstract: Blood is the pipeline of the immune system. Assessing changes in transcript abundance in blood on a genome-wide scale affords a comprehensive view of the status of the immune system in health and disease. This review summarizes the work that has used this approach to identify therapeutic targets and biomarker signatures in the field of autoimmunity and infectious disease. Recent technological and methodological advances that will carry the blood transcriptome research field forward are also discussed.

title: A multidimensional classification of public health activity in Australia
abstract: BACKGROUND: At present, we have very limited ability to compare public health activity across jurisdictions and countries, or even to ascertain differences in what is considered to be a public health activity. Existing standardised health classifications do not capture important dimensions of public health, which include its functions, the methods and interventions used to achieve these, the health issues and determinants of health that public health activities address, the resources and infrastructure they use, and the settings in which they occur. A classification that describes these dimensions will promote consistency in collecting and reporting information about public health programs, expenditure, workforce and performance. This paper describes the development of an initial version of such a classification. METHODS: We used open-source Protégé software and published procedures to construct an ontology of public health, which forms the basis of the classification. We reviewed existing definitions of public health, descriptions of public health functions and classifications to develop the scope, domain, and multidimensional class structure of the ontology. These were then refined through a series of consultations with public health experts from across Australia, culminating in an initial classification framework. RESULTS: The public health classification consists of six top-level classes: public health 'Functions'; 'Health Issues'; 'Determinants of Health'; 'Settings'; 'Methods' of intervention; and 'Resources and Infrastructure'. Existing classifications (such as the international classifications of diseases, disability and functioning and external causes of injuries) can be used to further classify large parts of the classes 'Health Issues', 'Settings' and 'Resources and Infrastructure', while new subclass structures are proposed for the classes of public health 'Functions', 'Determinants of Health' and 'Interventions'. CONCLUSION: The public health classification captures the important dimensions of public health activity. It will facilitate the organisation of information so that it can be used to address questions relating to any of these dimensions, either singly or in combination. The authors encourage readers to use the classification, and to suggest improvements.

title: Bovine Chlamydophila spp. infection: Do we underestimate the impact on fertility?
abstract: Bovine Chlamydophila spp. infection has long been assumed to be a primary agent of infertility in dairy cows, but its actual significance as a major cause of bovine infertility within this particular species remains unclear. Despite the fact that clinical examination is commonly used to diagnose reproductive failure in female calves and commercial stock, the potential for an underlying bacterial etiology such as C. psittaci may have been underestimated due to its lengthy latency period before symptoms manifest.This study aimed at evaluating if Cpsittaci plays an important role in infertility issues among the subject population by performing serology-based diagnosis followed by PCR identification of both acute and latent infections caused by this agent for samples collected from suspect farms over 12 months across three states in India . The results suggest that roughly 8-17% of cases previously classified as unexplained or idiopathic fertility issues were actually driven by Cpssitacci infection, which represents a significant burden on animal health while also causing economic damage through lost production costs associated with infected cows unable to identify during milking seasons when their high value persists due to the premium placed upon heifers shown proficiency at lactating early. This study highlights that we can no longer ignore nor underestimate the importance placed upon preventative protocols meticulously followed and more regular testing schedules conducted across all areas of husbandry related products derived from these herds given our findings point toward delayed yet biologically relevant impact Chlamydia based agents could place upon affected dairies yields worldwide

title: C. difficile 630Δerm Spo0A Regulates Sporulation, but Does Not Contribute to Toxin Production, by Direct High-Affinity Binding to Target DNA
abstract: This study investigates the potential of antibiotic-resistant pathogen C. difficile 630Δerm Spo0A as a contributory factor in toxin production and sporulation. Through use of DNA pulldown assays and sequence analysis, we determined that while C. difficile 630Δerm Spo0A binds to target DNA with high affinity, it does not contribute to toxin production but can significantly influence sporulation rates. As such, this result demonstrates a unique role for antibiotic-resistant C. difficile 630Δerm Spo0A in regulating both the toxicity and spores produced by certain bacterial pathogens – providing a novel insight into mutational mechanisms driven by antibiotic selection pressures at play in their environments.

title: RNA and DNA Bacteriophages as Molecular Diagnosis Controls in Clinical Virology: A Comprehensive Study of More than 45,000 Routine PCR Tests
abstract: Real-time PCR techniques are now commonly used for the detection of viral genomes in various human specimens and require for validation both external and internal controls (ECs and ICs). In particular, ICs added to clinical samples are necessary to monitor the extraction, reverse transcription, and amplification steps in order to detect false-negative results resulting from PCR-inhibition or errors in the technical procedure. Here, we performed a large scale evaluation of the use of bacteriophages as ICs in routine molecular diagnosis. This allowed to propose simple standardized procedures (i) to design specific ECs for both DNA and RNA viruses and (ii) to use T4 (DNA) or MS2 (RNA) phages as ICs in routine diagnosis. Various technical formats for using phages as ICs were optimised and validated. Subsequently, T4 and MS2 ICs were evaluated in routine real-time PCR or RT-PCR virological diagnostic tests, using a series of 8,950 clinical samples (representing 36 distinct specimen types) sent to our laboratory for the detection of a variety of DNA and RNA viruses. The frequency of inefficient detection of ICs was analyzed according to the nature of the sample. Inhibitors of enzymatic reactions were detected at high frequency in specific sample types such as heparinized blood and bone marrow (>70%), broncho-alveolar liquid (41%) and stools (36%). The use of T4 and MS2 phages as ICs proved to be cost-effective, flexible and adaptable to various technical procedures of real-time PCR detection in virology. It represents a valuable strategy for enhancing the quality of routine molecular diagnosis in laboratories that use in-house designed diagnostic systems, which can conveniently be associated to the use of specific synthetic ECs. The high rate of inhibitors observed in a variety of specimen types should stimulate the elaboration of improved technical protocols for the extraction and amplification of nucleic acids.

title: DNA Vaccines: Developing New Strategies against Cancer
abstract: Due to their rapid and widespread development, DNA vaccines have entered into a variety of human clinical trials for vaccines against various diseases including cancer. Evidence that DNA vaccines are well tolerated and have an excellent safety profile proved to be of advantage as many clinical trials combines the first phase with the second, saving both time and money. It is clear from the results obtained in clinical trials that such DNA vaccines require much improvement in antigen expression and delivery methods to make them sufficiently effective in the clinic. Similarly, it is clear that additional strategies are required to activate effective immunity against poorly immunogenic tumor antigens. Engineering vaccine design for manipulating antigen presentation and processing pathways is one of the most important aspects that can be easily handled in the DNA vaccine technology. Several approaches have been investigated including DNA vaccine engineering, co-delivery of immunomodulatory molecules, safe routes of administration, prime-boost regimen and strategies to break the immunosuppressive networks mechanisms adopted by malignant cells to prevent immune cell function. Combined or single strategies to enhance the efficacy and immunogenicity of DNA vaccines are applied in completed and ongoing clinical trials, where the safety and tolerability of the DNA platform are substantiated. In this review on DNA vaccines, salient aspects on this topic going from basic research to the clinic are evaluated. Some representative DNA cancer vaccine studies are also discussed.

title: Discovery and Genomic Characterization of a Novel Ovine Partetravirus and a New Genotype of Bovine Partetravirus
abstract: This work presents a comprehensive study on the discovery and genomic characterization of a novel ovine partetravirus, coined OPV-1, along with a new genotype of bovine partetravirus (BPT-2). OPV-1 was identified in an industrial flock of sheep by conventional RT-PCR seeking evidence for known members belonging to the family Partitiviridae. Both viruses were then cloned and sequenced, while their full-length genomes compared against relevant taxa within GenBank allowed to establish that they corresponded to distinct agents as others had already suggested. The results obtained suggest that these two newly described viruses are gaining relevance as viable disease agents among animals maintained under production contexts subject to high biosecurity standards.

title: Replication enhancer elements within the open reading frame of tick-borne encephalitis virus and their evolution within the Flavivirus genus
abstract: This study examines the evolutionary mechanisms of replication enhancer elements within tick-borne encephalitis virus (TBEV) as compared to other members of the Flavivirus genus. Through extensive in silico analysis, we investigated both the genomic location and sequence variability between closely related viruses to provide insight into the ancestral origin of these elements and how they are maintained through evolution. Using multiple bioinformatic tools, we were able to detect commonalities amongst core viral replicons that facilitate viral genome replication. Our work provides an overall overview of TBEV's replication enhancers at different phylogenetic scales as well as their functional significance for disease control efforts in conjunction with improved understanding of emerging flaviviruses. Moreover, our findings offer new insights on future vaccine design strategies and antigenicity generalization from a single host organism across various species in this diverse family.

title: An Epidemic Patchy Model with Entry–Exit Screening
abstract: This paper describes a novel epidemic patchy model with entry–exit screening. The model considers different environmental settings, such as urban or rural areas, and is capable of producing realistic scenarios of infection events by considering the individual's disease history over time together with environmental and geographic factors. To this aim, we propose an innovative approach that combines agent-based modeling techniques with stochastic dynamic programming to accurately track each individual’s exposure dynamics to emerging infectious diseases which are dependent on relevant socio-environmental parameters. Our results show that incorporation of entrance/exit control in addition to standard contact tracing can significantly reduce estimates based only off contact trace reporting for certain cases. This method provides policymakers valuable information regarding the effectiveness of detection and containment strategies when developing emergency preparedness plans for various environments .

title: Travelling Companions: Emerging Diseases of People, Animals and Plants Along the Malawi-Mozambique Border
abstract: This article investigates the emergence of diseases among people, animals, and plants at the border between Malawi and Mozambique. With increasingly long-distance travels in this region for trade, tourism, or migrations come new disease vectors that carry with them unprecedented risks to global health. This research analyses how risk assessment approaches can be used to identify pathogens as they cross borders, quantify contagion trends through syndromic surveillance systems, inform local communities on health precaution measures while travelling domestically or abroad, and empower public health workers in tracking infections across country lines. It will draw upon interviews conducted alongside existing secondary sources regarding travel habits at the border to create a clearer picture of how old and newly emerging viruses spread between different populations and within nations too often neglected by upper-level governments when it comes to their infectious disease preparedness. In sum, this paper seeks to provide sustainable solutions so those living near national borders can protect themselves from sudden outbreaks with effective aid from centralized medical authority structures.

title: A Pragmatic Evaluation of the Theory of Information Ethics
abstract: This paper aims to analyse the practical applications and implications of Information Ethics theory with a multi-disciplinary approach. Through an evaluation of existing research, an objective exploration is undertaken on how this novel field merges utilitarian and moral principals in interpreting data and information in order to protect vulnerable populations from potential harm. 'A Pragmatic Evaluation of the Theory of Information Ethics' presents a comprehensive review which assesses current practices, identifies any loopholes or limitations and offers solutions for their rectification.

title: Health System Resource Gaps and Associated Mortality from Pandemic Influenza across Six Asian Territories
abstract: This study examines the health system resource gaps across six Asian territories and their associated mortality from pandemic influenza. The severity of healthcare disparities between developed and developing countries has been further amplified by the ongoing COVID-19 crisis, highlighting the importance of this research in understanding regional differences in mortality due to inadequate pandemic preparation. By leveraging publicly available data sets including population size, income level, infectious disease-specific hospital bed capacity, government expenditure on health as a percentage of GDP, and cumulative deaths from four pandemics: H1N1 (2009), H5N1 (2005-2018), H7N9 (2013-2017) and 2019 novel coronavirus (COVID-19) during January 2020–February 2021 over 6 low-, middle-, upper-middle to highincome countries or territories in Asia namely China mainland, Hong Kong SAR China or Taiwan Province China SARs; collectively referred to as 'Asian territories', this study aims to assess whether there are inequalities among different regions with respect to access to essential healthcare resources such as beds for critical care services and influence on mortality outcomes under similar circumstances. In summary, findings from this analysis shed light on potential resource gaps that exist across various Asian locations when it comes to providing adequate quality healthcare during a global health emergency.

title: Brain Transcriptome-Wide Screen for HIV-1 Nef Protein Interaction Partners Reveals Various Membrane-Associated Proteins
abstract: This study presents a verification of the identifying and categorizing essential elements of HIV-1 Nef protein interactions partners by means of transcriptome-wide screening. Through immunoisolation and western blot analysis, researchers collected a total of 11 membrane-associated proteins, including various vesicular trafficking components that are likely to bind directly to Nef protein in several human cell lines. Furthermore, this research applies an advanced technique known as SILAC (stable isotope labeling with amino acids in cell culture) which is further evaluated through mass spectrometry platform technologies used earlier for other exogenous targets such as integral membrane proteins and GPCRs. Results demonstrate that viral infection regulates the expression levels of some tested candidates' molecules related to mitochondrial homeostasis and properties along with other closely associated cellular pathways. The results presented here provide valuable insight into therapeutic strategies against HIV infection using direct or indirect modulation on these promising nef protein interaction partner's activities specially those implicated at mitochondria level.

title: Oral health in China – trends and challenges
abstract: This paper provides an insight into the oral health of China and the related trends and challenges that impact the population. The study conducted focused on established data from in-depth interviews, surveys and reviews of online sources to analyse their implications for dental processes, access to healthcare resources, affordability and public awareness. Additionally, it draws upon current evidence based research which engages with various spheres including cultural traditions, economic inequality and technological advancement as primary determinants of a people’s overall well being. In conclusion this article analyses how all these elements interact together to shape the discourse around Chinese oral health today.

title: Superimposed high-frequency jet ventilation combined with continuous positive airway pressure/assisted spontaneous breathing improves oxygenation in patients with H1N1-associated ARDS
abstract: This paper presents the results of a clinical trial exploring how the combination of superimposed high-frequency jet ventilation (SHFJV) and continuous positive airway pressure/assisted spontaneous breathing (CPAP/ASB) improves oxygenation in patients with H1N1-associated acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). At present, due to the lack of evidence and small sample sizes for efficacy analyses, there is controversy surrounding ventilatory management strategies for treating ARDS. Thus, we conducted this prospective controlled study to assess if our proposed intervention effects on oxygenation indexes can be enriched. Our findings indicated that combining SHFJV and CPAP/ASB could bring about significant improvements in arterial oxyhemoglobin saturation (SaO2), PaO2/FiO2 ratio and PaCO2 level discrepancy compared to conventional mechanical ventilation alone. In conclusion, our research suggests that SHFJV combined with CPAP/ASB is an effective solution to improve hypoxemia in patients suffering from H1N1-associated ARDS.

title: The influence of climatic conditions on the transmission dynamics of the 2009 A/H1N1 influenza pandemic in Chile
abstract: The transmission dynamics of the 2009 A/H1N1 influenza pandemic in Chile was greatly influenced by climate conditions due to regional variation. This paper investigates how environmental parameters shaped the pattern of seasonal outbreaks and compare them to patterns prior to, during and post-pandemic and test continental predictions in a highly urbanized region like Chile. Using comprehensive cases from an outbreak surveillance system paired with climatic data, this study explores connections between infections' spread and meteorological derivatives covering a seven-year period (2009 - 2016). Logistic regression is used for hazard calculations providing valuable information about the evolution drivers outside population movement or human measures such as social distancing or vaccination rates. Results evidenced pronounced differences within July through March period temperatures increasing significantly risk at higher temperature range above 20°C while transmitting intensity decreased when arriving 27°C. Humidity had no effect on disease spreading rate during cold months yet delayed transmission when concentrated humidity reached 60% in summertime exceeding 40%. Findings suggested only short-term interactions ruling out current ability of models predicting long term epidemiological projections hence stressing environment relevance boosting sustainable public health interventions dealing with fall winter season disease pressure..

title: Tissue Tropism and Target Cells of NSs-Deleted Rift Valley Fever Virus in Live Immunodeficient Mice
abstract:
This paper discusses the effects of eliminating the NSm segment from Rift Valley Fever virus (RVFV) on its tissue tropism and target cells in a murine model. The study utilized an immunodeficient mouse for verifying these effects without interference from the host immune system. The results uncover new aspects surrounding RVFV pathogenesis, which can contribute to developing novel treatments targeted at this important human pathogen.
Tissue Tropism and Target Cells of NSs-Deleted Rift Valley Fever Virus in Live Immunodeficient Mice 
Rift Valley Fever virus (RVFV), a mosquitoborne flavivirus, is known to cause a wide range of clinical syndromes including fever, myalgia, vomiting and hemorrhagic disease resulting in significant morbidity and mortality worldwide. To investigate further its tissue tropism as well as identify infected cell targets, live immunocompromised mice were used since they provide an optimal setting under controlled laboratory environment with minimal influence from other factors such as differences among individuals’ adaptive immunity components. This paper elucidates the effect of deleting one genome segment encoding nonstructural protein 1 small subunit (NS1S) or NSm gene that behaves like virulence regulator on determining tissue tropism and target cells by RVFV strain 9000 recovered from East Africa isolates using CCID50 plaque forming units assay prior to inoculation into 7–8 week old SCID mice followed by histopathology assessment accordingly. The findings reported here may expand our knowledge on how infectious agents interact with their hosts leading up to optimizing therapeutic approaches against diseases caused by them moving forward.

title: Expression of anti-tumor recombinant IgG- and IgE-like genes in eukaryotic cells
abstract: This study evaluates the expression levels of two types of anti-tumor immunoglobulins, IgG and IgE, in eukaryotic cells. Through a series of experiments employing gene recombination techniques combined with genetic engineering and protein purification procedures, we sought to define their functional roles in cancer cell destruction. The purpose is to gain insights into how these molecules work together within complex cellular systems, such as cancerous lymphoma or leukemia tumors. Ultimately, this research could inform the development of novel therapies targeting both IgG- and IgE-mediated processes for future treatment applications. Expression of Anti-Tumor Recombinant IgG- And Ige_Like Genes In Eukaryotic Cells

title: Identification and Characterization of a Novel Non-Structural Protein of Bluetongue Virus
abstract:
The Bluetongue Virus (BTV) is a double-stranded virus belonging to the genus Orbivirus of family Reoviridae and has been associated with large scale morbidity and mortality in both humans and livestock. BTV harbours several non-structural proteins that are typically released through viral proteolytic processing during its replication cycle, yet some remain uncharacterized. In this study, we identify and characterize a novel non-structural95 kDa protein of BTV using reverse genetics coupled with biochemical approaches such as mass spectrometry, SDS PAGE gel electrophoresis along with Western Blot analysis. The product of core gene 14 possesses two distinct domains — an NterminusU1A domain which exhibits prolyl tripeptide repeat motifs plus an RNA binding domain at the C terminus–which are believed to be important for mediating various functions in genome packaging and translational regulation. Furthermore, we reported evidence for augmented expression levels during relatively late stages of infection when compared to early timepoints; moreover its molecular weight varied according to laboratory strains demonstrating site-specific variants among isolates. These results provide novel insights into the biology as well as structural characteristics facilitating deeper understanding towards functional roles altogether critical for successful completion of viral life cycle. Overall our findings further establish potential utility in terms of diagnostics while drawing attention towards development potential vaccines targeting specifically this component amongst other major ones employed by bluetongue virus replicative machinery. 

Title: Identification and Characterization of a Novel Non-Structural Protein of Bluetongue Virus

title: Genetic Variation in the TNF Gene Is Associated with Susceptibility to Severe Sepsis, but Not with Mortality
abstract: This study aims to investigate the potential association between genetic variation in the tumor necrosis factor (TNF) gene and susceptibility to severe sepsis, as well as its influence on mortality outcomes. Severe sepsis is a major cause of death across all age groups, but controversies remain regarding its etiology and treatment. TNF has long been proposed as an effective pathogenic target for severe cases of this disease, however its role in the condition's development remains unclear. Through comprehensive genotyping and phenotypic evaluation of patient cohorts from two hospitals in Northeast China, we sought to establish a more definitive link between TNF variants and severe sepsis susceptibility —and their relative impact on morbidity costs— by confronting them with clinical records over an extended period of time. Our results revealed that there was indeed a significant correlation between individualSNPs in rs361525/rs1800629/rs1800750 and three haplotypes constructed using these sites simultaneously with severity levels stratified according to CURB-65 criteria; however there was no association found between those SNPs or haplotypes tested herein with patients' mortality outcome after adjusting for covariates suchinflammation markers concentrations.Furtherextensive studies are still neededto confirm our findings.

title: Mutational analysis of human CEACAM1: the potential of receptor polymorphism in increasing host susceptibility to bacterial infection
abstract: A common overlapping site on the N-terminal IgV-like domain of human carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)-related cell adhesion molecules (CEACAMs) is targeted by several important human respiratory pathogens. These include Neisseria meningitidis (Nm) and Haemophilus influenzae (Hi) that can cause disseminated or persistent localized infections. To define the precise structural features that determine the binding of distinct pathogens with CEACAMs, we have undertaken molecular modelling and mutation of the receptor molecules at previously implicated key target residues required for bacterial binding. These include Ser-32, Tyr-34, Val-39, Gln-44 and Gln-89, in addition to Ile-91, the primary docking site for the pathogens. Most, but not all, of these residues located adjacent to each other in a previous N-domain model of human CEACAM1, which was based on REI, CD2 and CD4. In the current studies, we have refined this model based on the mouse CEACAM1 crystal structure, and observe that all of the above residues form an exposed continuous binding region on the N-domain. Examination of the model also suggested that substitution of two of these residues 34 and 89 could affect the accessibility of Ile-91 for ligand binding. By introducing selected mutations at the positions 91, 34 and 89, we confirmed the primary importance of Ile-91 in all bacterial binding to CEACAM1 despite the inter- and intraspecies structural differences between the bacterial CEACAM-binding ligands. The studies further indicated that the efficiency of binding was significantly enhanced for specific strains by mutations such as Y34F and Q89N, which also altered the hierarchy of Nm versus Hi strain binding. These studies imply that distinct polymorphisms in human epithelial CEACAMs have the potential to decrease or increase the risk of infection by the receptor-targeting pathogens.

title: A Microarray Based Approach for the Identification of Common Foodborne Viruses
abstract: An oligonucleotide array (microarray) incorporating 13,000 elements representing selected strains of hepatitis A virus (HAV), human coxsackieviruses A and B (CVA and CVB), genogroups I and II of Norovirus (NV), and human rotavirus (RV) gene segments 3,4,10, and 11 was designed based on the principle of tiling. Each oligonucleotide was 29 bases long, starting at every 5th base of every sequence, resulting in an overlap of 24 bases in two consecutive oligonucleotides. The applicability of the array for virus identification was examined using PCR amplified products from multiple HAV and CV strains. PCR products labeled with biotin were hybridized to the array, and the biotin was detected using a brief reaction with Cy3-labeled streptavidin, the array subjected to laser scanning, and the hybridization data plotted as fluorescence intensity against each oligonucleotide in the array. The combined signal intensities of all probes representing a particular strain of virus were calculated and plotted against all virus strains identified on a linear representation of the array. The profile of the total signal intensity identified the strain that is most likely represented in the amplified cDNA target. The results obtained with HAV and CV indicated that the hybridization profile thus generated can be used to identify closely related viral strains. This represents a significant improvement over current methods for virus identification using PCR amplification and amplicon sequencing.

title: Pandemic (H1N1) 2009 Risk for Frontline Health Care Workers
abstract: This project investigates the risk factors, consequences and surrounding circumstances associated with frontline health care workers (FHCWs) during pandemic H1N1 outbreak of 2009. Through a comprehensive study, we identify potential vulnerabilities of FHCWs and suggest possible countermeasures through an implementation system to enhance protection from contagion. Additionally, existing efforts at controlling the impact will be evaluated for their effective implementation in light of divergent national policies related to pandemic influenza preparedness. Our research focuses on socio-economic aspects while avoiding oversimplified approaches to protect healthcare personnel most at risk during such public health outbreaks. We argue that without further reinforcement or better regulations of safety protocols among those directly exposed to contagious material, adverse effects are likely to persist even long after an epidemic has subsided.

title: Multiplex cytokine profile from dengue patients: MIP-1beta and IFN-gamma as predictive factors for severity
abstract: BACKGROUND: Dengue virus pathogenesis is not yet fully understood and the identification of patients at high risk for developing severe disease forms is still a great challenge in dengue patient care. During the present study, we evaluated prospectively the potential of cytokines present in plasma from patients with dengue in stratifying disease severity. METHODS: Seventeen-cytokine multiplex fluorescent microbead immunoassay was used for the simultaneous detection in 59 dengue patients. GLM models using bimodal or Gaussian family were determined in order to associate cytokines with clinical manifestations and laboratory diagnosis. RESULTS: IL-1β, IFN-γ, IL-4, IL-6, IL-13, IL-7 and GM-CSF were significantly increased in patients with severe clinical manifestations (severe dengue) when compared to mild disease forms (mild dengue). In contrast, increased MIP-1β levels were observed in patients with mild dengue. MIP-1β was also associated with CD56+NK cell circulating rates. IL-1β, IL-8, TNF-α and MCP-1 were associated with marked thrombocytopenia. Increased MCP-1 and GM-CSF levels correlated with hypotension. Moreover, MIP-1β and IFN-γ were independently associated with both dengue severity and disease outcome. CONCLUSION: Our data demonstrated that the use of a multiple cytokine assay platform was suitable for identifying distinct cytokine profiles associated with the dengue clinical manifestations and severity. MIP-β is indicated for the first time as a good prognostic marker in contrast to IFN-γ that was associated with disease severity.

title: Stem–loop structures can effectively substitute for an RNA pseudoknot in −1 ribosomal frameshifting
abstract: This study explores the potential of stem–loop structures to substitute efficiently for an RNA pseudoknot in −1 ribosomal frameshifting, which is required by certain eukaryotic mRNAs to encode proteins. Frameshifting allows a reading frame change that enables translation from one open reading frame (ORF) into another. This has been linked with several important aspects of human physiology and pathology such as HIV, cancer and neuronal disease. The current study investigates if extended stem loops can possess sufficient structural flexibility, surpassing the energy threshold needed for ribosome movement during long downstream hops after expansion or contraction of secondary structure elements including helices and bulges along ORF boundaries in vivo. Results imply that larger stem–loops could effectively replace longer distance RNA pseudoknots at moderate cost under both physiologic temperatures and proper pH conditions.

title: Neutrophil elastase, an acid-independent serine protease, facilitates reovirus uncoating and infection in U937 promonocyte cells
abstract: BACKGROUND: Mammalian reoviruses naturally infect their hosts through the enteric and respiratory tracts. During enteric infections, proteolysis of the reovirus outer capsid protein σ3 is mediated by pancreatic serine proteases. In contrast, the proteases critical for reovirus replication in the lung are unknown. Neutrophil elastase (NE) is an acid-independent, inflammatory serine protease predominantly expressed by neutrophils. In addition to its normal role in microbial defense, aberrant expression of NE has been implicated in the pathology of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Because reovirus replication in rodent lungs causes ARDS-like symptoms and induces an infiltration of neutrophils, we investigated the capacity of NE to promote reovirus virion uncoating. RESULTS: The human promonocyte cell line U937 expresses NE. Treatment of U937 cells with the broad-spectrum cysteine-protease inhibitor E64 [trans-epoxysuccinyl-L-leucylamido-(4-guanidino)butane] and with agents that increase vesicular pH did not inhibit reovirus replication. Even when these inhibitors were used in combination, reovirus replicated to significant yields, indicating that an acid-independent non-cysteine protease was capable of mediating reovirus uncoating in U937 cell cultures. To identify the protease(s) responsible, U937 cells were treated with phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate (PMA), an agent that induces cellular differentiation and results in decreased expression of acid-independent serine proteases, including NE and cathepsin (Cat) G. In the presence of E64, reovirus did not replicate efficiently in PMA-treated cells. To directly assess the role of NE in reovirus infection of U937 cells, we examined viral growth in the presence of N-Ala-Ala-Pro-Val chloromethylketone, a NE-specific inhibitor. Reovirus replication in the presence of E64 was significantly reduced by treatment of cells with the NE inhibitor. Incubation of virions with purified NE resulted in the generation of infectious subviron particles that did not require additional intracellular proteolysis. CONCLUSION: Our findings reveal that NE can facilitate reovirus infection. The fact that it does so in the presence of agents that raise vesicular pH supports a model in which the requirement for acidic pH during infection reflects the conditions required for optimal protease activity. The capacity of reovirus to exploit NE may impact viral replication in the lung and other tissues during natural infections.

title: Influence of genetic variability at the surfactant proteins A and D in community-acquired pneumonia: a prospective, observational, genetic study
abstract: This paper sets out to determine the influence of genetic variability at the surfactant proteins A and D in community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). CAP is a severe pulmonary illness that is among the top 10 leading causes of mortality worldwide, influencing more than 27 million people each year. The current treatments for CAP are becoming increasingly less effective as resistance evolves alongside changes in environmental conditions and bacterial strains. To address this important issue, we conducted a prospective observational genetic study over 18 months across six Medical Centers to ascertain any associations between genetic variants related to SURF1A and SURF1D genes – both crucial for equilibrium within surfactant levels in alveolar macrophages - and disease susceptibility or severity. We analyzed data acquired from 436 individuals diagnosed with CAP, including theirs demographic histories such as age or gender, as well as complete blood counts and statistical analysis on cells collected by bronchoalverovsular lavage technique during admission period; results were compared against those obtained fromcontrol group comprising 517 healthy participants matched through age brackets. Our analyses revealed evidence that single nucleotide polymorphisms  located near or within 5’ regulatory regions SURFA though SURFD could predispose patients towards lower protection against airborne pathogens encountered while living in urban environment characterized by air pollution, extreme temperature variations or heavy metal intoxication; these effects seemed even bigger when combined with other medical condition like obesity or diabetes onset. Further research needs be carried out validate these findings so facts may found most suitable strategies provide stronger prevention epidemiologic evolving diverse microbialscenarioes seen urban settings today's world.

title: Analysis of synonymous codon usage and evolution of begomoviruses
abstract: Begomoviruses are single-stranded DNA viruses and cause severe diseases in major crop plants worldwide. Based on current genome sequence analyses, we found that synonymous codon usage variations in the protein-coding genes of begomoviruses are mainly influenced by mutation bias. Base composition analysis suggested that the codon usage bias of AV1 and BV1 genes is significant and their expressions are high. Fourteen codons were determined as translational optimal ones according to the comparison of codon usage patterns between highly and lowly expressed genes. Interestingly the codon usages between begomoviruses from the Old and the New Worlds are apparently different, which supports the idea that the bipartite begomoviruses of the New World might originate from bipartite ones of the Old World, whereas the latter evolve from the Old World monopartite begomoviruses.

title: Membrane Fusion and Cell Entry of XMRV Are pH-Independent and Modulated by the Envelope Glycoprotein's Cytoplasmic Tail
abstract: This paper examines the pH-independent membrane fusion and cell entry of XMRV, a virus implicated in some human diseases, as well as describing how such process is directed by the glycoprotein's cytoplasmic tail embedded in its envelope. Various techniques were employed to determine the preferences for acidic and basic conditions among different types of viruses. The research conducted revealed that particular discrepancies between XMRV and other members of its family are due to modifications in their respective glycoproteins’ cytoplasmic tails which permit them to become highly independent from external pH variations for configuring intracellular fusion processes – a feature not seen across many related species previously known. This paper articulates how pH independence relies on complex dynamics propelled by proteins' multiple dynamical adaptations at varying external ion concentrations and further postulate possible implications it may have for understanding urgent medical challenges surrounding this important group of pathogenic agents.

title: Positional Bias of MHC Class I Restricted T-Cell Epitopes in Viral Antigens Is Likely due to a Bias in Conservation
abstract: This paper examines the possible significance of positional bias for MHC Class I restricted T-cell epitopes which are present within viral antigens. Recent findings indicate that particular sites in a given antigen may be more receptive to MHC binding and thus T-cell recognition. In comparison, other positions remain unbound by most alleles and consequently can provide no immune response. Our research found evidence of highly conservative parts across various viruses leading us to suggest that preeminent conservation likely facilitates favorable interactions with MHC molecules allowing these areas heightened accessibility. This study presents findings shedding light onto the importance of conserved regions determined on a virus’ global sequence level and their interrelation with successful presentation by its human host, relevant for development targeted immunotherapies against viral infections as well as upon evaluations regarding an optimal choice for vaccine design strategies.

title: LoFreq: a sequence-quality aware, ultra-sensitive variant caller for uncovering cell-population heterogeneity from high-throughput sequencing datasets
abstract: This paper presents LoFreq, a novel variant caller designed to research cell-population heterogeneity from high-throughput sequencing datasets. This tool adopts an innovative approach that accounts for both sequence quality and read depth. It is an ultra-sensitive algorithm, capable of detecting extremely rare variants with low allele frequencies even in the presence of a large majority population. Through comprehensive simulations and real-world validation studies on whole exome sequencing data sets with known ground truth, we demonstrate that LoFreq significantly outperforms all modern existing methods by simultaneously maximizing sensitivity, precision and accuracy without compromising control of false discovery rate or requiring substantial additional computational resources. Moreover, our tool offers heightened ability in identifying cellular subclones within any samples while preserving pyrosequencing accuracy levels using phred scores alone to identify sites where reads should be discarded due to excessive noise or discordant information from surrounding regions. The performance results obtained validate the proposed approach as a reliable solution for uncovering subtle differences between complex cell-populations at unprecedented analytical resolution capability so far not achievable by other competing packages available today.

title: A MultiSite Gateway(TM )vector set for the functional analysis of genes in the model Saccharomyces cerevisiae
abstract: The ability to functionally analyze genes in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae is essential for our understanding of many biomedical processes. Such analyses can potentially provide key insights into global cellular physiology, metabolic and epigenomic mechanisms, as well as pathophysiology. Here we describe a novel MultiSite Gateway(TM ) vector set developed specifically for use in S. cerevisiae, which enables us to conduct efficient gene cloning and analysis with unprecedented throughput and accessibility. This comprehensive toolkit provides an easy-to-use system that allows researchers to quickly generate target genes with multiple genetic modifications or tagging platforms without requiringchanges in any plasmid components or starting from scratch each time the experiment is performed. These features render this vector set invaluable for functional studies on diverse areas of gene expression regulation across genomes such genome-wide siRNA perturbation screens or CRISPR disruption libraries. We discuss here our codeveloped methodology based on extensive experimental validation in combination with bioinformatic data processing pipelines for model generation and scalability throughout different labs worldwide focusing on industrial fermentation products research as well as medical description studies

title: Hepatitis C virus NS4A inhibits cap-dependent and the viral IRES-mediated translation through interacting with eukaryotic elongation factor 1A
abstract: This study explores the effect of Hepatitis C virus (HCV) NS4A on cap-dependent and IRES-mediated translation efficiency. HCV is a major cause of liver cancer, yet its exact mechanism(s) of inhibition remain largely unknown. This work aims to investigate the function of HCV NS4A in affecting translation efficiency by assessing its interaction with eukaryotic elongation factor 1A (eEF1A), demonstrating how it can alter viral infectivity at a post-initiation step. Through combined biochemical and virological approaches, we aim to uncover the underlying molecular basis by which HCV NS4A and eEF1a suppress mRNA translation initiation. The results could open up new opportunities for potential therapeutic intervention against this important human pathogen.

title: A New Model for Hendra Virus Encephalitis in the Mouse
abstract: This article presents an innovative approach to modelling Hendra virus encephalitis in mice, a highly contagious and often lethal disease with significant public health implications. By combining detailed biophysical parameters for protein folding with computer simulation techniques, our research team has developed a novel model that captures changes in the central nervous system caused by viral infection over time. This model sheds light on potential paths of pathogenesis, providing insight into specific molecular interactions implicated in neuron damage within this zoonotic disease. We have increased the predictive power of investigations by conducting a series of experiments that characterize both the effects of wild-type and mutant alleles on HVE progression in mice. Our findings suggest new strategies for prevention and treatment regimens that may be explored further as viable alternatives to extant control methods targeting this important family of viruses.

title: Rapid Identification of Malaria Vaccine Candidates Based on α-Helical Coiled Coil Protein Motif
abstract: To identify malaria antigens for vaccine development, we selected α-helical coiled coil domains of proteins predicted to be present in the parasite erythrocytic stage. The corresponding synthetic peptides are expected to mimic structurally “native” epitopes. Indeed the 95 chemically synthesized peptides were all specifically recognized by human immune sera, though at various prevalence. Peptide specific antibodies were obtained both by affinity-purification from malaria immune sera and by immunization of mice. These antibodies did not show significant cross reactions, i.e., they were specific for the original peptide, reacted with native parasite proteins in infected erythrocytes and several were active in inhibiting in vitro parasite growth. Circular dichroism studies indicated that the selected peptides assumed partial or high α-helical content. Thus, we demonstrate that the bioinformatics/chemical synthesis approach described here can lead to the rapid identification of molecules which target biologically active antibodies, thus identifying suitable vaccine candidates. This strategy can be, in principle, extended to vaccine discovery in a wide range of other pathogens.

title: Synergistic Roles of Eukaryotic Translation Elongation Factors 1Bγ and 1A in Stimulation of Tombusvirus Minus-Strand Synthesis
abstract: This study seeks to explore the Synergistic Roles of Eukaryotic Translation Elongation Factors 1Bγ and 1A in Stimulation of Tombusvirus Minus-Strand Synthesis. This cellular process is activated by numerous complexes, each responsible for various steps within viral replication. Recent studies have identified eEF1Bγ and eEF1A as two key elongation factors with critical impacts on minus-strand synthesis. Using a combination of biochemical analysis, accumulation assays and genetic testing this research aims to investigate how these proteins interact synergistically during tombusvirus DNA synthesis to promote efficient virus propagation both in vitro and in vivo. The outcomes will allow us to elucidate more fully the roles of eukaryotic translation elongation factors during RNA replication, facilitating further understanding into disease pathways connected with tombusviruses.

title: CVTree update: a newly designed phylogenetic study platform using composition vectors and whole genomes
abstract: The CVTree web server (http://tlife.fudan.edu.cn/cvtree) presented here is a new implementation of the whole genome-based, alignment-free composition vector (CV) method for phylogenetic analysis. It is more efficient and user-friendly than the previously published version in the 2004 web server issue of Nucleic Acids Research. The development of whole genome-based alignment-free CV method has provided an independent verification to the traditional phylogenetic analysis based on a single gene or a few genes. This new implementation attempts to meet the challenge of ever increasing amount of genome data and includes in its database more than 850 prokaryotic genomes which will be updated monthly from NCBI, and more than 80 fungal genomes collected manually from several sequencing centers. This new CVTree web server provides a faster and stable research platform. Users can upload their own sequences to find their phylogenetic position among genomes selected from the server's; inbuilt database. All sequence data used in a session may be downloaded as a compressed file. In addition to standard phylogenetic trees, users can also choose to output trees whose monophyletic branches are collapsed to various taxonomic levels. This feature is particularly useful for comparing phylogeny with taxonomy when dealing with thousands of genomes.

title: The Dynamics, Causes and Possible Prevention of Hepatitis E Outbreaks
abstract: This paper investigates the effects of a rising incidence and prevalence of Hepatitis E across different countries. It also explores possible causes that have been linked to such outbreaks, as well as examining the dynamics behind them. Finally, it identifies potential prevention strategies for containing any more future instances. The study used in-depth interviews from public health specialists and utilized medical records from 6 different affected countries to gather qualitative and quantitative data respectively. In order to better understand trends in hepatitis E occurrence rates following an outbreak, logistic regression models were employed over a period of 5 years through surveillance networks set up during this time period. Findings suggest that certain factors such as unhygienic conditions and contamination can lead to increases in reported cases of hepatitis E among vulnerable populations within certain geographical areas or communities with inadequate access to water sources; these results are discussed further alongside propositions for better management practices on both individual level and institutional level contexts towards preventing similar incidents in the future

title: Transmissibility and temporal changes of 2009 pH1N1 pandemic during summer and fall/winter waves
abstract:
The 2009 pandemic of influenza A (H1N1) virus, known as ‘swine flu’, initiated in North America and spread rapidly throughout the rest of world. To understand transmission dynamics of this virus, temporal changes in transmission during the summer and fall/winter waves are needed. This study evaluated transmissibility and temporal changes of 2009 pH1N1 pandemic during different periods across 218 countries to determine underlying epidemiological factors contributing to its prevalence over time. Data on a range of demographic features such as population size, mobility trend and age structure were utilized for statistical analysis by capture-recapture equation G log linear model through monthly aggregation over 9 months between April to December in each country-year combination with confidence intervals constructed using likelihood uncertainty estimation framework within frequentist approach using sampling with replacement technique for bootstraping data sample size. The findings demonstrate that there is an increasing pattern indicating significant impact from PH1N1 spreading occurring mainly towards end of winter season affected mainly by overcrowding coupled with diminished hygiene practices leading to higher chances if infection becoming endemic regions especially amongst outskirt rural areas necessitating nationwide governmental interventions promptly dispatchable resources along collective efforts coming together meaningfully surpass shortcoming limitations prevails upon prolonged presence viral strain during peaks period epidemics wave originated influenza stemming penetration en masse seasonality which could potentially provide insight decision makers proactive measures anticipate intensive effective countermeasures put forth early before spreading progressed deadliest depths jeopardize populace vulnerable return surviving vanquished adversity possessing itself harm might unfold civilization future prevent ill effects ruin would wreak . 
Transmissibility and Temporal Changes of 2009 pH1N1 Pandemic During Summer and Fall/Winter Waves

title: Immunogenetic Mechanisms Driving Norovirus GII.4 Antigenic Variation
abstract: The emergence of norovirus GII.4 as one of the predominant causative agents of gastroenteritis has compelled researchers to gain insights into its immunogenetic mechanisms. This article presents a comprehensive overview and evaluation of current research outlining how antigenic variation contributes to the viral evolution and spread globally. Through employing advanced molecular immunological techniques, it is proposed that norovirus GII.4 utilises a combination of genetic rearrangement and mutability strategies, allowing antigenic diversity which results in recurrent pandemics despite herd immunity among human populations. Further analysis explores potential implications for treatment approaches, highlighting promising new avenues such as antibody-based interventions to target multiple mutations while taking into account varying local outbreaks. The need for constant vigilance amongst healthcare practitioners is also addressed, by discussing ways in which monitoring of both regional patterns and antigenic characterization can lead to improved identification practices when managing associated clinical cases tied with this virus type

title: Ventilatory and ECMO treatment of H1N1-induced severe respiratory failure: results of an Italian referral ECMO center
abstract: BACKGROUND: Since the first outbreak of a respiratory illness caused by H1N1 virus in Mexico, several reports have described the need of intensive care or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) assistance in young and often healthy patients. Here we describe our experience in H1N1-induced ARDS using both ventilation strategy and ECMO assistance. METHODS: Following Italian Ministry of Health instructions, an Emergency Service was established at the Careggi Teaching Hospital (Florence, Italy) for the novel pandemic influenza. From Sept 09 to Jan 10, all patients admitted to our Intensive Care Unit (ICU) of the Emergency Department with ARDS due to H1N1 infection were studied. All ECMO treatments were veno-venous. H1N1 infection was confirmed by PCR assayed on pharyngeal swab, subglottic aspiration and bronchoalveolar lavage. Lung pathology was evaluated daily by lung ultrasound (LUS) examination. RESULTS: A total of 12 patients were studied: 7 underwent ECMO treatment, and 5 responded to protective mechanical ventilation. Two patients had co-infection by Legionella Pneumophila. One woman was pregnant. In our series, PCR from bronchoalveolar lavage had a 100% sensitivity compared to 75% from pharyngeal swab samples. The routine use of LUS limited the number of chest X-ray examinations and decreased transportation to radiology for CT-scan, increasing patient safety and avoiding the transitory disconnection from ventilator. No major complications occurred during ECMO treatments. In three cases, bleeding from vascular access sites due to heparin infusion required blood transfusions. Overall mortality rate was 8.3%. CONCLUSIONS: In our experience, early ECMO assistance resulted safe and feasible, considering the life threatening condition, in H1N1-induced ARDS. Lung ultrasound is an effective mean for daily assessment of ARDS patients.

title: Missing and accounted for: gaps and areas of wealth in the public health review literature
abstract: This article examines the gaps and areas of wealth in public health studies by surveying the current published literature. The study utilizes an extensive review of relevant material to identify critical elements that have been overlooked or inadequately addressed, thus uncovering opportunities for further exploration. Focusing on areas such as access to care and health literacy, this analysis provides a comprehensive overview of existing research and indicates where additional evaluation is necessary. In addition, it suggests ways to enhance the quality of future investigations through targeted interventions at each stage of the literature cycle: from concept development to publication; and from review board assessment through data collection/analysis/interpretation and reporting/communication dissemination. With specific regard to gender disparities in reporting one finds a notable absence; wherein contributions by evidence-based publications are not being seen as widely throughout disparate communities yielding an altogether inadequate representation across settings of practice. Ultimately it is incumbent upon both researchers and academic institutions alike taking accountability within their respective spheres while establishing standards appropriate to social determinants so that efficient utilization be had relative effectuating tangible solutions with viable redress outcomes in public health worldwide.

title: Brain Microbial Populations in HIV/AIDS: α-Proteobacteria Predominate Independent of Host Immune Status
abstract: With the advent of new sequencing technology, modern science has sought to understand how environmental bacterial composition can affect human health. This paper presents findings on the microbial populations existing in brains of HIV/AIDS patients that could potentially inform treatment protocols for this group. Using 16S ribosomal RNA and next generation sequencing (NGS), the authors analyzed brain tissue samples taken from 111 HIV/AIDS patients with varying CD4 cell levels, a marker used to indicate immunocompetence in infected individuals. Upon analysis they found two distinct phyla present in abundance – Firmicutes and Proteobacteria – but it was discovered that α -Proteobacteria predominated independent of host immune status, providing evidence for its role as an infectious and communicable agent within the brain microenvironment. Ultimately, this study seeks to gain further knowledge about this unique microbiome distribution among those suffering from advanced stages of AIDS as well as identify potential anti-microbial targets which may play a key role in providing successful therapeutic interventions moving forward..

title: Science into policy: preparing for pandemic influenza
abstract: Authoratative government pandemic preparedness requires an evidence-based approach. The scientific advisory process that has informed the current UK pandemic preparedness plans is described. The final endorsed scientific papers are now publicly available.

title: Isolation and characterization of microparticles in sputum from cystic fibrosis patients
abstract: BACKGROUND: Microparticles (MPs) are membrane vesicles released during cell activation and apoptosis. MPs have different biological effects depending on the cell from they originate. Cystic fibrosis (CF) lung disease is characterized by massive neutrophil granulocyte influx in the airways, their activation and eventually apoptosis. We investigated on the presence and phenotype of MPs in the sputum, a rich non-invasive source of inflammation biomarkers, of acute and stable CF adult patients. METHODS: Spontaneous sputum, obtained from 21 CF patients (10 acute and 11 stable) and 7 patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), was liquefied with Sputasol. MPs were counted, visualized by electron microscopy, and identified in the supernatants of treated sputum by cytofluorimetry and immunolabelling for leukocyte (CD11a), granulocyte (CD66b), and monocyte-macrophage (CD11b) antigens. RESULTS: Electron microscopy revealed that sputum MPs were in the 100-500 nm range and did not contain bacteria, confirming microbiological tests. CF sputa contained higher number of MPs in comparison with PCD sputa. Levels of CD11a(+)-and CD66b(+)-, but not CD11b(+)-MPs were significantly higher in CF than in PCD, without differences between acute and stable patients. CONCLUSIONS: In summary, MPs are detectable in sputa obtained from CF patients and are predominantly of granulocyte origin. This novel isolation method for MPs from sputum opens a new opportunity for the study of lung pathology in CF.

title: Differential Effects of IL-12 on Tregs and Non-Treg T Cells: Roles of IFN-γ, IL-2 and IL-2R
abstract: This study seeks to investigate the differential effects of interleukin-12 (IL-12) on regulatory T cells (Tregs) and non-Treg T cells, focusing particularly on the roles of interferon gamma (IFNγ), interleukin 2 (IL-2), and IL-2R. Emerging evidence suggests that these three molecules are key mediators in controlling immune responses through their actions on CD4+ effector T cell subsets; however, it remains unknown how these cytokines regulate inflammatory responses for different types of activated T cells, such as regulatory versus non‑Tregs. Utilizing in vitro cultures and mouse models with impaired IFNγ, IL‑2 and/or IL‑2 receptors provides insight into this important yet understudied area related to immunoregulation. The results gathered from our investigations can ultimately contribute towards a greater understand between biological processes on a mechanistic level while informing therapeutic considerations aiming at modulating particular aspects of inflammation or chemokine production through inhibition, enhancement or neutralization strategies.

title: Serodiagnosis of Echinococcus spp. Infection: Explorative Selection of Diagnostic Antigens by Peptide Microarray
abstract: BACKGROUND: Production of native antigens for serodiagnosis of helminthic infections is laborious and hampered by batch-to-batch variation. For serodiagnosis of echinococcosis, especially cystic disease, most screening tests rely on crude or purified Echinococcus granulosus hydatid cyst fluid. To resolve limitations associated with native antigens in serological tests, the use of standardized and highly pure antigens produced by chemical synthesis offers considerable advantages, provided appropriate diagnostic sensitivity and specificity is achieved. METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS: Making use of the growing collection of genomic and proteomic data, we applied a set of bioinformatic selection criteria to a collection of protein sequences including conceptually translated nucleotide sequence data of two related tapeworms, Echinococcus multilocularis and Echinococcus granulosus. Our approach targeted alpha-helical coiled-coils and intrinsically unstructured regions of parasite proteins potentially exposed to the host immune system. From 6 proteins of E. multilocularis and 5 proteins of E. granulosus, 45 peptides between 24 and 30 amino acids in length were designed. These peptides were chemically synthesized, spotted on microarrays and screened for reactivity with sera from infected humans. Peptides reacting above the cut-off were validated in enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISA). Peptides identified failed to differentiate between E. multilocularis and E. granulosus infection. The peptide performing best reached 57% sensitivity and 94% specificity. This candidate derived from Echinococcus multilocularis antigen B8/1 and showed strong reactivity to sera from patients infected either with E. multilocularis or E. granulosus. CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE: This study provides proof of principle for the discovery of diagnostically relevant peptides by bioinformatic selection complemented with screening on a high-throughput microarray platform. Our data showed that a single peptide cannot provide sufficient diagnostic sensitivity whereas pooling several peptide antigens improved sensitivity; thus combinations of several peptides may lead the way to new diagnostic tests that replace, or at least complement conventional immunodiagnosis of echinococcosis. Our strategy could prove useful for diagnostic developments in other pathogens.

title: Personal, Occupational, and Public Health Perspectives on Dealing with the First Case of Influenza A (H1N1) in the United Arab Emirates
abstract: This paper presents an examination of the personal, occupational and public health perspectives concerning the management of the first case of Influenza A (H1N1) in United Arab Emirates. The implications for health care professionals from each perspective will be discussed. It is concluded that thoughtful consideration needs to be taken when managing a case of a highly contagious illness like Influenza A (H1N1).

title: Antagonistic Pleiotropy and Fitness Trade-Offs Reveal Specialist and Generalist Traits in Strains of Canine Distemper Virus
abstract: This paper presents a novel predictive model that examines two types of intra- and inter-strain interactions amongst different strains of Canine Distemper Virus (CDV). Using antagonistic pleiotropy and fitness trade-off theory, we assess how specialist or generalist phenotypic traits might be determined through interactions between different CDV genotypes. By using transmission electron micrographs to visualize the changes in visible characteristics caused by mutations which occur during strain change, we are able to connect these morphologic alterations with underlying genetic differences in the virus. This provides additional insight into which strains display traits that make them both competitively advantageous and capable of upending existing adaptational pressure. We leverage our predictive model for predicting intrastrain fitness cost–benefit ratios as well as their dynamic changes over time and space. Our results indicate that CDV populations possess an array of specialist versus generalist traits which can respond rapidly when environ­mental stresses become exaggerated or abate due to variable selection pressures; this supports the notion that specialized characteristics generally present lower average resistance score than more generalized lines under similar environmental influences. We predict from our results could help assume more accurate tools for epidemiological forecasting, host adaptation succession empirical formulae and system optimization efforts. Ultimately it should improve preventive means against illness outbreaks amongst canine varieties host models as well as provide insights into evolution itself by highlighting mechanisms at play enabling CDVs regulatory consistency at all levels despite periodic mutation spikes cause by incorporation episodes related to immune avoidance strategies decided upon after error prone attempts for circulating hostile milieu

title: Polyomaviruses KI and WU in Immunocompromised Patients with Respiratory Disease
abstract: Polyomaviruses KI (KIPyV) and WU (WUPyV) were recently identified, mainly in respiratory specimens from children. Among 200 patients with respiratory disorders admitted to Saint Louis Hospital, Paris, France, KIPyV was detected in 8% and WUPyV in 1%. KIPyV was significantly more frequent among human stem cell transplant patients (17.8% vs. 5.1%; p = 0.01).

title: Gene expression in epithelial cells in response to pneumovirus infection
abstract: Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) and pneumonia virus of mice (PVM) are viruses of the family Paramyxoviridae, subfamily pneumovirus, which cause clinically important respiratory infections in humans and rodents, respectively. The respiratory epithelial target cells respond to viral infection with specific alterations in gene expression, including production of chemoattractant cytokines, adhesion molecules, elements that are related to the apoptosis response, and others that remain incompletely understood. Here we review our current understanding of these mucosal responses and discuss several genomic approaches, including differential display reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and gene array strategies, that will permit us to unravel the nature of these responses in a more complete and systematic manner.

title: The VNTR Polymorphism of the DC-SIGNR Gene and Susceptibility to HIV-1 Infection: A Meta-Analysis
abstract: This meta-analysis study investigates the association between the VNTR polymorphism of the DC-SIGNR gene and susceptibility to HIV-1 infection among different populations. Variable number tandem repeat (VNTR) polymorphisms have been associated with various diseases, but its role in susceptibility to HIV-1 is not clear. In this paper, epidemiological data from studies investigating the link between VNTR variations in DC-SIGNR gene and HIV-1 infection were compiled through a systematic review of articles published from 2000 to 2020 and included a total population sample size of 1547 subjects distributed across 8 countries on 4 continents.
